story:
"RETURN TO HOME BASE"

(An Acapella Musical Play in Two Acts Uplifting Black Veterans who served in Vietnam)

An Austin Veterans Arts Festival (AVAFEST 2019) PLAY

 

"At the beginning of the play "Return To Home Base", a Black soldier, Brain Keith, lies alone in the jungle of Vietnam mortally wounded. As we watch his life slipping away. He recalls the highlights and the low lights of his life. We learn about this young man in an intimate telling of his story,  through the frail incites created from the pain and agony of his memories. We re-live those moments in a way that we as the audience,  begin to form a relationship with the character that allows us to understand and, perhaps, truly care about him and others in war in a way that we never have been able to do before in war. Brain Keith becomes not just a name in our memories, of a young black soldier fallen in Vietnam, or name on a monument or wall, but a living breathing person that the audience grows to know and  once knew as a person who served his country despite its indifferences towards him."

Hello, my name is Glenn Towery, I am an award winning screenplay writer.  In 1988, I was a finalist in the Inner City Cultural Centers National short play competition with my entry, "SHADOW BOXER."  I am a graduate of Columbia College Hollywood, graduating in 1997 as the valedictorian of my class. It was there that I completed filming my award winning feature-length project "The Frequency." Recently, I won awards at both the CANNES and HOLLYWOOD screenplay contests OFFICIAL FINALIST AWARD in the Sci-Fi category for my screenplay, "STARFUNK and the ASTRAL PIONEERS." As an entrepreneur, I am the founder and chairman of the Veterans Suicide Prevention Channel (VSPChannel), that sponsoring the Austin Veterans Arts Festival, AVAFEST 2019 scheduled to take place in October/November 2019.


I am writing to ask you to support my latest project, "RETURN TO HOME BASE", an acapella musical play written in two acts, for the Austin Veterans Arts Festival AVAFEST 2019. "Return to Home Base" was written several years ago and this festival, is perfect for its debut. I am both the writer and the composer for this play. In order to produce this play, we need to raise about $7,850.00 "Return to Home Base" is a well-written play, and it is done in such a way that it can become a healing experience for many veterans who come to see it. Initially, I began writing this play for selfish reasons. I wanted to try and understand the things that happened to me while growing up in America and while I serving in Vietnam on a United States Navy destroyer. I suppose it was a form of healing for me as I battled with PTSD. However, soon I began to realize that "Return to Home Base" was not only about me because the lead character, Brain Keith, began to become a composite character of many Black soldier's and sailor's stories that I had heard over time after my return to the United States. America is so eager to show its might, that often, it doesn't want to know about the lives of the people that are actually sent into combat. I know this because I was medically evacuated out of Vietnam in November of 1972 in pretty bad condition. Not by wounds visited upon me by the enemy, but by those with whom I served.

Although I suffered many racial indignities and attacks as a service member in Vietnam aboard my ship, the USS Rupertus, DD851, I am still proud of my service to America. Yet, it is still important for me to be real about my service to understand what happened and why. As a writer, it is equally important for the viewers to understand how we as a nation and warring culture allowed ourselves to destroy valuable caring human beings during the Vietnam war, and why we fought with a cultural divide amongst blacks and whites who served together.

 

 

WHAT IS THE VETERAN SUICIDE PREVENTION CHANNEL & AVAFEST?

The Veterans Suicide Prevention Channel  (VSPChannel) was founded in 2015. The VSPChannel is a nonprofit 501 c3 organization dedicated to the preservation of veterans lives by working to prevent suicide. "Return to Home Base" is a part of the Austin Veterans Arts Festival (AVA,FEST) which has been created for the sole purpose of using the arts to save veterans lives. Art has become a powerful tool that helps heal veterans. The national AVAFEST festival is intended to attract veterans nationwide and introduce them to the curative power of art to promote wellness in vetreans who are suffering the symptoms of PTSD. PTSD symptoms including depression, anxiety, paranoia, guilt and anger often lead to the suicides of as many as 20 veterans a day. That is nearly 8,000 veterans a year lost to the senseless act of suicide. Our theme for this festival is "HEALING VETERANS USING THE ARTS & COMMUNITY."

 

How Your Support Can Help Us Produce "Return to Home Base"

We are living in some very trying times these days. Racist, or seemingly racist, views are expressed on social media every day. People forget that many people of diverse cultures have given their lives for freedoms that we now enjoy in America. By helping us to produce this play for the festival, you will be reaffirming the fact that we as Americans embrace and honor every culture who has migrated to our shores and served in the military to defend our nation with their lives.

 

WHAT THIS PLAY COULD MEAN TO BLACK VIETNAM VETERANS

Why is it so important to have "Return to Home Base" in the AVAFEST festival for black Vietnam veterans? All branches of the military during the Vietnam war experienced racial upheavals because of perceived biases during that war. These biases have been practiced since the Civil War, WWI, WWII and other wars that preceded Vietnam. African American veterans traditionally have been forced to fight for a country that refused to give them the same rights and privileges that it afforded its other citizens. There were documented protests and even revolts in the military during the Vietnam war while African American sailors and soldiers served at a higher percentage, population wise, than their white counterparts.


The Vietnam war was not fought by a volunteer army. The soldiers who fought were drafted, which was a way of saying, they were forced to fight because if you did not report to the military after you received a draft notice, you were breaking United States law and could be imprisoned. So, we had a situation during the Vietnam war where young black men were forced to join a military organization that was already biased against them and be sent far away from their homes to fight in a country they did not know, against people who had never done them any harm, while serving in a military unit that subjected them to racist treatment as part of their built-in system.

"Return to Home Base" can be healing for veterans to recognize what they went through as seen through the experience of the Black soldier presented in this play. The play, through its main character, Brain Keith, memorializes their treatment in that war and in America. In that way, "Return to Home Base" uplifts the African American veteran by way of showing some of the truths of their service that have been hidden away and never really discussed in the general public.

I wrote this play because I, too, was a victim of  racial injustice in Vietnam and I want the experience of veterans like myself to finally reach the light of day. It is in this way that this play, Return To Home Base may be able to promote some healing in veterans just by seeing it and hearin the songs. Please donate to day to bring Return To Home Base live at the National Austin Veterans Arts Festival.


"Learn to forgive, but always remember, to bring healthy healing from traumatic injury!"
 

Glenn Towery

story:
Short Summary

Where We Are Right Now!

Our first two shows have been booked in the first quarter of 2020!

*PIZZAZZ venues have been reserved, and deposits have been made

*PIZZAZZ show insurance is paid

*PIZZAZZ performers have committed and are waiting for their contracts

*PIZZAZZ features one of the already committed 27 acts on our social media site every week

*PIZZAZZ   includes a live orchestra that brings the classic revue-style which can be duplicated over and over.

*PIZZAZZ is included in a 400,000 distribution 2020 Playbill

*PIZZAZZ’s largest show features 9 acts and a live orchestra.

*We have already secured 27 acts and are aiming for 40 to ensure as little duplication as possible.

Thank you so much for your interest in this exciting show!

HERE'S HOW YOU CAN BECOME A PIZZAZZ SUPPORTER!

Any donation that you can provide will help defray the costs of theater space rentals, performer stipends, videographers, insurance, & stage management teams

What We Need & What You Get

FINANCIAL APPENDIX

What we need your help with (*$17,140 Indiegogo transaction fee not included)
*It’s possible! 745 folks@23$ or 380 folks @45$

All contributors in the United States will receive a personal phone call from the Producers of this show, as a way to say thank you for supporting this effort, in the most personal of ways.

The Cost Breakdown

Performer + Orchestra  Stipends 2 shows- $5066

Stage Management Team Stipends 2 shows -$1200

Videographers  2 shows-$3000

Orchestra original arrangements templates-$550

Two performing arts rental spaces $4250

Host's stipends 2 shows- $2400

Insurance 2 booked venues-$674

What we cover with ticket sales ($8560)

media & printing -$3300

social media postings mgr- $300

Indiegogo reward supplies - $4000

backstage food/drink for rehearsals and performance - $300

Additional startup investment-$660

Excess funds:

All excess funds will be reinvested in future shows.

Other Ways You Can Help

CASH IS NOT THE ONLY WAY YOU CAN HELP!

Like/Follow us on Facebook @PizzazzVariety. Help spread the word by liking & sharing our posts & this campaign with other supporters of the arts!

For Tampa/St. Petersburg, FL contributors, we welcome volunteers for ushering, stage management, tech work, print material designs, publicity photography & videography, etc, all forms of help are invited for consideration and appreciated.

Kenny and Nicole are ready, won’t you join them?!?!?

Who We Are  

Meet the two people behind the PIZZAZZ story, co-producers, Kenny Silkie & Nicole Pennington!

Kenny & Nicole met at a weekly Variety Performers’ crossword puzzles brunch. Rather than do puzzles, they bonded over their love of what they do, and the wonderful, talented friends they shared. They wanted to share everyone’s unique gifts with the rest of the world. That was the beginning of PIZZAZZ!

Kenny Silkie is a veteran of the Variety arts and a comic that uses opera parodies to entertain.

He has performed at countless events and festivals, national theme parks, corporate events, award banquets, science centers, fundraisers, and even a clothing optional resort.

He’s appeared as a Canadian trapper in one-piece long johns; a Roman centurion named Patheticus; Pinocchio as an older man; a giant lightning bug named Bulb; a honeybee queen named Aunt Bee, and even as Leonardo DaVinci’s brother Bob. He has seen Variety entertainment from the inside!

He has also spent a lifetime in the broadcast and the advertising industry. He has written, produced, and managed miles of advertising and commercial campaigns.

Nicole Pennington is an actor, singer, dancer, and producer, with a decade of experience working with her film production company, Liberty Lane Productions, featured on Netflix, and commercially as a producer with the Home Shopping Network.

Around the time she met Kenny, her itch to step back onstage had become insatiable. Drawing on her roots in musical theatre and blending thematic elements of human form study that had emerged in her photographic & video artwork, her performance art evolved towards a Burlesque persona, and her stage character Kiki von Blumen was born.

Blending her experience on and offstage, behind and in front of the camera, she is ready to take on this project.

Hooray!!! and Yikes!!!  They need your help!!

story:
What is Bay Area Zeta Players?

Bay Area Zeta Players is a completely student run theatre company based in Oakland. We started in 2014 as Nerdology Musical Theatre, and since expanded to include a student-written Ten Minute Play Festival, and have put on two straight plays over the past few years.

We pride ourselves on selecting material that speaks to the teenage experience and is rarely seen on stage. Starmites: The Musical is a vibrant, 80's style piece of theater that is rarely performed, and we are excited to bring it to life on the stage! 

We Need Your Help!

BAZP is funded almost entirely by donations. We want to give all participants a professional experience and a product with high production value, and for that we need you! The proceeds from this campaign will pay for sets, props, costumes, theater space, and printing; all the things that make a good show a great show!

Thanks to our fiscal sponsor Media Alliance all of your donations are tax deductible. You also have access to amazing perks such as tickets to the shows and merchendise signed by our cast!

The Impact

BAZP offers professional theatre experiences for all participants 100% free of charge. We are a diverse group of students from a wide variety of backgrounds and we make it a priority for our company to give all students access to an inclusive ensemble that explores all aspects of theatre. Being a student run company creates an equal ground for anyone to share their ideas and everyone to feel supported and heard. First and foremost, BAZP strives to support high school students to use their passion for the arts to enrich the community.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not able to make a donation, please spread the word around about our show! Starmites: The Musical, runs June 28th-30th, at the Flight Deck Theater in Downtown Oakland. 

 

Why should I donate?

 

1. BAZP is entirely student run.

Bay Area Zeta Players, after Generation Z, is completely run by high school students (and our middle-school mentee program). This includes, but is not limited to, actors, directors, stage managers, choreographers, musicians, vocal directors, and a full company board. We appreciate our partnerships and involvement with: our adult audience members, partner organizations, and fiscal sponsor: Media Alliance.

2. BAZP’s sole form of income is through donations and ticket sales.

We are a registered 501(c)(3) under Media Alliance. All of our revenue comes from ticket sales, donations, and sponsorships -and it goes right back to producing theatre, year after year.

3. No teen pays to be a part of BAZP.

Bay Area Zeta Players offers an immersive hands-on theatre education and experience to teens free of charge. No exceptions. Unlike pay-to-play youth and teen theatres, BAZP actors do shows with us for free. This allows teens from all over the Bay Area to share diverse narratives, and connect with other teens through our season each year, regardless of financial circumstance.

 

What if I can't donate a significant amount?

In our sixth season of producing theatre, we know that anything helps. Donations go to the season in the form of:

Venue Rental

Licensing & Rights

Sets, props, and costumes

Tech equipment (lights, microphones, etc.)

Any donation, small or large, keeps our beloved company afloat each season!

 

But, why does it even matter?

Since its founding in 2014, BAZP has become a staple of the Bay Area teen theatre community. It offers a unique and empowering theatre experience for all participants each season. Here, we share our love for theatre with our community, and represent youth art while doing so. We hope that you'll donate and spread the word.

Thanks for your time!

story:
Short Summary

New Industry Dance brings contemporary dance to South Bend through public performances, open classes, and community events. We strongly believe in the power of movement to heal, express, and connect. We aim to facilitate a safe space for all movers to engage in introspection, discovery, and personal expression. Through artistic collaboration and community engagement, we add dance as a valued language in the creative culture of South Bend and bring people together through our craft.

New Industry Dance functions in a highly do-it-yourself fashion; we do not have a brick and mortar space to call our own, and many of our spaces used for rehearsals, community events, and performances are generously offered to us by people and organizations in the community. Their support is crucial and without it, we could not continue our work.

As we prepare for our next season of dance in South Bend, we need your support. Your contribution will allow us to continue to collaborate and produce with voices in our community to create work born of diverse perspectives and art that inspires deeper thought, invites questions, and highlights human experiences. 

What We Need & What You Get

New Industry Dance needs your to help to raise $10,000. All funds raised will go toward production costs for the 2019-2020 season, including a large-scale community project.

Your contribution will assist in covering artistic and production costs, including:

Dancer stipends

Venue fees

Rehearsal space fees

Costuming fees (design, construction, materials)

Collaborating artist compensation

Marketing (print/web, graphic design, printing costs)

Photography and videography

Production supplies (props, curtains, miscellaneous)

New Industry Dance is a team of 8 dance artists (Chloe Ilene, Anna Greenawalt, Joanna Whitmyer, Sharon Sims, Mallory McAfee, Madeline Williamson, Isabelle Hanson, and Timothy McGinnis) and a company composer (Patrick Quiqley).

Our season contains public performances in the Winter and Spring. We will continue offering movement workshops, sound bath events, hosting guest artists, and performing at events like the Artists' Mixer.

Depending on your contribution level, you will receive supporter merchandise (sticker, T-Shirt, or poster), an invite to visit a rehearsal, mutual benefit support through program mentions or brand visibility on our website, season tickets, or be invited to a rehearsal. At the highest level, you will enjoy a full-length preview of a work and season tickets, or we will perform at one of your events, to be discussed with the artistic director.

The Impact

New Industry Dance adds to the cultural and artistic fabric of South Bend by providing public dance performances, open classes, movement workshops, sound bath events, and hosting visiting guest artists (bringing outsiders to South Bend).

Thanks to the money raised during last year's campaign, New Industry Dance was able to produce two evening-length productions (/in·habit/ and SENSORIMOTOR), host a three-part movement workshop series, continue open classes for the community, and host two visiting artists (Maceo Pailsey (LA) and Ron Shalom (NY)). We were also able to host sound bath and movement meditations events, with much success. Finally, we partnered with Browning Cinema at the DeBartolo Performing Arts Center to screen Bronx Gothic, a dance documentary.

Our work has an extended reach into a variety on non-arts organizations and educational institutions in our community, such as The LGBTQ Center and Clay High School, who have both hosted us for movement workshops. It is our hope that with the success of this campaign, we can continue to expand the depth of our reach within the educational system and at-risk communities.

    Risks & Challenges

    New Industry Dance produces all of our work purely from the contributions of our donors. We do not have any ongoing sponsorships or continued financial support. That means everything we do in one season relies on the contributions from this campaign. Our biggest risk is not raising enough money to support our upcoming season. Last year we increased our donor pool to around 60 persons. This year our goal is to increase our donor pool to 100-150 persons.

    Your contributions to our campaign show a community commitment to prioritizing dance as an important language of creative expression and a necessary voice in our arts and culture scene. With the success of this campaign, we will produce two full-length productions, including a large community project supported by the Indiana Arts Commission in Spring 2020. We will continue to bring outside guest artists to South Bend, to offer community classes and events, and we will expand our reach into more educational institutions.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you cannot help fund this campaign right now, you can always contribute by sharing our fundraiser with others who may want to help. The Indiegogo share tools make it easy to spread the word!

    In the meantime, stay tuned by following us on social media or subscribing to our email list. We hope to see you at a dance event soon!
story_txt:
Short Summary
New Industry Dance brings contemporary dance to South Bend through public performances, open classes, and community events. We strongly believe in the power of movement to heal, express, and connect. We aim to facilitate a safe space for all movers to engage in introspection, discovery, and personal expression. Through artistic collaboration and community engagement, we add dance as a valued language in the creative culture of South Bend and bring people together through our craft.
New Industry Dance functions in a highly do-it-yourself fashion; we do not have a brick and mortar space to call our own, and many of our spaces used for rehearsals, community events, and performances are generously offered to us by people and organizations in the community. Their support is crucial and without it, we could not continue our work.
As we prepare for our next season of dance in South Bend, we need your support. Your contribution will allow us to continue to collaborate and produce with voices in our community to create work born of diverse perspectives and art that inspires deeper thought, invites questions, and highlights human experiences. 

What We Need & What You Get
New Industry Dance needs your to help to raise $10,000. All funds raised will go toward production costs for the 2019-2020 season, including a large-scale community project.
Your contribution will assist in covering artistic and production costs, including:
Dancer stipends
Venue fees
Rehearsal space fees
Costuming fees (design, construction, materials)
Collaborating artist compensation
Marketing (print/web, graphic design, printing costs)
Photography and videography
Production supplies (props, curtains, miscellaneous)
New Industry Dance is a team of 8 dance artists (Chloe Ilene, Anna Greenawalt, Joanna Whitmyer, Sharon Sims, Mallory McAfee, Madeline Williamson, Isabelle Hanson, and Timothy McGinnis) and a company composer (Patrick Quiqley).
Our season contains public performances in the Winter and Spring. We will continue offering movement workshops, sound bath events, hosting guest artists, and performing at events like the Artists' Mixer.
Depending on your contribution level, you will receive supporter merchandise (sticker, T-Shirt, or poster), an invite to visit a rehearsal, mutual benefit support through program mentions or brand visibility on our website, season tickets, or be invited to a rehearsal. At the highest level, you will enjoy a full-length preview of a work and season tickets, or we will perform at one of your events, to be discussed with the artistic director.

The Impact
New Industry Dance adds to the cultural and artistic fabric of South Bend by providing public dance performances, open classes, movement workshops, sound bath events, and hosting visiting guest artists (bringing outsiders to South Bend).

Finally, we partnered with Browning Cinema at the DeBartolo Performing Arts Center to screen Bronx Gothic, a dance documentary.
Our work has an extended reach into a variety on non-arts organizations and educational institutions in our community, such as The LGBTQ Center and Clay High School, who have both hosted us for movement workshops. It is our hope that with the success of this campaign, we can continue to expand the depth of our reach within the educational system and at-risk communities.


Risks & Challenges
New Industry Dance produces all of our work purely from the contributions of our donors. We do not have any ongoing sponsorships or continued financial support. That means everything we do in one season relies on the contributions from this campaign. Our biggest risk is not raising enough money to support our upcoming season. Last year we increased our donor pool to around 60 persons. This year our goal is to increase our donor pool to 100-150 persons.
Your contributions to our campaign show a community commitment to prioritizing dance as an important language of creative expression and a necessary voice in our arts and culture scene. With the success of this campaign, we will produce two full-length productions, including a large community project supported by the Indiana Arts Commission in Spring 2020. We will continue to bring outside guest artists to South Bend, to offer community classes and events, and we will expand our reach into more educational institutions.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot help fund this campaign right now, you can always contribute by sharing our fundraiser with others who may want to help. The Indiegogo share tools make it easy to spread the word!
In the meantime, stay tuned by following us on social media or subscribing to our email list. We hope to see you at a dance event soon!

story:
ABOUT FRINGE AND FUR'S MISSION:

  • We are two emerging women artists who hire other bad ass women artists to make artistically, intellectually, and physically rigorous theater that challenges American identity, particularly as it pertains to ideas of gender,  fantasy, and nation through multimodal storytelling.

 

  • We are fundraising to produce a fully designed production of The Hopelessly Hopeless Story of All Good Girls  at THE BRICK 2020 February 9-23. AND we are paying a fair wage to each of our artists (We believe women should be financially empowered while making art!) 

 

  • Not only is 'HH' our longest standing creative collaboration (3 years in the making!! --thats a lot of rehearsal!) It is also our dream to produce a final version with a score, video design, set design and lights that we would be proud to tour in the years to come. 

 

  • We need your contribution to make all of the above happen and happen fast! Help us support the brilliant and boundary-pushing work of our designers: Video Designer: Dena Kopolovich, Set Designer: Emily Greco,  Lighting Designer: Marika Kent, Sound Designer: Margaret Montagna, Stage Manager: Cara Cincione!

 

  • Bonus Perk: Not only are our perks super dope but...The Hopelessly Hopeless Story Of All Good Girls is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization that shares their 501C3 status with us so we can make all donations made tax deductible! 

 

ABOUT HOPELESSLY HOPELESS:

  • The Hopelessly Hopeless Story of All Good Girls is a play with film and music. The play explores the inner lives of two women- a grandmother and granddaughter- who have experienced an unspeakable loss.

​(Check out pictures of past iterations of The Hopelessly Hopeless Story of All Good Girls here.)

  • They live in a ranch house together, trapped in Colorado, and ruled by their inherited domestic rituals. They go to the store, they dress up in fancy clothes, they smoke cigarettes, they sink into depression, they dread the phone’s ringing, and they drink very tall glasses of whole milk. All is revealed when they both have sexually charged encounters with the middle aged Man Next Door.

Merging film clips, movement, and scripted dialogues with texts from Adrienne Rich, Gloria Steinem, Julie London, Judy Garland, and Andy Warhol in the tradition of Kathy Acker, the characters’ identities blur as they seek a more fulfilling way to exist.

The ranch house, both a solace and a prison, serves as a setting to explore dread of the domestic, empty suburban lifestyles, and the violent alienation just beneath surface of American culture.

story:
OVERVIEW

Hello, my name is Julius Powell and I am the lead artist and creator of IF I KNEW YOU WERE COMING I WOULD HAVE WORN EYESHADOW--an experimental theater piece which was originally developed this summer at La Mama ETC’s Next Generation Artist Residency in Italy. I am so excited to announce that EYESHADOW will be having an in-development workshop production at The Tank here in New York City in February of 2020. The EYESHADOW production team and I are asking for your support in helping us put this show up on its feet, and providing us with a stable grounding which will allow us to experiment and invest in the future of this show. 

 

BRIEF SUMMARY OF EYESHADOW

In the time period directly succeeding desegregation and monumental movements in civil rights, disco, house, and dance music were forged as a modes of escape and entertainment for a number of marginalized individuals, particularly African American and queer individuals in urban environments. In these spaces, the life outside of the “break-down” was an afterthought, an aspect of the lived experience that needed to be set aside in order to continue on with life. 

How, in the face of death, were these individuals able to find joy and self-expression? How could the aspiration for euphoria and higher forms of existence actually manifest for these individuals? And how do I, as a descendent of these individuals, find my own euphoria? I find myself turning back to this idea of the seemingly never-ending disco song. To dance meant to forget, or to acknowledge, or to do some strange combination of both. In their article discussing the cultural significance of disco, Tan Lin defines the genre as, “the line between singing and acting, listening and participating, between a celebrity and what Warhol called a ‘nobody’,”. In thinking about this project, I find that the celebrity and “nobody” are individuals that live inside each of us, and the line between them are as thick or thin as we desire them to be, or perhaps societal boundaries keep us from seeing the two existing on the same plane. 

Inspired by interviews, various pieces of media, and oral history, If I Knew You Were Coming I Would Have Worn Eyeshadow finds Frisky Jones, a genderqueer sex worker balancing the line between celebrity and nothingness. In 60 minutes Eyeshadow remembers and showcases Frisky’s height and demise. Using “drag”, text, dance, lip sync, and experimental forms, the show explores what it means to escape one’s reality and, in doing so, what some must ultimately leave behind in a world set against us. Part repressed memory, part drag show, part interrupted stream of consciousness--Eyeshadow has several expectations, but then again, who has expectations these days?

 

WHY IT MATTERS

Making new work as a young artist here in New York City presents a number of obstacles, one of the major barriers is funding. In the work that I create, I find it immensely important to create stories that highlight Black and LGBTQIA+ experiences, particularly with themes regarding race, gender, and sexuality’s relationship to society. While I do see a beautiful influx of new work that highlights marginalized communities, I also desire to establish myself as an artist here in New York City that is a part of the growing community of young experimental theater artists finding new ways to challenge what we define as “theater” and “performance”. 

To be frank (and optimistic?), Eyeshadow’s development so far, and what has yet to come, has provided me with the opportunity to showcase my work, share cultural differences with international communities, and gain knowledge of new modes of storytelling. To see this show grow, would mean the world to me, and I see it introducing a number of opportunities not only for me, but also for the stellar production team that is helping bring this show to life. 

 

FUNDING AND OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

The Tank has provided a great system for us to have space for showings, and technical support, however additional production costs are on our production team. We are seeking avenues to make costs as low as possible, but there are of course some things that we have to invest in such as technology, set pieces, costumes, etc. All of the funds that are accumulated through our crowd sourcing campaign will go towards the production and future of Eyeshadow including compensating collaborators, and production costs. 

If you would not like to donate to this project, but would like to donate to a charitable organization, I highly recommend making a donation to the Audre Lorde Project, a Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Two Spirit, Trans and Gender Non-Conforming People of Color community organizing center, focusing on the New York City area.

If you are able to make a donation to the organization independent of this production it would be greatly appreciated. 

Sharing this fundraiser page as well with your family and friends would also be immensely helpful. 

No matter if you’re able to donate or share, we hope that you’ll join us in February 2020 at The Tank. And if you are unable to join us, sharing this campaign in your communities by word of mouth or any avenue, would help us greatly.

 

THE TEAM

Julius Powell (Creator, Lead Artist)
Rebecca Rouse (Scenographer, Collaborator)
Myra McPhee (Dramturg, Collaborator)
Caroline Burkhart (Choreographer, Collabrator)
Callum Bayle-Spence (Visual & Projection Design, Collaborator)
Dan Lalor (Video and Photo Documentarian)

For more information on Julius, including their previous work, future work, and biography, visit juliusjordanpowell.com

story:
“The production reaches the heights of perversion, existential depth and parody, with the madcap humor of Robin Williams, Eugene Ionesco, filmmaker John Waters and the gymnastics of Buster Keaton. Just downright ‘dirty’! Pure Pataphysics.” – Ernest Abuba, Pan-Asian Rep Theatre Company

From out of the depths of a grungy garage comes GAME NITE—a rude, raucous and ridiculous sendup of machismo gone wild. An infestation of raccoons in Mickey’s mancave threatens to tear Mickey and Dawn apart, so Dawn takes it upon herself to rid their home of beasts. As the filth piles up, food products are thrown around, masculinity is wrestled with (literally), and all the madness explodes at a grotesque football-Saturday party—Game Nite.

We have been given the opportunity to perform a full production of GAME NITE at Access Theater! We intend to use this production to lay the groundwork for further productions of works new and old, giving opportunities to all manner of weird, wild, wacky theatremakers—and we hope you can help us get started on this journey!

 

WHO ARE WE:

JACKSON TUCKER-MEYER is the writer and director of GAME NITE!!

LILY WELSH is the choreographer of GAME NITE, and also plays SKIP!!

CYNTHIA CUNNINGHAM is the producer of GAME NITE!!

CAMBER CARPENTER as DAWN!!

ETHAN GRAHAM-HOROWITZ as MICKEY!!

FRANK HALBIGER as TIM!!

SEAN BARRY as BIG PETEY SWEETS!!

ANDREA STAATS as ???!!

 

HOW WE’RE GONNA DO IT:

Fun Fact: GAME NITE has received two productions before this! First, it was performed fully-staged on campus at Sarah Lawrence College! It was really joyful, and proved that this play is, in fact, performable! The last time we performed GAME NITE, we were able to put on a sold-out staged reading through the magic of crowdfunding!

Using the money left over from ticket sales for the staged reading, we have scheduled a series of staged readings of COOL NEW PLAYS to help raise money--the LOUD COLORFUL FILTH Reading Series:

MANIC PIXIE DREAM GIRL, by Lily Welsh

PARADISE LOST AND FOUND by Brynn Hambley

THANKYOUFORLISTENING by Mariah Busk, VIRTUALLY YOURS by India Stachyra, JETTA & ZOOZY SAVE THE WORLD by Jackson Tucker-Meyer

Once we produce this new and improved version of GAME NITE, we will be able to apply for artists’ grants, so we can move forward with producing more exciting works of theatre—like full productions of the aforementioned COOL NEW PLAYS! This also means that we will not have to ask you, kind donor, for money anymore, as we will have more opportunity to subsidize our work!

 

WHERE THE MONEY GOES:

Thanks to the generosity of Access Theater, most of our rental expenses for rehearsal and performance space have been waived! However, we still have many expenses that need to be paid:

 

PAYING ACTORS: $300 x 6 = $1,800

PAYING DESIGNERS: $300 x 3 = $900

PAYING STAGE MANAGERS: $300 x 2 = $600

SETS / PROPS / COSTUMES: $500

RENTAL FEES: $2,900

CONTINGENCY: $300

 

TOTAL: $7,000

 

As you can see, the vast majority of the budget is going towards paying everybody on our team. This was the main priority last time we fundraised, for our staged reading, and we were successful last time—we paid for the space and we paid everyone! We hope to do this again--and again, and again, and again, as we continue making strange and wondrous theatre.

 

RISKS & REWARDS:

The risk, of course, is that we may not be able to put on the show. We’ll still have accomplished something—with the readings, we’ll have given exposure to several early-career playwrights, and that alone will be a wonderful achievement. However, if we can’t raise enough money for this production, we will have an equally arduous time raising funds for whichever project we attempt next.

However, to reiterate—if we DO manage to put on this show, it will be much easier for us to raise money for our next project through more traditional means! With a fully-staged, well-documented performance of a new play under our belt, we will be able to apply for grants to fund our future endeavors.

Please, if you can, take a moment to invest in a group of theatremakers creating beautiful work—and if you can’t, please share with anyone who can!

 

Thank you for your kindness.

story:
An Evening with

ONASSIS

Financers/Producers Run

Off Broadway

at

AMERICAN THEATRE OF ACTORS (NYC)

(Tickets on sale to the public) 

 

Culture Spot LA " Skordi has got his character down pat, the same way you know that STREEP has perfected Julia Child or Margaret Thatcher. This is the mark of a highly professional actor who has mastered his craft.."

 

We are preparing a 5 week Producers/Financers run to bring in potential investors and producers  for a NYC run. In order to do that, we need to put the show up and invite potential collaborators to it. The performances will also be open for ticket purchase to the general public.

 

ONASSIS opened to critical acclaim and standing ovations * years ago at the Stella Adler Theatre in Los Angeles. It's time for a NYC run!

 

CRITICS PICK *****

  • Grigware "Skordi is a master story teller seducing his audience"

  • Broadway World ''Suave, charming, ego maniac Aristotle Onassis comes to vivid life through the brilliantly modulated, cautiously executed and intensely focused performance of Anthony Skordi on the stage. You will be captivated by the magnificent artistry of Anthony Skordi's acting''

 

What we need the funding for

  • Theatre rental  ($12,750)
  • Lighting Designer
  • Sound designer
  • Stage Manager
  • Front of house
  • PR
  • Props/Furniture
  • Costume
  • Poster/Postcards
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Accommodation
  • Travel expenses

 

West Coast Review

BWWNEWS DESK: "ONASSIS" starring Anthony Skordi at The Stella Adler Theatre. Audiences and critics who raved about Anthony Skordi's tour de force as Edgar AllenPoe in “Poe,” will not be disappointed with his depiction of the megalomaniac - Aristotle Onassis. Skordi is a master of storytelling. Seducing the audience, in much the same way, Ari himself might have done with world leaders in his home or aboard his famous Yacht “The Christina.” Skordi does the impossible, by enabling the audience to relate to the overwhelmingly complex, even mythical, character of Onassis. Skordi manages to bring Aristotle Onassis' storybook existence ... or to some a Greek tragedy, to life in just under ninety minutes. Patrons not only laughed out loud, but often found themselves responding emotionally to Skordi's depiction of the man who entertained everyone from business tycoons and royalty to the icons of stage and screen, as well as Presidents … and their wives"

 

 

ANTHONY SKORDI

http://www.imdb.me/anthonyskordi

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Skordi

 

Anthony Skordi as ONASSIS

 

 

 

"The Hunger for love is harder to remove than the hunger for bread"

The richest man in the World, the most renowned playboy and perhaps, ultimately, the loneliest man, burdened with what many of us crave.

In today's World we judge ourselves by our material possessions and financial achievements. We often lose sight of what is fundamentally important and meaningful. In the struggle to own the newest gadget and fancy car, our life passes us by. In our climb to the highest peak, we might forget to enjoy the scenery on the journey. In the battle to achieve what we think will fix us, we forget it's an inside job, it's about relationships, family and love. We spend our time carving out a career to make money in order to buy the things we enjoy but end up having no time to enjoy them...

​

 

Dikran Tulaine. Director

Dikran Tulaine Directing Resume
Training: Acting, at London Drama Centre 1977-1980
Iphigenia by Jean Racine at Sir Richard Steele, Haverstock Hill. London NW3The Christmas Carol by Charles Dickens at Good Luck Theatre Company. Covent Garden,Bob Sawyer’s Party, Sikes and Nancy, Dr Marigold, Dombey and Son by Charles Dickens. Platform Performances at The Royal National, London.Sikes and Nancy, Bob Sawyers Party, Clerkenwell Festival, Finsbury Town Hall, Rosebury
Lincoln by Robert Manns at the Atlanta Shakespeare Company, Atlanta, Ga.Galileo by Brecht at Atlanta Shakespeare Company, Atlanta, Ga.Christmas Carol at Atlanta Shakespeare Company, Atlanta, Ga., from 2003-2010
Pandoras Box, Various poets
The Iliad, adaptation by Dikran Tulaine
Action by Sam Shepard
Moonies Kid Don’t Cry and Talk to me Like the rain by Tennessee Williams at Push Push Theater Company Atlanta, Ga.
Julius Caesar By Shakespeare at Atlanta Shakespeare Company, Atlanta, Ga
The Happy Prince By Oscar Wilde at Atlanta Shakespeare Company
Antonio and Shylock (adaptation of Merchant of Venice) at Stage Left. West 30th street,NY, NY.
Hamlet, a one man show
Passion in the Desert by Balzac Richard Burton.s Christmas Story Mask of Apollo by Mary Renault
A Christmas Carol, one man show.

 

    Risks & Challenges

    We may not raise all the money, however, we will do as many performances as the money allows us to. The costs of New York theatre are staggering and we will adjust accordingly to whatever budget we find ourselves with. We can use the other space at the theatre which is much smaller audience (65), and stage for apex half the theatre rental space of the main house....

     

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute, you can still help by putting the word out and make some noise about our campaign.You can do this using the Indigo share tool Tweet, Facebook, email, etc

     

     

     

    Anthony Skordi as ONASSIS
     
     
     
     
     
     
     
     

     

    Some of Anthony Skordi's tv & film work

     

    Anthony Skordi in Star Wars Battlefront2

We are preparing a 5 week Producers/Financers run to bring in potential investors and producers  for a NYC run. In order to do that, we need to put the show up and invite potential collaborators to it. The performances will also be open for ticket purchase to the general public.
 
ONASSIS opened to critical acclaim and standing ovations * years ago at the Stella Adler Theatre in Los Angeles. It's time for a NYC run!

Grigware "Skordi is a master story teller seducing his audience"

Broadway World ''Suave, charming, ego maniac Aristotle Onassis comes to vivid life through the brilliantly modulated, cautiously executed and intensely focused performance of Anthony Skordi on the stage. You will be captivated by the magnificent artistry of Anthony Skordi's acting''

story:
221B
Baker Street, reimagined.

A new play by Ren Cleveland
Inspired by the works of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle

Directed by Lorelei Lemon
Creative team: Ren Cleveland and Zoe Barham

 

 

We're excited to say we're on the final leg of financial production for 221B. Big thank you's for all the support that's got us to this exciting stage. Production costs include: paying actors and designers, purchasing props, costumes, and scenic elements. A donation of any kind is deeply appreciated, as is sharing our campaign page with friends. We at Baker Street thank you sincerely for supporting our theatrical endeavors, and for helping us bring 221B to life for the triangle community.

 

Summary...

A 2019 Manbites Dog Grant recipient, 221B is a fiercely female-driven reimagining of the Sherlock Holmes classics. Inspired by the works of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, this contemporary adaptation rips the roof off the iconic Baker Street residences and puts the world’s greatest consulting detective face-to-face with perhaps her most dangerous mystery to date - her own humanity. Join us as Sherlock and Watson navigate murder, marriage, and the infamous criminal mastermind, Professor Moriarty. 221B seeks to be a conversational catalyst for themes regarding gender-equality via an entertaining expedition through Holmes and Watson’s contemporary London.

 

Note from the Playwright...

In response to the most common question we’ve received regarding the show - how did 221B come about? - I’d like to take this space to give a bit of background on how the play was written. 

The seed for 221B was planted deep in the roots of my childhood when a tiny girl with messy hair and a strange affinity for the macabre fell in love with the tales of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle’s enigmatic detective.

Fast forward to my adulthood, when I found myself directing an adaptation of Sherlock Holmes and cast the title role as female. When I’d bump into folks and they’d ask what I was up to, their responses began to form a pattern.

“A female Sherlock. What a concept?”

My, “Yeah.” soon evolved into, “Wait. Not yeah. A female Sherlock shouldn’t actually be a radical concept at all, because quite frankly there is nothing about Sherlock that constitutes the need to be male.”

(The same could be said about a whole slew of other roles… but I digress! Save those for the next project.)

That notion was the spark that, ten insomnia-spiked drafts later, would become 221B.

When pen first hit paper, I set out with two goals.

1. By reframing the iconic roles of Sherlock and Watson as women, I wanted to challenge the societal constraints of gender roles. To turn up the volume, 221B places Sherlock and Watson in modern day to highlight the rather unsettling truth - that much of the opposition women faced in Victorian London still exists in society today.

2. I wanted to showcase the characters as they were so brilliantly set forth by Doyle - as human beings - a matter that too often gets lost in translations that jump to frame the characters as archetypes. Sherlock’s, Watson’s, Mrs. Hudson’s, and Mycroft’s ability to thrive in the imaginations of fans through the decades is directly attributed to the fact that Doyle wrote them to be unapologetically human. To quote the script, “With all the broken pieces and eccentricities such a title entails.” We love them because we can relate to them.

At its core, 221B was created for anyone and everyone who’s ever been told they can’t do something simply because of who they are, indiscriminate of gender.

The hitch between Sherlock and conversations regarding gender roles seemed a perfect match for a detective who’s built their entire legacy off of not taking anything at face value. Sherlock stands for the underdogs, the unconventionals, the misunderstoods. 

You can’t do something simply because of who you are.

Seems a rather ridiculous statement when you look at the words in a line, right? I like to think Miss Sherlock Holmes would take a look at the statement above, crack that ole I-know-something-you-don’t-know grin with her pipe in the corner of her mouth, and gladly accept the challenge that summarizes the driving force behind 221B. 

Prove ‘em wrong.

story:
Jagged Nails

"A broken dancer journeys to Los Angeles in search of healing and a last chance to honor her dying mother."

  • I'm Kit Wilson-award-winning writer/producer/director of over six short films, acclaimed in over 54 Film Festivals around the world. I work with a seasoned crew and super talented cast dedicated to bringing a struggling dancer's journey to life. .
  • Working with a small, mobile crew, we're accurate film makers who don't waste time or money capturing the "magic" necessary to tell a fully-developed 15 minute film.
  • Because film production is a demanding process, that also incurs monies spent, we're looking for enthusiastic co-creators eager to join in the crafting, editing, and completion of a unique story-not told in a feature or tv episode. There is a seat for you at table for passionate dreamers, ready to make them come true.

What Is The Film's Needs

 We've estimated a full production budget at $9,000. After successfully funding and completing six previous short films that went on to become film festival award winners, we felt comfortable packaging our costs into the most valuable departments: ie. cast, crew, equipment rental, location scouting, costume and props, craft services, and transportation. The post production costs would cover captured footage editing, sound design, VFX, color correction, music  composition-recording-mixing, and possible pickup shots necessary to weave the film together in a seamless visual experience.                     

  • With a multi-tier opportunity to contribute, we've thought in creative ways to reward our new team members. The usual film credit, screening VOD, cast signed poster, VIP premiere invite will be available to modest investors, but for those who love dance, our studio will be open to share the skills of our cast dancers. Lunch with the director and  lead cast members will also be on the table.
  • Since we've already completed two shooting days to create our trailer, funds to pay our talent, crew and extras would be our first goal-with any remainder employed to capture further scenes in the story.

Is "Jagged Nails" Important?

  • Presently, we live in a chaos laden world where the creative arts have been badly tattered by lack of funding and apathy. "Jagged Nails" will electrify audiences and awaken them to the incredible passion each artist must focus to achieve their dreams. The constant theme in the film is "never give up", "never surrender."
  • We've created six short films with Seattle cast/crew that became award winning film festival stories. "TrickShop", "Drowned World", "Remnants", "Fragile Ghost", "A Twist of Time", "Layla's Rain"-all were screened in cities such as: London, Berlin, Munich, Florence, Rome, Vienna, Paris, Milan, Chicago, New York City, Los Angeles, Portland, and Washington state.
  • Please visit my IMDb page: "Kit Wilson"-or visit the FaceBook pages for our previous titled films, where details of festival awards and behind the scenes images are available. I'm also visible on LinkedIn for business connections and networking.

The Pitfalls of Film Making

I started out writing feature scripts after a successful book career on Amazon and Barnes & Noble. After completing seven production-ready scripts, I realized my Seattle location afforded a lot of obstacles to networking with Los Angeles studios and production companies. Consequently, I began to write short film scripts in the hopes that I could tap into the local talent/crew pool and actualize my dream of film making-though on a much smaller scale. the choice was immediately rewarding. From my written words, I watched actors, technicians, camera and grip creatives build the structure and erect a finished film. It was a fantastic learning experience. Every script I crafted afterward included techniques and subtle tweaks to actually produce a professional, audience-ready project. From MasterClass instruction, to books, dvds, seminars and one-on-one mentor opportunities-my screenwriting/producing/directing skills became evolved and sharpened.

Thanks to the passion and skills of my actors and crew, I've managed to "step into the fire" of a film production set and think on my feet, as countless decisions are made on the fly. Rather than be overwhelmed by the possible chaos, I learned to "trust" everyone on the teams and that allowed me to be stress-free as I orchestrated the story to its completion.

Working with a veteran crew and accomplished actresses and actors affords me the opportunity to fully concentrate on the tasks at hand and get the job done. Film making is a business and should be taken seriously. Not a "weekend warrior", or "run and gun" film maker, my professional standards won't allow any project I create to be subpar.

Is There Other Ways To Contribute-besides money?

We want to invite everyone to join our creative team in whatever capacity they feel comfortable in accomplishing. Use your social network to spread the "word" about "Jagged Nails" . Please visit our FaceBook, Instagram pages and support the project with positive feedback and continal encouragement. It will be greatly appreciated and we're honored to have you participate. Also, don't forget to use Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Our Story

BAM! (Bay Area Musicals) is the newest organization to join the vibrant Bay Area theatre community, calling San Francisco home.   

BAM! was founded by local leaders and theatre professionals in August of 2014.  The vision for Bay Area Musicals! was born from the realization that San Francisco had a void and was in need of an organization specializing in professional musical theatre.  Our vision is to (1) present classics as well as contemporary pieces, (2) exhibit diversity of appeal and diversity of cultures (3) exhibit local and national talent (4) prepare emerging artists for success in the professional musical theatre industry, and (5) cultivate original pieces from conception to premiere in San Francisco. 

We are an organization devoted to providing the highest caliber of musical theatre to the San Francisco Bay Area. Our promise and mission is this: 

"BAM! (Bay Area Musicals), a professional theatre company, stimulates and inspires the San Francisco community through high-caliber musical theatre ranging from familiar classics to challenging New Works; to produce professional musical theatre at accessible ticket rates; and to engage the community through performance, outreach, and educational opportunities."

Our Need 

The arts is a non-profit entity because it provides a service to the community, and we want to give to the San Francisco Bay Area scene for many years to come.  BAM! will be for San Francisco what the Lyric Theatre is for Atlanta, 5th Avenue Theatre is for Seattle, Papermill Playhouse is for New Jersey, and what American Musical Theatre was for the Bay Area. These regional theaters and more across the country are dedicated solely to the craft of American musical theatre and we want to join that list.   

But only if you help us. 

Only 50% of theatre companies' income and financial stability is achieved solely by ticket sales and other earned income.  For any theatre company to flourish and remain financially stable, it relies on donations from organizations, private donors, volunteers, partnerships, corporate sponsors, grants, and fundraising efforts.  As a start up company we will not even be eligible for most of those until the year 2019.  That means we have to rely on our community for support… such as your beautiful self. 


Our Inaugural Season

Marines' Memorial Theatre, Sutter Street

Victoria Theatre, 16th Street

Victoria Theatre, 16th Street 

Our Campaign Budget

BAM!'s entire season budget is $133,000----which is only because many professional artists, designers, admins, and specialists are donating their talents and services because they believe in what we want to do.  We are asking for $10,000, less than 10% of our total annual budget, in this campaign to get us off the ground and running for our first production.  Here is what that covers:


Your Perks

BAM! isn't just about the artists, our shows, or musical theatre.  It is much, much more.  It's about YOU: the relationships you make with BAM!, your support for BAM!, and how we are able to better serve this beautiful city.  Because of your help with seeing this monumental project come to fruition, BAM! wants to make sure you know how important you are.  You mean A LOT to us.  Take a look for yourself:

 


Bay Area theatre artists Daren A.C. Carollo and Kimberly Dooley speak about supporting BAM! 


Listen to Daren A.C. Carollo (Producing Artistic Director of Berkeley Playhouse) and Kimberly Dooley (Bay Area favorite director & choreographer) talk about why they are involved with BAM! and how your support today, determines our future moving forward.



The Impact 

    With over 250 companies in the Bay Area between the North Bay, South Bay, East Bay, and San Francisco---- WHY START BAM! (Bay Area Musicals)? Here are FIVE POINTS that combined, make BAM! unique. 

    1)  Diversity: We utilize local professionals in non-traditional casting, administration, and other artistic roles. All of our productions are chosen for a diverse audience and are selected to appeal to a wide audience inclusive of diversity in age, gender, race, and sexuality. We are a theater who reflect the world around us.

    2)  Professionalism: We use experienced Equity and non-Equity Actors, and pay all of our artistic staff, designers, and musicians.

    3)  Creativity: We will focus on creating original works for the musical theatre canon.  Integral to our mission is the cultivation of New Works from conception to production with world premieres in San Francisco.

    4)  Variety: Our season of musical choices will vary in style, mood, setting, and content. BAM! will be the only musical theatre company whose seasons present popular classics, modern musicals, and New Works.  And these New Works will be made possible through BAM!. 

    5)  Innovation: Our musicals will be told through original interpretations, presenting superior musical theatre pieces in innovative ways that speak to today’s audiences, and inspires new perspectives. 

    Our project affects the entire San Francisco community…  especially YOU! Our project is valuable to our funders.  With this new company alone we will be 1) creating jobs by utilizing the Bay Area's top professionals, 2) provide a safe and inviting environment that induces creativity, 3) present a variety of musicals through innovative eyes, and 4) educate and train the audiences of tomorrow so theater continues to enrich the lives of the San Francisco community.  

    The Team

    Matthew McCoy, Founder & Artistic Director

    To fulfill all of BAM!'s (Bay Area Musicals) objectives, Matthew McCoy, Founder & Artistic Director, has put together a team of local artists and community leaders – including respected Bay Area arts professionals, experienced development directors, attorneys, and entrepreneurs.  Combined, the team has over 200 years of experience in non-profit arts administration, event-based marketing and regional, international and Off-Broadway theatre.  The team includes Daren A.C. Carollo (Artistic Advisor/Berkeley Playhouse Producing Artistic Director), Kimberly Dooley (Artistic Advisor/Director&Choreographer), Carnell Freeman (Board Member), Jon Gallo (Secretary/Resident Music Director), Wilson Hardcastle (Vice President/Development), Michelle Ianiro (New Works), Kevin Kopjak (Board Member), Kirk Johnson (Marketing & Sales Director), Annette Lai (Volunteer Coordinator),  Matthew McCoy (Founder & Artistic Director), AeJay Mitchell (Managing Director), , Benjamin Nguyen (Community Outreach), Jon Tracy (Artistic Advisor), Aaron Vanderbeek (Webmaster) and Leslie Waggoner (Advertising).

    Risks & Challenges

    What happens if we don't reach our goal? 

    WE KEEP GOING! It will take up to three years to gain and build a devoted base of supporters who will continue seeing BAM! shows.  We might not reach that potential crowd with this fundraising campaign.  The money raised will go towards securing our most prominent needs in the season.  

    What qualifies us to overcome this issue?

    Our artistic and leading team is made up of the Bay Area's finest.  Each member is a specialist in their own field from marketing & finance to choreography & casting.  We are in great hands with the leaders of tomorrow's theatre.  

      Other Ways You Can Help

      1) Can't give now? That's okay! BAM! still loves you and we want you to be a part of our growing future.  Please stay connected for future events, fundraisers, or season announcements by joining our newsletter HERE.

      2) Save the date! Our first show, How To Succeed In Business Without Really Trying, will play November 28 -December 19, 2015.  Put that on your calendar NOW to join us.  Come see a show!

      3)  It takes a village to put on a show and we can only succeed with your help.  Become part of the BAM! family by sharing this project with your friends and loved ones. Help support BAM! and spread the word.
story_txt:
Our Story

BAM! (Bay Area Musicals) is the newest organization to join the vibrant Bay Area theatre community, calling San Francisco home.   


BAM! was founded by local leaders and theatre professionals in August of 2014.  The vision for Bay
Area Musicals! was born from the realization that San Francisco had a void and was in need of an
organization specializing in professional musical theatre.  Our vision is to (1)
present classics as well as contemporary pieces, (2) exhibit diversity of
appeal and diversity of cultures (3) exhibit local and national talent (4)
prepare emerging artists for success in the professional musical theatre industry, and (5) cultivate original pieces from conception to premiere in San
Francisco. 
We are an organization devoted to providing the highest caliber of musical theatre to the San Francisco Bay Area. Our promise and mission is this: 

"BAM! (Bay Area Musicals), a
professional theatre company, stimulates and inspires the San
Francisco community through high-caliber musical theatre ranging from familiar
classics to challenging New Works; to produce professional musical theatre at
accessible ticket rates; and to engage the community through performance,
outreach, and educational opportunities."

   Our Need  The arts is a non-profit entity because it provides a service to the community, and we want to give to the San Francisco Bay Area scene for many years to come.  BAM! will be for San Francisco what the Lyric Theatre is for Atlanta, 5th Avenue Theatre is for Seattle, Papermill Playhouse is for New Jersey, and what American Musical Theatre was for the Bay Area. These regional theaters and more across the country are dedicated solely to the craft of American musical theatre and we want to join that list.   
But only if you help us. 
Only 50% of theatre companies' income and financial stability is achieved solely by ticket sales and other earned income.  For any theatre company to flourish and remain financially stable, it relies on donations from organizations, private donors, volunteers, partnerships, corporate sponsors, grants, and fundraising efforts.  As a start up company we will not even be eligible for most of those until the year 2019.  That means we have to rely on our community for support… such as your beautiful self. 




Our Inaugural Season


Marines' Memorial Theatre, Sutter Street

Victoria Theatre, 16th Street

Victoria Theatre, 16th Street 


Our Campaign Budget
BAM!'s entire season budget is $133,000----which is only because many professional artists, designers, admins, and specialists are donating their talents and services because they believe in what we want to do.  We are asking for $10,000, less than 10% of our total annual budget, in this campaign to get us off the ground and running for our first production.  Here is what that covers:



Your Perks
BAM! isn't just about the artists, our shows, or musical theatre.  It is much, much more.  It's about YOU: the relationships you make with BAM!, your support for BAM!, and how we are able to better serve this beautiful city.  Because of your help with seeing this monumental project come to fruition, BAM! wants to make sure you know how important you are.  You mean A LOT to us.  Take a look for yourself:

 



Bay Area theatre artists Daren A.C. Carollo and Kimberly Dooley speak about supporting BAM! 

Listen to Daren A.C. Carollo (Producing Artistic Director of Berkeley Playhouse) and Kimberly Dooley (Bay Area favorite director & choreographer) talk about why they are involved with BAM! and how your support today, determines our future moving forward.

The Impact 

  With over 250 companies in the Bay Area between the North Bay, South Bay, East Bay, and San Francisco---- WHY START BAM! (Bay Area Musicals)? Here are FIVE POINTS that combined, make BAM! unique. 
1)  Diversity:
We utilize local professionals in non-traditional casting, administration, and
other artistic roles. All of our productions are chosen for a diverse audience
and are selected to appeal to a wide audience inclusive of diversity in age,
gender, race, and sexuality. We are a theater who reflect the world around us. 
2)  Professionalism: We use experienced Equity and non-Equity Actors, and pay all of our artistic staff, designers, and musicians.
3)  Creativity:
We will focus on creating original works for the musical theatre canon.  Integral to our mission is the cultivation of New Works from conception to production with world premieres in San Francisco. 
4)  Variety:
Our season of musical choices will vary in style, mood, setting, and content.
BAM! will be the only musical theatre company whose seasons present popular
classics, modern musicals, and New Works. 
And these New Works will be made possible through BAM!.  
5)  Innovation:
Our musicals will be told through original interpretations, presenting superior
musical theatre pieces in innovative ways that speak to today’s audiences, and
inspires new perspectives. 

Our project affects the entire San Francisco community…  especially YOU! Our project is valuable to our funders.  With this new company alone we will be 1) creating jobs by utilizing the Bay Area's top professionals, 2) provide a safe and inviting environment that induces creativity, 3) present a variety of musicals through innovative eyes, and 4) educate and train the audiences of tomorrow so theater continues to enrich the lives of the San Francisco community.  




The Team








Matthew McCoy, Founder & Artistic Director
To fulfill all of BAM!'s (Bay Area Musicals) objectives, Matthew McCoy, Founder & Artistic Director, has put
together a team of local artists and community leaders – including respected
Bay Area arts professionals, experienced development directors, attorneys, and
entrepreneurs.  Combined, the team has
over 200 years of experience in non-profit arts administration, event-based
marketing and regional, international and Off-Broadway theatre.  The team includes Daren A.C. Carollo (Artistic Advisor/Berkeley Playhouse Producing Artistic Director), Kimberly Dooley (Artistic Advisor/Director&Choreographer), Carnell Freeman (Board Member), Jon Gallo (Secretary/Resident Music Director), Wilson
Hardcastle (Vice President/Development), Michelle Ianiro (New
Works), Kevin Kopjak (Board Member), Kirk Johnson (Marketing & Sales Director), Annette Lai (Volunteer Coordinator),  Matthew McCoy (Founder & Artistic Director), AeJay Mitchell (Managing
Director), , Benjamin Nguyen (Community
Outreach), Jon Tracy (Artistic
Advisor), Aaron Vanderbeek (Webmaster) and Leslie Waggoner (Advertising).




Risks & Challenges
What happens if we don't reach our goal? 
WE KEEP GOING! It will take up to three years to gain and build a devoted base of supporters who will continue seeing BAM! shows.  We might not reach that potential crowd with this fundraising campaign.  The money raised will go towards securing our most prominent needs in the season.  
What qualifies us to overcome this issue?
Our artistic and leading team is made up of the Bay Area's finest.  Each member is a specialist in their own field from marketing & finance to choreography & casting.  We are in great hands with the leaders of tomorrow's theatre.  

  Other Ways You Can Help 1) Can't give now? That's okay! BAM! still loves you and we want you to be a part of our growing future.  Please stay connected for future events, fundraisers, or season announcements by joining our newsletter HERE.
2) Save the date! Our first show, How To Succeed In Business Without Really Trying, will play November 28 -December 19, 2015.  Put that on your calendar NOW to join us.  Come see a show!
3)  It takes a village to put on a show and we can only succeed with your help.  Become part of the BAM! family by sharing this project with your friends and loved ones. Help support BAM! and spread the word.

story:
I'm Sabry Zekry, OVPS Workshop Director and I'm trying to raise $4950...

  • To buy flight tickets for OVPS group members to get to Spain.
  • To run and buy materials for our Persian storytelling workshops in Spain.
  • To cover living expenses for the OVPS team, for 2 weeks whilst running the project.
  • To do documentation of project.

We have been invited by the Nau Côclea Center in the north of Spain to partake in their art residency. During our residency we will teach the art of Oral Visual Persian Storytelling called "Naghali & Pardeh khani" to the Spanish artists through few intensive short term workshops where participants will explore techniques of the Naghali & Pardeh khani. The workshops will culminate in a final show presented by the trainers and the participants.

The aim of the project is to explore eastern narrative-painting and storytelling techniques, to learn about eastern techniques and to revive the dying art of Naghali & Pardeh Khani.

By traveling with the Pardeh Khani to new communities it becomes revitalized, since workshops and live performances recycle the ancient art to serve contemporary communities. This provides a means to express stories that are relevant to a particular place and its people. It can be expected that a Pardeh Khanii event, as a valuable means for direct communication, will serve to strengthen the community identity. 

Naghali: is narrating of a story or an event in verse or prose with special tone, feelings and expression.

A Naghal (storyteller): playing the roles of different characters by himself, usually narrates epics and mythical stories.

The Sofrehkhaneh: is a traditional Tea house where people gather to watch Naghali performances in the past.


Pardeh khani: The story-teller Naghal  sometimes uses the visual aid of a Pardeh Nagashi, (a large canvas painting) that depicts characters and scenes related to the story, rather like a modern action painting.

Our workshops include Persian clown, physical storytelling and how to use basic objects to turn them into props for the storyteller, such as the magical stick! We will also teach how to express the story beyond language, using body and voice, using the physical as not only movement but to convey an image and object also. Become a story teller and interactive face to face with audience!

Location of Project Workshops:

Girona, Barcelona in the north of Spain

Starting Date:

January 25th 2015

Ending Date:

February 8th 2015

We are looking to raise $4950 for this production, firstly to get our 4 members of the team over to Spain, secondly we need to buy art supplies to make the paintings, thirdly we will want to cover basic living expenses, such as food and transportation and finally we must document the workshops and pay Indiegogo fee.

So due to a lack of funding for Persian arts, we are asking for your help.


ARE YOU in Spain and would like to receive some ancient Persian knowledge of theatre and storytelling? Or maybe you know others who would be interested? 

By spreading the word about our project and the Indiegogo campaign you will be helping us tremendously and you will be contributing to exposing this rarely seen, unique art form of Persian storytelling.

We are trying to revive and recycle old rituals, traditions, stories and almost extinct ways of performance. This is not just important to us but for the future generations to come...


So tell everyone about us! 
Here is a teaser of what we have in store for you as gifts for your contribution. In case you did not take cuneiform as a second language (really?) here is how SABRY is written in Persian calligraphy inside in a Stone Pine cone and how Cyrus the great is written in ancient cuneiform alphabet. Wouldn’t it be cool to have your name written in Persian calligraphy or ancient cuneiform alphabet too in a surprising design!!!



He is an Iranian - Egyptian multidisciplinary artist and the founder of Performance Recycling Factory. (PRF) is a platform and manifesto for reviving and recycling rituals and traditions to convert them into theatrical events and collective creations. http://sabryzekry.wix.com/sabry-zekry#!what-is-prf/c13

Sabry's work includes actor's training, physical theatre, play writing, theatre directing and storytelling. He received his Diplomas in Film-making and Conceptual Photography in 2007 and in 2011 he received his B.A. in Theater Directing. The following years, he performed in various Festivals in South Korea, Egypt, Greece, Poland and Iran. In 2013 he received a grant from Al Mawred Al Thaqafy to produce the project based in intercultural encounters between Egyptian and Persian storytelling styles.

http://mawred.org/programs-and-activities/production-awards/latest-projects/once-upon-a-time-yesterday-today-and-tomorrow/

Currently Sabry is teaching the Russian theatre approach called Biomechanics at Cairo Contemporary Dance Centre and at the same time he is teaching a variety of theatre workshops based on visual story-telling, physical theatre and stage combat.


Born in Barcelona, she received her B.A. in Arabic Language and Literature in 2000 and in 2009 she graduated with a diploma in Arts Management. She participated in a long theatre education project for acting, story narrating, clown, circus and mask in Espai de les Arts in Barcelona between 1993 and 2002.

Currently she is working as freelance arts manager wilts continuing her  work in  social theatre in Egypt. 

http://rjuradocastillo.wix.com/rjuradocastillo#!c-work/c1ger


He received his Diploma in acting from the Film-making Youth Institute in 2006 in Tehran. Later, in 2010 he received his B.A. in theater acting from Sooreh University in Iran.

Currently he is studying a Master on Dramatic Literature in Iran while researching about the relation between martial arts and drama.

He  has been performing different kinds of plays since 2006, including classic texts (Macbeth, Prometheus, Agamemnon), modern plays and collective creations in South Korea, Greece and Iran. 


She Is an Iranian poet, novelist, translator and Book publisher. She received her B.A. in English Literature and Translation from Al Zahra University in 1975 and since then she has been writing and editing.

In 2005, she received the permission to open her publishing houseThe night of poem from the Ministry of Culture and Art. Since 2005 she has edited poem, short novels and translated many books for children and adults. 

Nau  Côclea Center for Contemporary Creation was founded in 1996 and is based in Camallera, Catalonia, Spain. They produce and present exhibitions, art and sound art projects, as well as artists training workshops and performances. They also have a creator’s residence program. Open to ideas, desires and projects...

http://naucoclea.net/?lang=es

https://www.facebook.com/NauCoclea

We would like to thank them for supporting us:

us:

story:
Short Summary

The Elektro Botz concept series is a collection of concept driven dance videos that will be unlike anything you've ever seen before. We are aiming for a ten video series all focused on completely different ideas. Each video in the series has a completely different feeling and story and will transport the audience into a different state of mind. We are looking for funding to bring the full vision to our audience the way we imagined it. With this project we will be creating ten completely different universes with their own stories and feelings being expressed through a new unique style of dance. 
What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise 10,000 dollars to make this dream of ours come true. Funding is needed to acquire all of the necessary equipment and locations to bring this project to life. We are creating ten completely unique very dense realities and to do so the locations as well as the equipment( Camera equipment, Lighting, Special effects etc.) have to be up to the industry standard. 

We wil be making a wide variety of perks for potential contributors, such as Elektro Botz merchandise, private Behind the scenes video packages, Film posters, and actual props from the set. 

All funding will be pumped directly into this project to support every aspect of production. We intend on meeting our goal and believe that this project deserves the goal funding so that all ideas may be fully explored and we may deliver a finished product unlike anything else. If our goal is not met we will continue to produce this project to the best of our ability. 

The Impact

This project is extremely valuable to the dance and film community. The combination of these two art forms is unparalleled to anything else thats been made today. 

The Elektro Botz Dance crew has previously produced a few short dance films on little to no budget and they have both done extremely well. They have gained a lot of positive acknowledgment in regards to both the dancing and the quality of the filmmaking. We created these projects with few lights, little to no budget or equipment, and backyard locations. This gives us great confidence that with the right support and funding we can create something truly amazing. 

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

There are a few risks associated with the creation of this project such as, getting the rights to certain locations and being able to pay our cast and crew. These problems can both be fixed with your donation. We have the experience and ingenuity to work around any problems that may arise. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Any sort of donation you could make would definitely help us achieve our goal and we appreciate it greatly. If you can't make a donation just sharing or telling a friend, getting the word out about this project in any way shape or form would get us one step closer to accomplishing our dream. 

Thank you for your time.
