story:
Short Summary

NOISE is a new play written by myself, Thomas Moran. It discusses topics in the LGBTQ community and emphasises the importance for communication and connection. I am working with an incredible creative team of young actors and theatre-makers in bringing my production and ideas to the stage. At 19, I have forever been driven in being creative and making my ideas happen. In 2010, I secured funding from O2 to write, direct, film and edit my own short film which immediately gave me the desire to want to continue creating these experiences and opportunities for not only myself, but for other young talented individuals. 

NOISE follows the story of two young boys who, in the midst of the madness of first year at university, begin a relationship that reignites fragments of Evan's life. NOISE is the heart­-warming story of love, loss and togetherness.

Your help will allow us to make this project a reality and onto a stage - and that alone would deserve a standing ovation!

What We Need & What You Get

  • As for the production, the funding will go directly towards the process ranging from: rehearsal spaces, equipment, set design to travel expenses. 
  • The perks are oh so exclusive: an invite to a rehearsal, tickets to a preview, special behind-the-scenes videos and images and many more.
  • With your input, regardless of whether we reach our target, the money will be put directly into the production.

The Impact

We cannot stress quite enough just how much even the smallest of contributions will do to help us. Having ideas and the crave to entertain people comes at a cost. You will be giving a small group of actors the chance to be in a stage production created and performed by young individuals and allowing our ideas to come to life. With your help, we will be able to showcase the hidden talent that young people have to offer.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot donate, you can help us in a further two ways:

  1. Make some NOISE and get the word out about our project!
  2. Share, share and share again.

That is all for now.

A jazz-hands goodbye and we hope to see you soon!

story:
About the Show

In a time when men played all the roles in the theatre, two boy players fight it out to land the role of Lady Macbeth in Shakespeare's upcoming new play. Witty, campy, poetic, and profane, UNSEX’d is a satirically biting comedy that questions fame, gender, and the truth about beauty.

Written by playwrights Daniel Judes and Jay Whitehead, this production marks the first time U.S. audiences will have an opportunity to see the play. Its run of sold out performances in Canada and the UK includes the Dublin Gay Theatre Festival, where it won the best actor award and was nominated for the Oscar Wilde Award for Playwriting.

Our Goals

Our goal is to create a high quality production while compensating our artists for their talent and dedication.

What We Need And What You Get

We need your support to take this show to Fringe. 100% of proceeds from our campaign will go toward funding the production. Your donation will be put to good use buying props, renting rehearsal space, advertising, and most importantly, paying our artists.

With your donation, you not only receive the token(s) of appreciation listed at your funding level, but also personal ownership in the show and the gratification of knowing your contribution is making a real difference.

The Impact

Behind the campy and raucous dialogue, UNSEX’d is an opportunity to explore gender stereotypes and challenge society’s preoccupation with gender roles. Our production at Fringe will provide audiences a chance to engage with these important topics and experience a never-before-seen story.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our campaign on social media and help us spread the word! We can always use the extra publicity. And, of course, come see the show!

story:
WHAT IS IT?  Using the structure of the book 'Where The Wild Things Are' by Maurice Sendak, gathering it's content from extracts of my 1989/1990 diary and initially set amongst the corresponding world events of those two years RUMPUS begins as a distress signal. An SOS. A letter from my 12/13 year old self addressed to my 'adult' self asking: "Who do I go to when the joke has gone too far – WHO is going to say STOP?" The second half of the show reveals my current and long awaited reply.
    Through a combination of live performance, animation, soundscape, lip syncing and bad dance moves audiences are taken on a wild but charasmatic tour through the wormholes of time and space. Together we examine distinct correlations between the local school yard and the global political arena in order to begin asking how the experience of play turned violent can so easily be created, in what ways are we complicit within the nature of that game and how do we now enter into a 'grown up' conversation about the potential health and sustainability of not only our own future local and global relationships but also those of the adults and children to come?

    WHO ARE YOU?  My name is Ahmarnya Price. I am a visual artist and performance maker living and working in Melbourne. Australia. I draw, paint, animate, write, direct and perform. Since 1999 I have exhibited work throughout Australia, Europe and Asia. In 2002 I was awarded a 'Noma Concours (Unesco) Prize for Picture Book Illustration'. The exhibition Just Me and Yoko Ono won a Melbourne Fringe Festival Award for Best Exhibition 2008. During 2009 I established the interdisciplinary performance ensemble The Chaotic Order at Footscray Community Arts Centre (FCAC). Our show The Waiting Place won 'Best Original Australian Work' at the 2011 Melbourne Fringe Festival. In 2012 I completed postgraduate studies in Performance Creation at the Victorian College of The Arts and was granted the Grace Marion Wilson Trust Scholarship. During this time of research the initial stages of my project RUMPUS begun. In 2013 Footscray Community Arts Centre invited me to take part in a three year Artist Residency to develop the work. That invitation was also extended by Metro Arts in Brisbane as part of their Takeover Program. The following year, 2014, I received the Victorian College of The Arts Professional Pathways Scholarship to extend my research both at FCAC and Battersea Arts Centre (BAC) in the UK. RUMPUS will debut it's first season in March 2016 at FCAC as part of The Festival Of Live Art before returning to BAC and Metro Arts in 2016/2017. Additional and ongoing working relationships include Back to Back Theatre, Rawcus, St Martin's Youth Theatre, Leisa Shelton and Christine Johnston.


    WHAT IS NEEDED - Where the money goes:
    All up I need to gather $9812. I have already invested $6000 of my own money into this stage of RUMPUS and now aiming to raise $3812 through this fundraiser. The funds will go towards the following: 

    - Fees for Artists working on the show: $1400
    - Set/ Materials/ Props/ Costume: $1440
    - Equipment Hire (Lighting, Sound/ Audio Visual): $972

    If the entire goal isn't reached the funds raised will be still be allocated into the areas above.

    WHAT YOU GET - THE PERKS: As mentioned in the video above - for every $10 $50 $80 $150 $500 $1000 + you will receive an original artwork hand made by me. (See 'PERKS' section for more details). Every one a unique piece. This could involve an idea you already have or we can come up with one together but essentially you are commissioning me to create a piece personally for you. Please see below for the complete details and also check out my website/blog if you need to see more examples of my work: ahmarnyaprice.blogspot.com.au

    WHAT AGAIN - THE IMPACT 
    Your contribution will help achieve the following:
    Supporting new narratives as well as the development and sustainability of independent artists: I consider my role as an artist to be one of service and crucial in it's contribution to the wider community. Art has the capacity to create spaces where we can reflect on, critique, offer, create and re-create stories that are capable of containing the complexities of who we are and the diverse ways in which we live. We are constantly in need of new stories to encompass who we are becoming. RUMPUS was born from this conviction. More specifically, I regard the Australian viewpoint as an original one: we are an upside down, topsy-turvy paradox. Young but complex. Ancient yet bursting with vitality. Our story and our reality is unique but it also remains universal and has much to contribute to the larger world narrative. I would like the work I create (both myself and with others) to be a useful and effective part of that contribution and believe that through the eventual touring vehicle that is RUMPUS, with it's specific idiosyncratic themes and provocations, I can begin to achieve this.
    Supporting the skills and professional development of my practice: The impact of RUMPUS's debut season, at the Festival Of Live Art, on the sustainability of my practice/career is that it will add to the experience of presenting work in a professional context with various audiences. Consequently this will raise my profile through connecting with other artists, potential producers and international delegates invited to the festival. Additionally the activity will also be an opportunity for my own skills development as a writer and a performer as well as directing a team of collaborators to work with sound, lighting, set building and projection.
    Support the development of national and international collaborations:   In 2013 RUMPUS was invited to develop the work at Metro Arts in Brisbane as part of its Takeover Residency. Likewise in late 2014, as a result of a Producer/ Artist exchange between FCAC and Battersea Arts Centre in the UK I presented the work as part of a 'scratch' showing to relevant producers. Consequently I am in conversation with both organisations to find possible contexts for RUMPUS to return and present a season. With it's particular but universal themes and investigations I consider RUMPUS to be an effective and exciting platform for developing both local and global creative partnerships.
    Supporting community engagement with the work: In the development of this performance I am currently working with a handful of young artists from St Martins Youth Theatre as well as ensemble members from The Chaotic Order/ FCAC to create content for the show as both artists and test audiences. In this way they are and will continue to be both highly valued observers and contributors in their engagement with the work.


    WHERE TO FROM HERE AND HOW?
    Rehearsals at Footscray Community Arts Centre in February/March 2016:
    - one week/ in kind support from FCAC for venue hire/ some tech and equipment/ working with team of creatives to refine and rehearse
    Debut the first season of Rumpus at Footscray Community Arts Centre as part of The Festival of Live Art in 2016:
    - two week season – 7 shows/ in kind support from FCAC for venue hire, administration, marketing, some tech and equipment/ working with team of creatives.
    Return to Metro Arts, Brisbane and Battersea Arts Centre, UK between 2016 - 2018 with a season of the finished work:
    - two week season – 10 days 10 shows/ in kind support from Metro Arts/BAC for venue hire, administration, marketing, tech and equipment.
    Find a Producer/ Festivals/ Organisations post FCAC Residency (March 2016) to tour RUMPUS. Eg:
    - Various Arts organisations and Arts Markets.

    HOW - OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:  Even if you can't contribute financially that doesn't mean you can't help. Getting the word out and sharing this campaign amongst your social and professional networks would be such fabulous support.
    And then there's the actual show – come along! You can book tickets through Footscray Community Arts Centre here: footscrayarts.com.   Or through the Festival Of Live Art site (coming soon). 
    THANK YOU.
    And now....LET THE WILD RUMPUS START!!!!!!

	Order at Footscray Community Arts Centre (FCAC). Our show The
	Waiting Place won 'Best Original Australian Work' at the 2011
	Melbourne Fringe Festival. In 2012 I completed postgraduate studies
	in Performance Creation at the Victorian College of The Arts and was
	granted the Grace Marion Wilson Trust Scholarship. During this time
	of research the initial stages of my project RUMPUS begun. In 2013
	Footscray Community Arts Centre invited me to take part in a three
	year Artist Residency to develop the work. That invitation was also
	extended by Metro Arts in Brisbane as part of
	their Takeover Program. The following year, 2014, I received the
	Victorian College of The Arts Professional Pathways Scholarship to
	extend my research both at FCAC and Battersea Arts Centre (BAC) in
	the UK. RUMPUS will debut it's first season in March 2016 at FCAC as
	part of The Festival Of Live Art before returning to BAC and Metro
	Arts in 2016/2017.  Additional and ongoing working relationships
	include Back to Back Theatre, Rawcus, St Martin's Youth Theatre,
	Leisa Shelton and Christine Johnston.WHAT IS NEEDED - Where the money goes:All up I need to gather $9812. I have already invested $6000 of my own money into this stage of RUMPUS and now aiming to raise $3812 through this fundraiser. The funds will go towards the following: 
-
	Fees for Artists working on the show: 
	$1400-
	Set/ Materials/ Props/ Costume: $1440-
	Equipment Hire (Lighting, Sound/ Audio Visual): $972


If
 the entire goal isn't reached the funds raised will be still be
allocated into the areas above.


WHAT
	YOU GET - THE PERKS: As
	mentioned in the video above - for every $10 $50 $80 $150 $500 $1000
	+  you will receive an original artwork hand made by me. (See 'PERKS' section for more details). Every one
	a unique piece.   This could involve an idea you already have or we
	can come up with one together but essentially you are commissioning
	me to create a piece personally for you.  Please see below for the
	complete details and also check out my website/blog if you need to
	see more examples of my work: ahmarnyaprice.blogspot.com.au



WHAT
	 AGAIN - THE IMPACT Your
	contribution will help achieve the following:


Supporting
new narratives as well as the development and sustainability of independent artists:                                                      
                                                                     
                       I
consider my role as an artist to be one of service and crucial
in it's contribution to the wider community. Art has the capacity to
create spaces where we can reflect on, critique, offer, create and
re-create stories that are capable of containing the complexities of
who we are and the diverse ways in which we live. We are constantly
in need of new stories to encompass who we are becoming. RUMPUS was
born from this conviction. More specifically, I regard the Australian
viewpoint as an original one: we are an upside down, topsy-turvy
paradox. Young but complex. Ancient yet bursting with vitality. Our
story and our reality is unique but it also remains universal and has
much to contribute to the larger world narrative. I would like the work I create (both myself and with others) to be a useful and effective part of that contribution and believe that
through the eventual touring vehicle that is RUMPUS, with it's
specific idiosyncratic themes and provocations, I can begin to
achieve this.


Supporting the skills and professional development of my practice: The
impact of RUMPUS's debut season, at the Festival Of Live Art, on the
sustainability of my practice/career is that it will add to the
experience of presenting work in a professional context with various
audiences. Consequently this will raise my profile through connecting
with other artists, potential producers and international delegates
invited to the festival. Additionally the activity will also be an
opportunity for my own skills development as a writer and a performer
as well as directing a team of collaborators to work with sound,
lighting, set building and projection.


Support
the development of national and international collaborations:   In
2013 RUMPUS was invited to develop the work at Metro Arts in Brisbane
as part of its Takeover Residency. Likewise in late 2014, as
a result of a Producer/ Artist exchange between FCAC and Battersea
Arts Centre in the UK I presented the work as part of a 'scratch'
showing to relevant producers. Consequently I am in conversation with
both organisations to find possible contexts for RUMPUS to return and
present a season. With it's particular but universal themes and
investigations I consider RUMPUS to be an effective and exciting
platform for developing both local and global creative partnerships.


Supporting
community engagement with the work: In
the development of this performance I am currently working with a
handful of young artists from St Martins Youth Theatre as well as
ensemble members from The Chaotic Order/ FCAC to create content for
the show as both artists and test audiences. In this way they are and
will continue to be both highly valued observers and contributors in
their engagement with the work.


WHERE
TO FROM HERE AND HOW?


Rehearsals at Footscray Community Arts Centre in February/March 2016:-
one week/ in kind support from FCAC for venue hire/ some tech and
equipment/ working with team of creatives to refine and rehearse


Debut
the first season of Rumpus at Footscray Community Arts Centre as part
of The Festival of Live Art in 2016:-
two week season – 7 shows/ in kind support from FCAC for venue
hire, administration, marketing, some tech and equipment/ working with
team of creatives.


Return
to Metro Arts, Brisbane and Battersea Arts Centre, UK between 2016 -
2018 with a season of the finished work:-
two week season – 10 days 10 shows/ in kind support from Metro
Arts/BAC for venue hire, administration, marketing, tech and
equipment.


Find
a Producer/ Festivals/ Organisations post FCAC Residency (March 2016)
to tour RUMPUS. Eg:- Various
	Arts organisations and Arts Markets.HOW - OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:  Even
if you can't contribute financially that doesn't mean you can't help.
 Getting the word out and sharing this campaign amongst your social and
professional networks would be such fabulous support.And
then there's the actual show – come along!  You can book tickets
through Footscray Community Arts Centre here: footscrayarts.com.   Or through the
Festival Of Live Art site (coming soon). 

THANK YOU.


And now....LET THE WILD RUMPUS START!!!!!!

story:
Young Ballet Dancers

Deniz Akarslan ve Berkay Günay, two Turkish young ballet dancers at ages 16 and 17. They are both students at Istanbul University State Conservatory Opera-Ballet. They have just recently won first and second place prizes in Grand Prix Ballet Competition that was held in US. Deniz won 1st place in classical and Berkay won 2nd place in modern dance categories. 

We wanted to raise our voices for these guys as Turkish society living in the US. We know how hard it is to come to states and achieve our goals. 

Our campaign is to raise money for these two young ballet dancers to come to New York City and compete in the finals. So we decided that through Indiegogo, we can help the star dancers of our future come and compete for the final round. 

The contributors will help make these young students achieve their dreams. 

Deniz and Berkay are very successful young dancers and they do not want their dreams to fly away just because there is no budget from their school to send 2 kids to NYC. They are very determined to come and compete for the finals and it is their only chance to prove themselves in their career. 

Funding

We are helping out 2 dancers and 1 coach. Total of 3 people will b coming and staying throughout the competition. All the funding will be given to the dancers and their coach.

. Visa application fees

. Transportation and Room 

. Pocket money for their entire stay in the city 

. Rental studio space to practice throughout the competition. 

2 ballet students and their educator have to be in NY on April 10th, 2015. They are staying for 8 days and will depart back to Turkey on April 18th, 2015. 

Unfortunately it is a very short period of time but weather we raise the total funding or not they will receive everything from this fundraiser until the given date. 

Resume of Deniz

Personal Information

Date of Birth:  16.09.1998

Place of Birth: Istanbul     

Education

  • Istanbul University State Conservatory Ballet  Department  2012-….
  • Mimar Sinan State Conservatory Ballet Deparment  2009-2012

Performances

Don Quixote     matadors       2010

Le Corsaire Corps De Ballet       2011

Fairy Doll     pas de deux    2012

Nutcracker  pas de trois    2012

Coppelia Suite     Coppelius      2012

İnvitation to the Dance /Murat Kurtulmuş    2012

Harlequinade     male variation       2013

Nutcracker  Prince      2013

Bir Tutku Vivaldi /Mercan Selçuk(contemporary)

İkili/Oral Yazıcı    2013

Harlequinade    grand pas de deux    2014

Character Dances /Zehra Tarım Özbal     2014

     

Special Performance 

Young Talent Performer     Istanbul Ballet Contest Finals    2012 

 

Workshops

Istanbul Dance Platform (Vladimir Malakhov, Slava Samadrov)    2010

Varna Ballet Contest Summer School (Aurora Bach, Gilbert Mayer)    2012


Resume of Berkay


My initial interest in the art of ballet started due to my father and mother working in Antalya State Opera and Ballet.
 
My father is a master stage hands and my mother is a costumer at the State Opera and Ballet in Turkey. When I was 5 years old I’ve decided to be a ballet dancer as soon as I saw the performances of ballet dancers and felt their excitement and joy while dancing on stage.
 
I succeeded in the State Opera and Ballet’s children ballet audition and therefore I joined the company. My education in children’s ballet company took about 5 years and during that time I studied at the State Conservatory Ballet Department of Antalya Mediterranean University in part-time schooling. Then my mentor Mehmet Balkan, the chief choreographer of Directorate General of Turkish State Opera and Ballet, suggested that I should apply to the audition to receive education at Istanbul University State Conservatory Ballet Department for improving my ballet skills. I applied to the audition in June 2010 and I passed it successfully. So I have been eligible to attend Istanbul University State Conservatory Ballet Department and still resuming my ballet education there. All through my student years I took on some roles in various ballet and opera productions as part of children’s ballet company.
 
Currently my biggest dream is to be a successful ballet dancer completing my dance education in prominent and well-known ballet schools and represent the beautiful aesthetics of the Art of Ballet to various audiences taking my part in the renowned ballet companies.

story:
We raised $8,154.......but we refunded it since the goal was $12,986....but NOW we have an "angel" who has given us a matching grant...if we can RE-raise the $8K then we MAKE THE GOAL!

Oakland is one of the few metropolitan areas not to have a theatre company.   Piedmont Avenue is a great site to have a theatre and we found just the place: 4137 Piedmont Avenue (next to the Yogurt Shop, across from Barney's)         We plan to raise enough money to build a real theatre there...but first we need to produce the next play!

PHOTOS, POSTERS, REVIEW below:

Our First Production!   "The Dining Room” by A. R. Gurney, Piedmont Center for the Arts, Piedmont  November 21  – December 7 , 2013

“[The Dining Room] is more than a baby step – it’s a full-fledged accomplishment. Deft orchestrator, the Rep’s artistic director, John McMullen, who has chosen perhaps the perfect play for his company’ debut in town.” --Robert C. Hall, Piedmont Post

"When I saw their riotous and high-spirited production of "The Dining Room" by A.R.Gurney last holiday season, I thought here is a neighborhood theatre company whose work I do not want to miss. “The Piedmont-Oakland Rep is thoroughly professional, under the direction of John McMullen, whose imagination and energy never falter, and who promises, with "Other People's Money" by Jerry Sterner, to give us an entertainment both witty and timely."--Jeremy Larner, Screenwriter,  Academy Award winner  for Original Screenplay in 1973 for "The Candidate" which starred Robert Redford.

------------------------------------

---------------------------------------------------------------------

Our Second Production!“   Other People’s Money” by Jerry Sterner,            Kehillah Synagogue, 1300 Grand Ave.  March 8 – April 12, 2014

“Come for the greed and sex, stay for the doughnuts. [‘Other People’s Money’] features exquisite power plays and the compelling-yet-repelling  (John Hale as) Garfield, whose cunning, self-deprecation, dancey rejoinders, and fetish for doughnuts make him…highly watchable.”

–Anna Pulley , East Bay Express

“… an enormously entertaining ride—a not-so-fictional history lesson that rockets viewers right into the present. ‘Other People’s Money’ is a sobering reminder of how we got here. Piedmont Oakland Rep has done a great job bringing it to life.”

---Barry Willis, president, Critics Circle in Piedmont Post

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Our Third Production   “What I Did Last Summer by A. R. Gurney, 4137 Piedmont Avenue November 1 - December 13, 2014

 “Alison Whismore as the distraught mother is a joy to watch…. [Director John] McMullen keeps the action moving at a good clip….Add in two teen pals  and a bit of sexual tension… you have a coming-of-age drama with plenty of grit.” – Sally Hogarty, Contra Costa Times & Inside Bay Area News

“…a neat ensemble for the often quick scenes with sharp dialogue.  It's a fine Fall entertainment—and hopefully PORT has a long run of its own on Piedmont Avenue.”  --Ken Bullock, Berkeley Daily Planet

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We also did three Stage Readings and some of them sold out!

“Speed-the-Plow” by David Mamet, 4137 Piedmont Ave., June 29-30, 2014


“In the Next Room: The Vibrator Play” bySarahRuhl, 4137 Piedmont Ave. September 6-21, 2014 


“Love Letters” by A. R. Gurney, 4137 Piedmont Ave., September 21-22 2014


\

“Love Letters” by A. R. Gurney, 4137 Piedmont Ave., September 21-22 2014

story:
Short Summary

My friends,

In the last year some exciting things have been occurring in my life. First of all, our fundraising effort for EQUUS was achieved - raising $4,610! The production was a rousing success and we received incredible reviews including features in Broadway World, Houston Press and CultureMap Houston. Since last Summer, I've directed the main-stage production, Evita, for the Houston Family Arts Center with an equally talented cast. It has truly been wonderful to bring theatre to a diverse community as Houston.

I would like to continue to bring meaningful work to our city by staging Tony Kushner's Pulitzer Prize winning play, ANGELS IN AMERICA. Any time I'm seized by a work of art, it haunts me. I dream about it. It challenges me to explore its meanings. ANGELS IN AMERICA has captivated me since I was a freshman in college. It follows several people. Prior Walter is a man whose life is torn apart when he is diagnosed with AIDS. Roy Cohn is in danger of losing his high-powered life due to an illness. Joe and Harper Pitt are fighting to keep their marriage intact as its threatened by secrets, lies and Valium. Louis Ironson is running in fear that the consequences of his actions will catch up to him. Enter the Angel, a beautiful, terrifying and powerful being who is in need of a human prophet. All of these stories intersect in the high stakes world of 1985.

ANGELS IN AMERICA explores humanity and the triumph of fighting for every breath we take. I am truly inspired by the production. I know that it will add to the rich culture of Houston Theatre... the theatre of the future.

I grew up in a church where visions and prophecies happened often. Spirituality is such an important part of my work as an artist. I am constantly exploring issues related to spirituality and its duality. What is the realm of the spiritual - that place between life and death? It is a question that is explored in all art. The unknowable question. Theatre has its origins in religious celebration. I want to capture the ritual power of the theatre in this production. As we explore the humanity of these characters and experience a few bells and whistles, I hope that this production is transformative to you, the audience member. I believe that the arts are often prophetic. They encourage humanity to move forward and grow, or to warn of doom due to injustice. In ANGELS IN AMERICA, Tony Kushner was the prophet for the gay community during the plague of the 1980s. It is important to bring this play to Houston with our exciting production of Angels in America Parts 1 and 2.

I appreciate that the play examines a multi-faceted view on spirituality. Some of the characters are deeply spiritual, and all are deeply human. Some of the most compassionate people in the play are those who are often demonized in the media.  I believe this play can cause meaningful dialogue between the gay, Mormon and Christian communities which could move society forward.

To tell a story as profound as "Angels", we need amazing actors. For doing great work, I am a strong believer in paying performers. The funds I am asking for will go directly to their salaries and rental of a quality venue. Most will go directly to the pockets of the brave performers who choose to work in a field that often pays nothing. I want to do great theatre that contributes to the actors.

We have proven before that we can create great theatre with little funding. Please help us pay the artists and make their dreams a reality. 

Thank you for your time and support.

Matthew C. Logan


What We Need & What You Get

The Breakdown:

  • Goal = $8,000
  • $4,000 pays for facility rentals.  
  • $4,000 pays for actor stipends.
  • Donors get "first picks" on seating.
  • VIP talkbacks with the cast and crew.
  • Producer credits.
  • If we do not reach our entire goal... (we will) then, all funds raised will go towards the facility and the actors.

Risks & Challenges

1. This production deals with mature themes.  We want to be able to explore the themes in a tasteful way without compromising the Pulitzer Prize winning material. 

2.  The production has some nudity. It will be handled tastefully, but some Houston audience members may be offended. To tackle this, we will be upfront in all of the advertising. We will also address any questions the audience members may have at the box office or in our FAQ section.

3. Finding multi-disciplinary actors. Because of the talent required for this production, we need exceptional actors (hence this campaign). Each actor plays several roles so they must be flexible.  We also want actors that are great movers and/or can sing or play an instrument as well.  Auditions are underway and we have seen some incredible talent. These actors are in high demand so if they accept contracts for other shows, the concept will be adjusted and new actors will be found.

4. Box office and other volunteer positions. We will need to find help to man the box office, concessions and help in set construction.  Since we are operating on a shoestring budget, we are going to need volunteers to help maintain operations. 

5. Production Values. We have to be able to fly! We are not looking at a facility with a fly system, but we are planning on using aerial silk or other acrobatic skills to tell this story. Pictures coming soon!


Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can donate funds, but there are still ways you can be a part of all the action!

EARN 2 FREE TICKETS!

  • Invite your friends via Facebook to RSVP on our event page AND
  • Share approved content about the upcoming show OR
  • Volunteer your time or services to the production
    (and get your name in the show's program, too.)
  • Contact us here for more details. Limited number of free tickets available.
  • And, of course, share this Indiegogo campaign with others!

$4,000 pays for actor stipends. Donors get "first picks" on seating.
VIP talkbacks with the cast and crew.
Producer credits. If we do not reach our entire goal... (we will) then, all funds raised will go towards the facility and the actors.


    Risks & Challenges  
1. This production deals with mature themes.  We want to be able to explore the themes in a tasteful way without compromising the Pulitzer Prize winning material. 2.  The production has some nudity. It will be handled tastefully, but some Houston audience members may be offended. To tackle this, we will be upfront in all of the advertising. We will also address any questions the audience members may have at the box office or in our FAQ section.3. Finding multi-disciplinary actors. Because of the talent required for this production, we need exceptional actors (hence this campaign). Each actor plays several roles so they must be flexible.  We also want actors that are great movers and/or can sing or play an instrument as well.  Auditions are underway and we have seen some incredible talent. These actors are in high demand so if they accept contracts for other shows, the concept will be adjusted and new actors will be found.4. Box office and other volunteer positions. We will need to find help to man the box office, concessions and help in set construction.  Since we are operating on a shoestring budget, we are going to need volunteers to help maintain operations. 5. Production Values. We have to be able to fly! We are not looking at a facility with a fly system, but we are planning on using aerial silk or other acrobatic skills to tell this story. Pictures coming soon!
Other Ways You Can Help We know that not everyone can donate funds, but there are still ways you can be a part of all the action!
EARN 2 FREE TICKETS!


Invite your friends via Facebook to RSVP on our event page AND

Share approved content about the upcoming show OR

Volunteer your time or services to the production(and get your name in the show's program, too.)
Contact us here for more details. Limited number of free tickets available.

 And, of course, share this Indiegogo campaign with others!

story:
You awake to find yourself sitting at a table inside a cube, your friends are gone and you are faced with the question, “how do you build a reality which doesn't collapse within three days?”

This VR experience seeks to introduce audiences to the story of one of history's strangest mass disappearances based on the evidence of eight letters left behind by the disappeared.

Made as a collaboration between Simon Wilkinson [circa69] Scott McPherson [Amoeba Design] and Jilt Van Moorst [Amsterdam Film Academy/Robot Funk], this 15 minute first person performance incorporates 360 degree vision, head tracking, hand tracking and a clever manipulation of the kinesthetic senses to create full multi-sensory and narrative immersion.

In addition the show incorporates a substantial transmedia universe designed to keep audiences engaged and interacting with the piece for days after the show is over.

We received Arts Council funding to create an R&D version of this show with additional support from Cambridge Junction and LDD Research Group. The R&D version is currently being tested in Cambridge, Bristol and Brighton so that from July we can go into pre-production for the completion of the work in time for a performance at Digital Festival Brighton in September and a UK / international tour.

Have a look at our Perks and Goodies


We are looking to raise £1500 in order to match fund other sources of cash for the completion of the work.

story:
Dance is for everyone!

Can you imagine being trapped in a body that no longer responds to your every wish and desire? Can you imagine not being able to move freely and express yourself easily?

This is what happens to people afflicted with Parkinson's. Slowly, they lose the ability to control their arms and legs, their balance deteriorates, speech becomes difficult and eventually they may be unable to move or speak at all.

There is no cure for Parkinson's. Right now the drug treatments are limited and the main goal in treating the disease is to slow its progression down.

This where the Dance for Parkinson's Class comes in!!

Dance for Parkinson's Class

We are creating a class based on the "Dance for PD" model started by the Mark Morris Company in New York. For over 15 years, they have been refining their program and now offer training for dance instructors all over the country. The "Dance for PD" classes emphasize self expression and joyful living through dance.

They have seen people slow down the progression of their Parkinson's and in some cases the dance classes have improved the participant's overall quality of life.

Light Energy Dancing

 Light Energy Dancing is a unique wellness center in Fort Walton Beach, FL. We specialize in dance, yoga & meditation. One of our mail goals is to provide dance for people with various limitations....people that want to experience the joy of dance, but a traditional crowded, high energy environment is too overwhelming or intimidating for them. We have a quiet, light filled, beautiful studio that is the perfect learning environment for those who need a little more attention and need to take a little more time to accomplish their goals.

Keeping in mind our goal of bringing dance to everyone...At  Light Energy Dancing, we want to offer a Dance for Parkinson's Class  once week that is FREE to the participants and their caregivers!

People with Parkinson's are eventually no longer able to work and the finacial strain for their medications and therapy tends to become overwhelming. We want to be able to keep their burden at a minimum so it is really imporant we secure funding so they can participate free of charge.


The Plan!!

As you know however, nothing is actually free and we need to cover the cost of the instructor, advertising and rent. We need to raise at least $2,000 to cover the first four months of our pilot program.

We hope to grow and eventually offer the class twice a week. Any donation you can make will go a long way towards providing dance for people with Parkinson's in the Fort Walton Beach, Navarre, Destin area. If all goes as planned, we will eventually become an advocate for this program in Ballroom Studios all across the country. It is our long term goal to see every studio offer Dance for Parkinson's classes.

story:
From the darkest depths of city slums,
Something sketchy this way comes.
Performers from both wide and deep,
Will poke some fun at all the sheep.
The taboo we’ll poke, to make the joke.
When something sketchy this way comes.

Something Sketchy This Way Comes
... is Coming!

With a strong history of original entertainers and comedians that have sprung forth from the banks of the Mighty Mississippi, St. Louis is once more playing host to a unique experiment that aims to bring recognition to the amazing host of comedic talent who call the city their home.

On Saturday, August 1, 2015, a sketch comedy showcase like nothing St. Louis has ever seen before is set to debut at the storied Off Broadway Music Club. Diving into uncharted waters, the show will take comedic performers from across the metro area and randomly assign them to a new sketch comedy group, and each group will have three weeks to write, rehearse and produce three brand new sketches.

Six teams will be performing at the event, with each team consisting of seven performers. The performers will be randomly assigned to their groups after a week-long sign up period beginning on July 1. The team that gets the biggest reaction from the judges- the audience- will win a cash prize. Interspersed between teams, four local stand-up comedians will keep the show moving at a brisk pace.

Though many performers will undoubtedly have backgrounds in improvisation, this is not an improv show. Each sketch will be written and rehearsed by the participating performers. Think of shows such as Saturday Night Live, Mr. Show with Bob and David, The State and Kids In The Hall and then throw them all into a blender. The end result will be a mixture of sketch comedy genres and styles that will be daring, unexpected and- most important- funny.

Producing the show are two veterans of the St. Louis sketch comedy scene, Tyson Blanquart and Drew Somervell, who directed, performed with and wrote for such groups as The NonProphet Theater Company, The Zim Zam Kök Show and The Finger Breaker Brothers. Their new collaboration, BS Productions, hope to make this an annual event, and it all starts here.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise money to help cover the production costs of the show. We don't need much, but the more we raise, the better the production will be. The money will be used, in part, to cover:

  • Filming and video production
  • Set rental/construction
  • Payment to the venue and special performers.
The show is happening regardless if we reach our goal or not. If we do not reach the goal, we will still use whatever is contributed toward the production.

The Impact

The potential impact of this show would be revitalization of the St. Louis Comedy scene. There are events happening here and there throughout the city, but part of our goal is to bring all those factions together for one night of unique comedy and to help foster a city-wide network of comedic performers and writers.

The two people spearheading this endeavor have a track record of producing quality shows with little to no budget. As part of The NonProphet Theater Company's production staff, cast and writing staff, Blanquart and Somervell contributed to the legacy of the group, and helped establish a silver age of sketch comedy in STL throughout the 2000s.

Risks & Challenges

The risks are almost non-existent. The suggested individual donations we're asking for are small- almost pocket change. For a few dollars, you can help make this show even better than we already feel it will be. The challenges are small, as well, but exist. We would like to offer a professional, polished show, both to the live audience as well as to those who view the show via digital download.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, we encourage you to spread the word about the show and about our campaign to raise my for it. Please feel free to forward the link to this campaign to anyone you feel may be interested in participating or contributing.

We thank you in advance for any help you can offer, and we hope to see you at Off Broadway on Saturday, August 1, 2015.

story:
Here's Our Hope:

My name is Bobby Wise and I am here to raise money for one of my best friends & future leader in the arts, Lydia Nightingale. Her original play titled "Adele in Berlin" has officially been accepted into The Riant Theatre's Strawberry One-Act Festival held in New York City during the month of August! As this is her dream come true, it was AMAZING news for both her and the rest of us that found out ^_^
BUT then the reality of the situation kicked in...
You see, even though her play is in the festival, there is still: a registration fee, travel expenses round trip from Albany, food, costuming & general supplies that just ADD UP SO FAST! Not to also mention that she is 25 years old, has a costly BA from SUNY New Paltz in Theatre to pay for, and just like all of the rest of us in this Generation, has zero money after all of the bills are paid... Therefore, she doesn't think that she will be able to afford doing this, even though it's only a couple hundred dollars.
But that's 'Merica for ya!  The land FULL of opportunities, that only people with money are able to take advantage of...
SO, that is why I am asking for your support in raising this EXTREMELY small amount of money to prove that this world is still full of the magic that's seen when dreams come true. 
SHE IS A BEAUTIFUL WRITER WITH A NICHE IN CREATING WORKS THAT EXPOSE HISTORICAL CONTROVERSY & SHED LIGHT ON BOTH SIDES OF CONFLICT (In other words, it's super worthwhile because her work is stuff you don't ever really hear about, but events in history that you should've always been aware of.) 

Lydia's Expenses:

Participation Fee: $300 (PAID DIRECTLY TO RIANT THEATRE & covers everything on the festival's end of things)
Round Trip Train Rides: $480 (Ave. $80 from Albany to Penn Station, 6 times)
Supplies & Food: $100

Other Ways YOU Can Help:

As money is hard to come by these days, we understand if you are a friend or relative that can't help out financially!
STAY UPDATED ON HER PROGRESS IN THE STRAWBERRY ONE ACT FESTIVAL: www.TheRiantTheatre.com
Stay updated on Lydia's progress through her website: (www.LydiaJNightingale.wordpress.com)
"Like" her page on FaceBook: Lydia Nightingale

story:
#HERstoryCounts

I have been galvanized into action!! #HERstoryCounts is a theatre project: brave, rebellious, and unstoppable. A project I created in response to what I saw happening around us in our theatre and film communities with the lack of diversity from the creation level when it came to storytelling.  

#HERstoryCounts is a movement! One that I can see exploding all over the world one person at a time, one production at a time, taking root in communities everywhere. #HERstoryCounts is creating a new possibility for our theatre community. The possibility of having more female leaders, more womyn taking on big projects, more visibility for womyn who have felt silenced, and an overall awareness of the importance of womyn in the world free from constraint and living a life of self-expression and authenticity.

Aaaaand...  #HERstoryCounts is an independently financed Canadian production with big dreams, and it cannot be understated how much we need your support to make it a reality. Your contributions is what will make her story count. 

Please read on and watch the video above to learn more about our project and the different ways you can help us make her story count.

The Story

#HERstoryCounts is a series of monologues, autobiographical in nature. They are evocative stories of endurance, strength, loss, survival, and love that push the boundaries of what is often expected of womyn on stage. . . Real stories told from each of our different perspectives.

Why Should You Help Us?

1. Help a group of talented artists take the next step in their careers.

2. Become a part of making magic happen on stage. Check out the perks on the right, aimed to include you on our journey making her story count.

3. Champion a project about womyn and fuelled by womyn, from the creators to the crew.

4. Support local Canadian talent.

5. Give a voice to a brave and rebellious project.

Where Do Your Donations Go? 

Directly towards the production expenses of #HERstoryCounts. Our inaugural showcase will be April 22-24, 7:30pm at The Red Sandcastle Theatre.

  • Fees for the creators
  • Venue fees
  • Fees for the crew
  • Fees for the writing mentors
  • Marketing & Advertising

The Creators

Jennifer Neales, Artistic Producer
www.herstorycounts.wordpress.com
Tennille Read, Writer
Sundance Nagrial, Writer
Kelly Wilk, Writer
Susan A. Lock, Writer
Janet Romero-Leiva, Writer
Evangelia Kambites, Writer
Ordena Stephens-Thompson, Writer 

The Team

Melanie Hrymak, Co-Artistic Over-seer, Writing Mentor
www.melaniehrymak.com
Franny McCabe-Bennett, Stage Manager, Co-Artistic Over-seer
Jenna Borsato, Assistant Stage Manager, Assistant Producer
Melissa Major, Co-Artistic Over-seer
Trey Anthony, Writing Mentor
Anusree Roy, Writing Mentor


We have an INCREDIBLE team behind #HERstoryCounts who have each come on board because they believe in it and the space it can create for female-identified playwrights. Some productions we do for the rent, and others we do because we are PASSIONATE about them, as is the case for #HERstoryCounts.

Spread the Word: 

Lets face it, not everyone has pockets that drag to the floor. If you can’t make a donation, we can still use your help!  Spread the word by sharing our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat, Periscope: any and all social media sites! Make #HERstoryCount.

story:
Hi We are Level Up Studios!!!


We are a collective of dancers, designers, web developers, art enthusiasts and musicians who have been working and freelancing in our prospective fields, in Pittsburgh, for over the past 6 years. We've recently come together to cultivate our arts into a one stop shop and share our gifts with the community!! 
    • Level Up Studios is a creative arts studio that offers Dance Instruction, Design & Creative Writing Services, and Urban Apparel under one roof. Inspired by hip hop culture, Level Up celebrates its positive roots and serves as a creative playground for artists and enthusiasts. Created out of a passion for community reinvestment, Level Up Studios aims to make art, music and movement accessible in life, not just the classroom. Level Up Studios encourages students to explore their ideas through experimentation in the arts while building the skills to develop self confidence and cultural awareness.
    • Imagine a space where when you walk in, you are given the opportunity to take dance classes from some of the city’s most renowned choreographers and teachers; write and record your own music, receive graphic design services from logos to websites and purchase quality urban apparel. Well this is Level Up, the creative playground for the collaborative culture!
    •  Why we've come together: We feel as though it is our time to take our passions and gifts to the next level by joining in collaboration to build a space that gives backs to our community in a unique way. We feel that everyone should have access to the arts and that is why we are starting Level Up Studios. Utilizing our skill sets we will educate, mentor and empower youth and adults, while providing a service like no other.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We know that starting a studio can be expensive and this is why we need your support. Our goal is to raise $30,000 this will help us with:

Flooring, Mirrors, Rent, Speaker system, Media equipment, Staffing, Air Conditioning, City Permits, Lighting Fixtures, Instructors, Insurance, Marketing, Furnishing, Business Licenses, Office Equipment, Phone & Internet, Interior Design, Build-out Fees, Sound-Proofing, Furniture, Programming/Curriculum, Upkeep/Maintenance, Accounting, Signage etc.

Breakdown:

Equipment  $9270.72

Furnishing $2298

Retail Inventory $2500

Legal Fees/ Insurance  $2000

Software $1129.88

Signage $1348.22

Marketing & Web $4903.18

Studio Rent & Utilities $1750/mo

Studio Assistant/ Teaching Artist $4800/mo

TOTAL: $30,000

  • First and foremost, we want to thank you in advance for your support!!! As a contributor you can expect cool perks like: Free Dance Classes and Writing Workshops, Studio Access, Exclusive Level Up Merchandise and Discounted Design Services for starters! Please check out the rest of the perks on the right, and again thank you for your support, we wouldn't be able to do this work for our community without you!!! 



The Impact


Educate, Mentor & Empower:

  1. Strengths/Relationships: We want to build an environment where clients can truly learn, grow and be inspired!! Our goal is to not only help in advancing our students' talent, but also encouraging confidence within their attitude and look on life. Through teaching, we are able to mentor each student on a one on one basis, while helping them build on their strengths. Providing top notch classes, services and products is one thing;  we want to create a space that allows us to develop long lasting and direct relationships with our students and clients.
  2. Community Reinvestment: Level Up Studios also has a nonprofit summer youth program, in partnership with Sons of the Boogie known as the Zelda Pito Emerging Artist Fellowship. ZPEAF is a 3 week summer intensive designed to use storytelling, dance, poetry, graphic design, emceeing, and creative writing to explore identity construction and the concept of home among Pittsburgh area public high school students. Students will engage in critical dialogues with their cohort, artists, and social change leaders, develop professional networks, participate in group and individual mentoring sessions, and receive support and resources to create new artwork. The program's core message is: Learn to create, Create to empower, Empower to change.
  3. Collaborative Culture: We want this space to be a hub for creativity, a place where local artists and businesses of all types can cultivate and thrive! With this space we will be able to offer studio rentals, design and branding services, and opportunities for collaborative projects.
  4.  Community Resource: In addition to classes, apparel and services we want this space to host events for our community, from live showcases, to art exhibits, seminars and workshops.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about Level Up Studios!!! Share, share, share with friends, family, co-workers, dancers and artists!!! We know not everyone can contribute so lend a helping hand by sharing this campaign and please follow our progress on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/levelupdancestudio/

Find this campaign on Twitter & Youtube:

https://twitter.com/MarioQuinn

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cbluaEUp8a8



Honestly we wouldn’t be here if it wasn’t for our love of the arts, collaboration with like minds and community reinvestment. Help us make our dream come true by building Level Up Studios. We thank you for taking part in our journey and thank you ALL for your support!!!
story_txt:
Hi We are Level Up Studios!!!



We are a collective of dancers, designers, web developers, art enthusiasts and musicians who have been working and freelancing in our prospective fields, in Pittsburgh, for over the past 6 years. We've recently come together to cultivate our arts into a one stop shop and share our gifts with the community!! 



Level Up Studios is a creative arts studio that offers Dance Instruction, Design & Creative Writing Services, and Urban Apparel under one roof. Inspired by hip hop culture, Level Up celebrates its positive roots and serves as a creative playground for artists and enthusiasts. Created out of a passion for community reinvestment, Level Up Studios aims to make art, music and movement accessible in life, not just the classroom. Level Up Studios encourages students to explore their ideas through experimentation in the arts while building the skills to develop self confidence and cultural awareness.
Imagine a space where when you walk in, you are given the opportunity to take dance classes from some of the city’s most renowned choreographers and teachers; write and record your own music, receive graphic design services from logos to websites and purchase quality urban apparel. Well this is Level Up, the creative playground for the collaborative culture!
 Why we've come together: We feel as though it is our time to take our passions and gifts to the next level by joining in collaboration to build a space that gives backs to our community in a unique way. We feel that everyone should have access to the arts and that is why we are starting Level Up Studios. Utilizing our skill sets we will educate, mentor and empower youth and adults, while providing a service like no other.


   What We Need & What You Get 
We know that starting a studio can be expensive and this is why we need your support. Our goal is to raise $30,000 this will help us with:

Flooring, Mirrors, Rent, Speaker system, Media equipment, Staffing, Air Conditioning, City Permits, Lighting Fixtures, Instructors, Insurance, Marketing, Furnishing, Business Licenses, Office Equipment, Phone & Internet, Interior Design, Build-out Fees, Sound-Proofing, Furniture, Programming/Curriculum, Upkeep/Maintenance, Accounting, Signage etc.

Breakdown:
Equipment  $9270.72
Furnishing $2298
Retail Inventory $2500
Legal Fees/ Insurance  $2000
Software $1129.88
Signage $1348.22
Marketing & Web $4903.18

Studio Rent & Utilities $1750/mo
Studio Assistant/ Teaching Artist $4800/mo

TOTAL: $30,000



First and foremost, we want to thank you in advance for your support!!! As a contributor you can expect cool perks like: Free Dance Classes and Writing Workshops, Studio Access, Exclusive Level Up Merchandise and Discounted Design Services for starters! Please check out the rest of the perks on the right, and again thank you for your support, we wouldn't be able to do this work for our community without you!!! 






The Impact

 Educate, Mentor & Empower:



Strengths/Relationships: We want to build an environment where clients can truly learn, grow and be inspired!! Our goal is to not only help in advancing our students' talent, but also encouraging confidence within their attitude and look on life. Through teaching, we are able to mentor each student on a one on one basis, while helping them build on their strengths. Providing top notch classes, services and products is one thing;  we want to create a space that allows us to develop long lasting and direct relationships with our students and clients.


Community Reinvestment: Level Up Studios also has a nonprofit summer youth program, in partnership with Sons of the Boogie known as the Zelda Pito Emerging Artist Fellowship. ZPEAF is a 3 week summer intensive designed to use storytelling, dance, poetry, graphic design, emceeing, and creative writing to explore identity construction and the concept of home among Pittsburgh area public high school students. Students will engage in critical dialogues with their cohort, artists, and social change leaders, develop professional networks, participate in group and individual mentoring sessions, and receive support and resources to create new artwork. The program's core message is: Learn to create, Create to empower, Empower to change.


Collaborative Culture: We want this space to be a hub for creativity, a place where local artists and businesses of all types can cultivate and thrive! With this space we will be able to offer studio rentals, design and branding services, and opportunities for collaborative projects.

 Community Resource: In addition to classes, apparel and services we want this space to host events for our community, from live showcases, to art exhibits, seminars and workshops.

   
    Other Ways You Can Help Please spread the word about Level Up Studios!!! Share, share, share with friends, family, co-workers, dancers and artists!!! We know not everyone can contribute so lend a helping hand by sharing this campaign and please follow our progress on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/levelupdancestudio/
Find this campaign on Twitter & Youtube:
https://twitter.com/MarioQuinn
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cbluaEUp8a8


Honestly we wouldn’t be here if it wasn’t for our love of the arts, collaboration with like minds and community reinvestment. Help us make our dream come true by building Level Up Studios. We thank you for taking part in our journey and thank you ALL for your support!!!

story:
The most important accomplishment of our Company is organizing
The OKaua Theatre Festival

Behind this success hide 8 years of hard work and the tremendous efforts of each of the members who have hoped that one day, they could create a `playground` that theatre lovers and art lovers in general could benefit from.

For 2017, we proposed ourselves to make one step ahead and change the status of the festival to`international` but this is still only a dream, and that is why we need your help. We know that everyone can make a difference and we want to give you a chance to do that.

The Jury is composed of experts in theatrical pedagogy:

UNATC Instructors,TV hosts at the National Broadcasting Service of Romania, radio hosts, actors and actresses.

This first edition was the solid basis we needed in order to build up a strong, high class, national and even international competition in the following years.

Our goals are the main goals that define our troupe:
"Education through theatre"

In the Western countries this form of education is implemented in the scholar curriculum while in Romania it only occurs thanks to the ambition of some truly art devoted people.

Starting from the second edition, a new section was introduced: `College`, where shows produced by UNATC and The Hyperion University delighted the audience.

The name of our troupe, `OKaua` stands for our creed to take the measure of everything using a unique scale, the scale of TRUE VALUE and COMPETITION. "OKaua" is in romanian language a unit of measure from the 19th century.
This creed, inspired by William Shakespeare’s works, gave birth to the motto of the festival: `Measure for Measure`

We were the only high school troupe in Romania invited to play in professional festivals, including The International `Shakespeare` Festival, for three editions in a row so we know how important it is for a festival to invite both professionals and professionalized amateurs.

Troupes from all over the country will be invited at this 4th edition.

In order to encourage and help the development of the Arts in Romania, we want to add more diverse categories in this 4th edition. We already have a Prizes for Outstanding Voice, Costumes, and Posters and now we want to new categories for craft : Best Theatre Mask "Ion Sava" and a Best Scenographic Model/Miniature Mock-up "George Baron Lowendal". Additionally the winning Theatre Mask will be worn at the Carnival of Venice by OKaua Theatre Companys members who hopefully be performing there in 2017.

Also, daily workshops will be held by professionals and video projections will be screened.

Our festival wants to add even more forms of art at future editions like : theater - dance, theater animation, sports theater, pantomime, musical shows, and puppet theater.

We need this fundraising in order to pay for the transport, food and accommodations for every international or national troupe that would like to join us and every person who wants to see the performances but does not have the means to do it.

The present stage of the festival

Period: Between 12th - 15th of May 2016

Location: The Student's Cultural House of Bucharest (Bucharest)

Structure:
-Show Competition
Two Competitional Sections:
-High School (besides the play in the contest, there will be another `Short Play`, with a given sequence of a script)
-College (besides the play in the contest, there will be an impromptu)
-Dance and Theatre acts outside the competition
-Workshops
-Theatre Crafts Competition

The Grand Prix of this Festival can be awarded to both a High School or a College Show.

We would be pleased with any help that you can give, maybe a share, or a facebook like, a kind word, is all you have to give right now, and we really appreciate it.

We self-finance ourselves through the contributions of each and every member and this is how we mostly have financed our festival, a lot of people/little sponsors have joined our cause but they are not enough for what we want to build.

We sold handmade objects for 3 years to be able to pay for a part of the last editions of this event. We also had shows especially for raising money for the project, did volunteer work to promote our festival, won some prizes in money over time and all the money were also raised for the festival.

We know how to deal with struggles because we started from nothing. We learned how to work with people, how to promote our ideas, how to build things with our hands, how to make promotional stuff and how to build something from scratch. We can learn anything, and we can help you learn it to.

We want our festival to grow along with its team and so we decided to ask everyone for help.

THANK YOU,
OKaua Theatre Company.

https://www.facebook.com/FestivaluldeTeatruOKaua/
http://okaua.ro/

story:
Programme de bourse TransFormation | 

The TransFormation Scholarship Program

(english will follow)


© Michael Slobodian | Interprètes Odile Amélie Peters et Marilyn Cyr

Transformation est un atelier intensif de danse contemporaine qui chevauche le Festival TransAmériques et le OFFta ce qui permet aux participants de baigner littéralement dans la création contemporaine. TransFormation accueille des danseurs d'horizons diverses ayant des vues et intérêts éclectiques. Cela contribue à en faire un espace/temps unique.


Pour souligner notre 10e anniversaire nous vous encourageons à donner 10$!

╰☆╮ 10$ fait une différence!!╰☆╮



Un soutien à nos danseurs!

© Anne-Flore de Rochambeau 


Le Programme de bourse TransFormation 

Le Programme de bourses de TransFormation a été conçu afin de venir en aide aux artistes professionnels et pré- professionnels qui bénéficieraient grandement d’une participation à une portion ou à la totalité du stage.

Le stage TransFormation est un événement unique qui offre non seulement des opportunités aux danseurs de rencontrer les artistes créateurs d’ici et d’ailleurs, mais qui renverse aussi la dynamique et permet aux chorégraphes et répétiteurs de voir ces artistes dans leur propre travail, d’explorer avec eux pendant une semaine ou plus et de créer des affinités. C’est un vecteur d’échanges dans un territoire où peuvent naître des collaborations, des opportunités professionnelles et des projets fertiles qui seraient impossibles dans un simple contexte d’audition.


╰☆╮ 10$ fait une différence!!╰☆╮


© Anne-Flore de Rochambeau | Interprète Axelle Munezero


Grâce à la générosité de nos partenaires du Programme de Bourse TransFormation nous avons déjà réussis à amasser 2500$. C'est maintenant vers vous, notre chère communauté, que l'on se tourne afin de faire appel à votre aide pour soutenir les artistes en donnant à notre programme de bourse 10$ pour notre 10e anniversaire. 


                                    ╰☆╮ ╰☆╮ ╰☆╮ 


En 2015, des bourses totalisant plus de 3500$ ont été accordées à 8 récipiendaires.


 Odile Amélie Peters

Joshua Sailo

Julie Tymchuk

Paco Ziel

Marilyne Cyr

Christina Paquette

Jossua Collins Dufour


╰☆╮ ╰☆╮ ╰☆╮


Un soutien à nos danseurs! 

S'il-vous plaît, devenez un donateur!   

╰☆╮ 10$ fait une différence!!╰☆╮

 

© Anne-Flore de Rochambeau | Interpretes Charlie Prince, Kelly McInnes et Laura Barecelo

              

Un message de Julie Tymchuk:

Se transformer, grandir au sein d'une communauté qui fait preuve d'ouverture d'esprit et de respect est une des plus belles expériences que l'on peut vivre en tant qu'être humain. Pour moi, le stage est synonyme de ce sentiment.

Je participe au stage Transformation depuis plus de 8 ans. Chaque expérience fut unique, teintée par les différents artistes invités. Le seul dénominateur commun est le bonheur de danser dans un contexte riche et stimulant.

╰☆╮╰☆╮╰☆╮╰☆╮


__________________________________________________________________

The TransFormation Scholarship Program


© Michael Slobodian | Interpreters Odile Amelie Peters and Marilyne Cyr

TransFormation is an annual contemporary dance intensive which overlaps with the Festival TransAmériques and the OFFta. It provides participants with total immersion in the world of cutting-edge contemporary dance and creation. TransFormation brings together dancers from different horizons with different views and interests. Together these factors make for a very unique and enriching experience. 


To celebrate our 10th anniversary we encourage you to donate $10!

╰☆╮$10 makes a difference!╰☆╮



Support for our dancers!

© Anne-Flore de Rochambeau

The TransFormation Scholarship Program


TransFormation Scholarship Program is designed to provide assistance to professional and pre-professional artists who would benefit from attending either the full, or a specified component of the programming.


TransFormation is a unique event which not only offers opportunities for dancers to work closely with creators from Montreal and abroad, but also allows choreographers and rehearsal directors to see the artistes within their own work, exploring and creating with them throughout a week or two creating  kinships. It is a vector for exchange in which collaboration, professional opportunities and fertile projects are born, something that is impossible in the context of a single audition.


╰☆╮ $10 makes a difference!╰☆╮


© Anne-Flore de Rochambeau


Thanks to the generosity of TransFormation Scholarship Partners, we have already raised $2500 in scholarships for the 10th anniversary edition. It is at this point that we turn to you, our community, and ask for you help in supporting our artists by donating to the scholarship program. 


Support for our artists!
10$ for our 10th anniversary!


In 2015, a total of $3500 in scholarships were awarded to 8 artists!

 Odile Amélie Peters

Joshua Sailo

Julie Tymchuk

Paco Ziel

Marilyne Cyr

Christina Paquette

Jossua Collins Dufour

╰☆╮╰☆╮╰☆╮╰☆╮


A few words from Joshua Sailo:

The benefit of the Scholarship program goes beyond my personal development, but affects and enforces cross-cultural sharing of information as the knowledge gained affects many others through the sharing of our experience and invokes a series of new thought and ideas. I look forward to an invigorating and enriching few weeks at Transformation 2016


© Michael Slobodian | Interpreters Jerimy Rivera and Paco Ziel


╰☆╮╰☆╮╰☆╮╰☆╮

Support for our artists!

Please become a donor!

╰☆╮ $10 makes a difference!!╰☆╮


A message from Paco Ziel




•••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••


Notre corps professoral 2016 | 

Our 2016 faculty:

Laboratoire de création | Creation laboratories

Gioconda Barbuto, Virginie Brunelle, Paul-André Fortier, Manuel Roque et Ismael Mouaraki

Artistes Internationale | International Artists

Jose Agudo, Laura Aris Alvarez et James O'Hara

Ateliers | Workshops

Clara Furey, Mistaya Hemmingway, Kelly Keenan, Alanna Kraaijeveld, Éric Zig Martel

Ateliers FTA | FTA workshops

Louise Lecavalier et Robert Abubo 

*2 autres artistes du FTA annoncer le 22 mars| 2 more FTA artists announced March 22

Classes technique | Technique classes

Sophie Corriveau, Daniel Villeneuve, Jamie Wright

story:
Summary

Up the Ante formed in November 2014, with the aim to work cooperatively, collaboratively to create fresh and thought provoking new theatre by working with other artists, and building community links. The company was formed by professionals from performance-related fields, and has a focus on skill-sharing with members sharing their personal skill and expertise through a series of workshops. 
Auguste and the Moon is an adaptation of Henry Miller's short story The Smile at the Foot of the Ladder, and follows the story of August the clown and his journey to find himself and his true purpose in life. It echos the struggles which many people face today with finding a true path and the possible consequences and sacrifices which must be made to get there.
We have a venue secured and the script, actors and a design for the show are ready to go and now we just need your help to make it happen. Our set, costume and technical design team need the funds to bring their wonderful ideas into reality. 

What We Need & What You Get

We now need the funds to buy materials and objects to create August's world for the audience. We will need £2500 to help realise our designer's wonderful plans which involve using the height of our venue at the beautiful Trinity Centre in Bristol. 
We are offering free tickets for the show, signed copies of programmes and juggling balls along with oppertunities to meet the cast and crew, have sneak peaks into our process and to be invited to a free workshop run by our members. 
Even the smallest contributions will help towards purchasing materials for the creation of set and costumes and help to create the wonderful world of Auguste the clown.

The Impact

Our company has been going from strength to strength and the more shows we do the more we can follow our aims of providing affordable theatre for everyone. Following the success we will be able to offer more workshops and offer more places within our members for artists to grow and gain skills. 
We offer a collaborative way for actors, designers and creatives to develop their work and opportunities for people who may not otherwise get the opportunity to work in this way. 
Our plans for the future do not stop with Auguste and the Moon and any donation you can make will help us on our development forwards.

Risks & Challenges

We are currently in the process of applying for arts council funding but this is by no means a guarantee and we need to be able to begin building the set as soon as possible. We aim to be as frugal as possible using recycled materials and buying second hand where possible but this still needs funding. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute the more people hear about the project the more we will have to put towards it to create a truly wonderful piece of theatre.

Please follow us on twitter and facebook and share our event with everyone you know! Don't forget to book your tickets!

  • Facebook Event for Auguste and the Moon- https://www.facebook.com/events/639397112866649/
  • Our Facebook page-https://www.facebook.com/antetheatre/?fref=ts
  • Our Website- http://www.antetheatre.co.uk/
story_txt:
Summary
Up the Ante formed in November 2014, with the aim to work cooperatively, collaboratively to create fresh and thought provoking new theatre by working with other artists, and building community links. The company was
formed by professionals from performance-related fields, and has a focus on skill-sharing with members sharing their personal skill and expertise through a series of workshops. 
Auguste
and the Moon is an adaptation of Henry Miller's short story The Smile at the
Foot of the Ladder, and follows the story of August the clown and his journey to find himself and his true purpose in life. It echos the struggles which many people face today with finding a true path and the possible consequences and sacrifices which must be made to get there.
We have a venue secured and the script, actors and a design for the show are ready to go and now we just need your help to make it happen. Our set, costume and technical design team need the funds to bring their wonderful ideas into reality.

story:
Bref résumé

Marie-Denise Bettez et Marika Dumoulin sont deux jeunes artistes à têtes fortes qui ont élaboré un projet de recherche autour du thème de la femme vulnérable. Ce projet a mené à la pièce F E M, qui sera présentée au Festival Fringe de Montréal en juin 2016.

Étant toutes deux artistes de la relève, elles ont décidé de faire une demande de subvention au Conseil des Arts du Canada afin de pouvoir payer les trois chorégraphes et l'interprète du projet qui travailleront chacun entre 30 et 120 heures et pour se payer elles aussi, en tant qu'interprètes et chargées de projet pour les quelque 200 heures investies. À travers le Canada, seulement quelques projets recevront une subvention. Même si elles espèrent de tout leur cœur obtenir ce financement,  il n'y a aucune garantie que le gouvernement soutiendra le Projet F E M.

 Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez

Pour la production au festival, nous devons payer de notre poche (en attendant de, peut-être, recevoir de l'aide financière du gouvernement) :

- Le diffuseur

- Tout le matériel promotionnel (photo, images, affiches, affichettes, communiqué de presse, impression)

- Les studios de répétitions

- Les collaborateurs (graphiste, éclairagiste, concepteur sonore)

- Décors, costumes, accessoires

- Réseautage lors du festival

- Cachets des artistes

- Et bien plus encore

Nous aimerions amasser 5000 $ afin de payer tous ces services, mais quel que soit le montant récolté, petit ou grand, il nous sera d'une aide incommensurable pour le développement du projet.


 L'impact

Il n'est jamais heureux qu'un travail artistique accompli nous laisse dans le négatif. Le Projet F E M nous tient tellement à cœur que nous voulons qu'il soit une réussite totale. Comme nous en sommes encore à nos premières expériences d'élaboration de projet, il est important pour nous que cette opportunité se classe comme étant une expérience positive et mémorable.


Risques et défis

Nous sommes prêtes à travailler sans garantie de salaire, c'est pourquoi nous nous considérons comme des artistes dévoués à leur art. Par contre, nous essaierons par tous les moyens que notre travail soit rémunéré et nous ne sommes pas du genre à laisser tomber au premier obstacle. Nous sommes des guerrières et nous voulons que notre travail soit reconnu! Aidez-nous à valoriser notre art!


 D'autres façons d'aider

Nous comprenons que ce n'est pas possible pour tout le monde de donner une cotisation en argent, mais il est gratuit et facile de nous aider en partageant nos événements! Partagez notre page Indiegogo ou encore notre page Facebook! Invitez les gens à venir voir le spectacle du 10 au 19 juin 2016. Partagez l'événement du spectacle! Merci!
Page Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Projetfem/?fref=ts
Événement Facebook du spectacle: https://www.facebook.com/events/238458779847773/
Site de vente de billets: http://2016.montrealfringe.ca/index.php/spectacle/f-e-m/

Indiegogo: https://igg.me/at/projetfem
