story:
ULTIMATE MAN! has been selected to participate in NYMF (New York Musical Festival) 2016. The artistic collaboration team is thrilled to be participating in the "Sundance" of new musicals.  However, even with limited funding from the festival, grants and personal resources, we need $17,000 to cover the costs of rehearsal space, casting, costumes, publicity, a choreographer, a musical director, all the actors and many, many other costs. (BTW...We are working within all the talent unions) Let's face it, producing a musical in NYC is a costly undertaking!

The "ULTIMATE MAN!" Story:

The Comic World is in a state of chaos. Joe, the artist who draws the politically savvy ULTIMATE MAN! has lost control of his characters and himself. Ultimate Man, in a desperate attempt to save his beloved Cathy Cookie, confronts the cartoonist in the Real World, and is followed by Rex Ringer, a villain!  Buffy, Joe’s publisher, has her own twisted agenda, so Joe is faced with the dilemma of creating edgy art or embracing mass appeal in a corporate world.  For Joe, worlds collide in this comic adventure.

The Team: The show is composed by Alastair William King, with a book by Jane Edith Wilson and Charles Abbott with lyrics by Paul Gambaccini, Alastair William King and Jane Edith Wilson.  The story was first conceived by Paul Gambaccini.

All donations are needed and deeply appreciated. Share on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or even that old-fashioned thing known as email! We only have 30 days to raise this money so we need all the help we can possibly get!

ABOUT THE TEAM

CHARLES ABBOTT (Director, Book) – Director: -- Multiple productions at Alabama Shakespeare; The Alley in Houston; The Alliance -- (3 years as Associate Artistic Director); 5th Avenue -- ; -- Fulton Opera House; Maine State Music Theatre (30-year history including 20 years as Artistic Director); Music Theatre of Wichita; Portland Stage; Houston’s TUTS including the World Premiere of Yeston/Kopit’s Phantom! , and Follies twice; and 31 productions at Walnut Street Theatre from Oliver in 1983 to South Pacific later this year, representing 4 world premieres, 2 Barrymore Awards, 5 nominations, and the Edwin Forrest Lifetime Achievement Award.  Recent off-Bdwy: I Forgive You, Ronald Reagan.  He received the first-ever Directing Drama-Logue Award for Oklahoma! at LA Opera. Writer: co-authored Games, produced in Toronto by Marlene Smith; a new book for Zev Bufman’s tour of Panama Hattie starring Ann Miller; and Not Just Kidstuff for The Alliance.  Also a Broadway and regional theatre actor, he’s played over 1000 performances as Cabaret’s Emcee beginning in the 1st National -- under Harold Prince’s direction.  He’s honored to have an SDC Foundation Fellowship in his name, which allowed burgeoning directors to assist Artistic Directors of Pittsburgh Public, Arena Stage, Signature, Pioneer and Hartford Stage.

PAUL GAMBACCINI (Conceiver, Co-Lyricist) Born in the Bronx, he graduated from Dartmouth College, where he was General Manager of WDCR, then the nation’s largest radio station run by students.  He then won scholarships to Oxford University, earning a degree in Philosophy, Politics and Economics.  Gambaccini was one of the early music journalists on ROLLING STONE magazine, having more bylines than anyone else on the paper in 1973.  While still at Oxford he became involved with BBC radio.  Paul is the only broadcaster to have had his own series on BBC Radios 1, 2, 3 and 4.  He is also the only one to have appeared regularly on the British television stations BBC 1, BBC 2, ITV, Channel 4 and Sky.  For several years Paul broadcast The Classic Countdown on Classic FM, achieving the highest ratings in the history of the network.  He has presented the Ivor Novello songwriting awards for 29 years.  Paul was co-author of the million-selling title THE GUINNESS BOOK OF BRITISH HIT SINGLES.  Another of his co-productions, TELEVISION’S GREATEST HITS, was both a book and BBC television series.  During the Silver Age of Comics, Paul was the second Executive Secretary of the Academy of Comic Book Fans and Collectors and attended the first Comicon in 1964.  The villainous tailor Paul Gambi in THE FLASH was named after him. 

ALASTAIR WILLIAM KING (Music, Co-Lyricist)  Born in Glasgow, Scotland, he lives in New York City.  He is the co-composer/co-book writer for Outlaws-The Ballad of Billy the Kid (NYMF 2011), composer of The Family Fiorelli (NYMF 2007, NAMT 2008 Finalist, York Theatre Developmental Reading Series 2010/11), composer for Christy and the Playboys (Stowe Theatre, Vermont) and he wrote the revue Relationships (Tada Theatre, New York City, CCT Theatre, St. Croix).  He is also the composer for 3 children’s musicals The Adventures of Superbunny (Midtown International Theatre Festival 2013), A Superbunny Christmas and Superbunny’s Pirate Vacation (The Actor’s Fund Arts Center).  His pop songs have been published by Carlin and Southern Music and recorded and released by Warner Music and Viva Records.  As a pianist, he has performed at Chez Josephine, the former Windows on the World, and the world famous Rainbow Room.  As a dancer/singer he performed in shows in London’s West End at the London Palladium, Royalty Theatre, Royal Opera House and in a cabaret revue at La Vie En Rose.  Alastair also danced for ZDF TV and was a featured dancer in the video for the world-wide pop hit Total Eclipse of the Heart.

JANE EDITH WILSON (Book, Co-Lyricist) As a writer, Jane’s plays have been performed all over the US.  She is the recipient of a playwriting grant from The Pilgrim Project and a screenwriting fellowship from The Writer’s Guild of America.  She also wrote, produced and played the title character in the film JANEANE FROM DES MOINES, which debuted at the Toronto International Film Festival.  She created and helped produce the popular web series “Kids Court.“  She has been a professional actress for over 30 years, acting in over 40 plays in NYC, Los Angeles and various professional regional theatres.  She was Connie on the critically acclaimed BRAVO series “Significant Others” and has been featured on TBS’s “Frank TV” on “Curb Your Enthusiasm”, “Seinfeld” , “1600 Penn“, “The Crazy Ones“ , and “ER“. Other film credits include “Catch Me If You Can”, “American Zombie” and “Eight Legged Freaks”. She was the recipient of the Dramalogue Award for Best Performance as a Lead Actress in the Harry Kondoleon play “The Houseguests”.

... and read about us on the NYMF website!

http://www.nymf.org/festival/2016-events/ultima...

story:
The World Premiere of THE MISSING PEACE 

            

We are raising money for the Capital Fringe Festival world premiere of THE MISSING PEACE a new musical by Ron Melrose. THE MISSING PEACE is a musical folk tale about Brianna, a young girl who embarks on a journey to find her banished mother and heal her land. Kelly Williams Carlson directs Christine Demuth in this multi-character one woman musical which has been arranged for violin, flute, keyboard, and percussion by Mandee Ferrier Roberts and Co-produced by StillPointe Theatre of Baltimore. 


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise enough money to:

  • Pay the Capital Fringe Festival Participation and Insurance Fees
  • Pay the artists, designers, and musicians involved in the production 
  • Pay for materials to make our costumes and props
  • Pay for advertisements (postcards, posters, online ads)

    

         


We  have a number of unique perks for those that donate including:

  • Online thank you's and shout outs
  • Your name in our program
  • Capital Fringe buttons
  • Complimentary Tickets to the show
  • Complimentary Tickets + a bottle of wine
  • An original thank you song composed in your honor and posted to YouTube
  • A bound copy of the script/libretto signed by the composer/lyricist 
The Impact

Your contribution will help to bring a new original musical to life.

            


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, there are many other ways you can help!

-You can help get the word out! 

  • Share this campaign with your Facebook friends, your twitter followers, and your email contacts.
  • If you know of any reviewers, bloggers, podcasters or arts' writers looking for a story, send them our way.

-You can follow us on social media

  • Follow us on Twitter @misspeaceshow #missingpeaceshow #takebackyourbreath
  • Like our Facebook page: facebook.com/takebackyourbreath
  • Visit our website missingpeaceshow.wix.com/stillpointe
  • Follow us on instagram: stillpointe_theatre

-Come see the show!

One of the best ways you can support the creation of this new musical is by coming to see the show. Tickets go on sale on June 20. Purchase tickets at capitalfringe.org

story:
Phaedra 
is the daughter of Minos and Pasiphaë, wife of Theseus, sister of Ariadne, stepmother of Hippolytus, and Queen of Athens. She is the lovesick icon of Greek mythology, the paragon of tragic desire. Since 400 BC, the world can't stop making plays about her. Now, four St. Louis theatre companies undertake an exploration of Phaedra's theatrical legacy. 

Please support The Phaedra Phestival, a classical event and fundraiser supporting theatrical experimentation for these St. Louis companies: 
ERA, Poor Monsters, SATE, & YoungLiars. 

The Phaedra Phestival takes place over 3 days, with a theatrical event occurring on each day. The specifics of the 3 events are as follows:

DAY 1 - PHAEDRA'S BIG, PHAT GREEK WEDDING 

Slightly Askew Theatre Ensemble,

Minos, and Pasiphaë

request the honor of your presence

at the wedding of their heroine/daughter

Phaedra

to

Theseus, King of Athens

On Phriday, the twelfth of August

[two thousand sixteen]


DAY 2: 50 SHADES OF PHAEDRA

YoungLiars cordially invites you to the book release party for

50 Shades of Phaedra

Saturday, August 13, 2016

Please join us for an evening of readings by the authoress, followed by music, socializing, and phun as we celebrate the release of this phiery book

Attire is party chic


DAY 3: PHAEDRA'S PHUNERAL

Equally Represented Arts and Poor Monsters regret to inform you of the death of Phaedra. We request the honor of your presence at a phuneral service celebrating her life on August 14, 2016. Please bring your thoughts, prayers, and phondest memories of the deceased. Reception to follow.
(We expect the attendance of many iconic and tragic women at this event. Please plan accordingly.)

The Phaedra Phestival exists as an experimental and collaborative theatrical investigation and fundraiser for the 2016-2017 production seasons of ERA, Poor Monsters, SATE, and YoungLiars .  


What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise $10,000 to be divided among the 4 participating organizations for their 2016-17 projects. Your contributions are how you gain admission to The Phaedra Phestival's events, and other perks.

  • $10-  PHAEDRA PHAN: Admission to your choice of ONE of the three Phestival Events: Phaedra’s Big, Phat, Greek Wedding; 50 Shades of Phaedra; or Phaedra’s Phuneral.

  • $18- PHAEDRA PHAMILY: Admission to your choice of TWO of the three Phestival Events: Phaedra’s Wedding, 50 Shades of Phaedra, and/or Phaedra’s Phuneral.

  • $25- PHULL-PHRONTAL PHAEDRA: Admission to ALL THREE of the Phestival Events: Phaedra’s Wedding, 50 Shades of Phaedra, and Phaedra’s Phuneral.

  • $50- PHAEDRA’S PHAERIE GODMOTHER: A Phaedra Phestival poster signed by the Phestival artists, PLUS all the perks of PHULL-PHRONTAL PHAEDRA.

  • $100- A video thank you from cast member, PLUS all the perks of PHULL-PHRONTAL PHAEDRA.

  • $250- PHAEDRA PHOREVER: A Phaedra's Phestival photo album, PLUS all the perks of PHULL-PHRONTAL PHAEDRA.

  • $500- PHAEDRA’S PHAVORITE: Phaedra's Wedding Album, Phaedra's Phuneral Memorial Keepsake Book of Eulogies and More, or a copy of 50 Shades of Phaedra, PLUS all the perks of PHULL-PHRONTAL PHAEDRA.

  • $1000- PHACTION OF PHAEDRA or THE UNSPEAKABLE: A live (or video recorded, your preference) eulogy of you from a tragic female character, PLUS all the perks of PHAEDRA'S PHAVORITE.

The Impact

The proceeds raised from this campaign will be divided among the 4 participating arts organizations to support these groups 2016-17 projects. Specifically, your contributions go towards these theatre companies' production costs such as artists' fees, design materials, space and equipment rentals, marketing, and other expenses. Your contributions allow these companies to continue to create professional, thoughtful, and courageous work. 


Who Are These People?

Equally Represented Arts (ERA)

ERA is an independent, experimental theatre company based in St. Louis, MO.

Mission: Theatre is a collaborative, multi-disciplinary, live art form. ERA's mission is to use the elements unique to theatre's identity to expand the possibilities for what that art for can be, thereby challenge expectations for meaning in theatre, art, and the world. We root ourselves in the believe that all theatre's components are equal, and that innovation stems from experimentation.

Poor Monsters

Poor Monsters is an experimental theatre company concocting new works and fighting for gender parity.

Slightly Askew Theatre Ensemble

Slightly Askew Theatre Ensemble (SATE) is a non-profit, 501(c)(3), with the mission to encourage and enable an intense exploration of movement-based theatre through ongoing training, education, and collaboration.The company is comprised of artists from varying disciplines devoted to movement training, the telling of stories through an exploration of words, movement, and sound, educational outreach, and the creation and development of new theatrical works and the revisiting of established works as an ensemble.

YoungLiars

#moreartlessadmin

YoungLiars is a loosely-knit collective of like-minded artists committed to creating unique inter-disciplinary theatre performance, including both original works and radically entertaining re-imaginings of the classics. We believe that magic is created through the fusion of different art forms and that bold simple theatricality will set hearts and minds on fire. We believe that the theatrical experience is richer and deeper than simple voyeurism and that audiences, now more than ever, crave engagement and involvement, and want to be challenged rather than placated.

PROJECTS YOUR MONEY COULD FUND:

ERA

  • R + J: A Telephone Play at SIUE's Xfest in September 2016

  • Immersive version of Twelfth Night in April 2017

  • The Misanthrope,  2017

POOR MONSTERS

  • OR WHAT YOU WILL, PART DEUX at the St Lou Fringe Festival, August 2016

SATE

  • Mary Shelley Monster Show, August 2016

  • Cuddles, November 2016

YOUNGLIARS

  • Commedia/Grand Guignol version of The Most Lamentable Roman Tragedy of Titus Androgynous in 2017


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t attend any of the Phaedra Phestival Phunctions, you can still be a part of the action!

  • Donate!

  • Share this campaign on social media!

  • Tell your phriends!

  • Tell your phriends’ phriends!

  • Wander the streets, lamenting your inability to go, but lauding the general public’s ability to participate in this phantastic event!

  • Honor the memory of our dear Phaedra as often as you can by donating to The Phaedra Phestival multiple times!
story_txt:
Phaedra 

is the daughter of Minos and Pasiphaë, wife of Theseus, sister of Ariadne, stepmother of Hippolytus, and Queen of Athens. She is the lovesick icon of Greek mythology, the paragon of tragic desire. Since 400 BC, the world can't stop making plays about her. Now, four St. Louis theatre companies undertake an exploration of Phaedra's theatrical legacy. 
Please support The Phaedra Phestival, a classical event and fundraiser supporting theatrical experimentation for these St. Louis companies: ERA, Poor Monsters, SATE, & YoungLiars. The Phaedra Phestival takes place over 3 days, with a theatrical event occurring on each day. Equally Represented

story:
About Rhythmic Motion:

Rhythmic Motion is an evening length dance concert exploring the body as an instrument in movement and the rhythmic interconnections of movement and sound. This intimate concert brings the audience close to the movement in the beautiful wood floored Headwaters Studio in Missoula, MT. The concert explores the use of body percussion, vocals, breath, live music, designed sound scores, and sound creation within contemporary modern movement. It also incorporates Dance for Camera elements through dance for camera videos and the interaction between projection and live dance. 

The rhythmic sensations and vibrations of movement intrigue choreographer, Arina Hunter. Rhythmic Motion is her culminating senior project for her BFA in Dance from the University of Montana. She is producing the concert on her own as a beginning professional experience. Arina is working with a cast of five dancers along with tech designers including sound and lighting. It will be presented May 18th and 19th 2015 at the Headwaters Studio in Missoula, MT. 

The concert features a range of pieces that explore a wide variety of live sound creation and designed soundscapes. It is an innovative exploration of a movement language developed through sounds and movement coming and interacting together. The work is textured, powerful, expansive, detailed, layered, and passionate. Rhythmic Motion is family friendly and fun for all ages. 

Who we are:

Arina Hunter is a senior at the University of Montana working towards her BFA in Dance. Rhythmic Motion is her culminating senior project. She is compelled by the vibrations and kinesthetic sensations of movement. The way the body in movement connects to a beat and the sound score and how that translates viscerally to the audience. She also is exploring the development of a movement language, through movement and sound. Arina is working with a group of four dancers along with tech designers including sound and lighting. Her cast of dancers are upperclassmen in the University of Montana Dance Program. 


What we Need & What you Get

Producing a concert requires a lot of support, we are raising as much as we can to go towards the costs of production. Your help will go towards:

  • Space Rental 
  • Publicity Materials -posters, programs, flyers, press release, printed materials
  • Costumes
  • Documentation -video equipment, dvds
  • Tech Needs  -video equipment, projection equipment, sound and lighting needs
  • Pay Tech -sound designer, lighting designer, stage manager
  • Pay dancers 

Creating and producing a show takes an enormous amount of time, energy, and love from many people. Our first priority is to pay for the needed space rental, publicity, costume, and show elements. Through your support we will be able to compensate the people who are essential to putting on the show, our tech designers and the dancers. 

To say thank you for your support we have a list of thank you incentives. Ranging from shout outs and thank you cards to pictures from the show and personalized thank you videos. Any support that you can give is invaluable and we will send love and gratitude your way for any help you can give!


The Impact

Your help and support will help bring Arina Hunter’s senior project and first evening length concert to the Missoula community. Young artists are turning to many new sources to find the support to produce their work and your support will help with the development and full production capabilities of Arina’s work and will better enable us to share it with the community. 

Risks & Challenges

I've taken a risk creating this show without the guarantee of a budget. The show will go on if our fundraising is not reached, but at sacrifice to the artists involved and the ability to fully design, document, and share the work with the community. I will cover the cost of space rental, costumes, publicity, and tech elements if not funded to the best of my ability, but will be unable to fully integrate my intention.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount that you can give helps, even $5! You can also help by sharing this campaign and project with everyone you know. Share the link to our Indiegogo page and our Facebook page (facebook.com/RhythmicMotion) on social media and spread the word to everyone you know! Any of course coming to our show on May 18th and 19th 2015 at the Headwaters Studio in Missoula, MT. 

For more information check out our Facebook page: Facebook.com/RhythmicMotion

story:
Welcome to the CAN-paign!

If you've landed here it's likely you already know us . . . but for those of you who stumbled here by chance, we are Red Tape Theatre.  Hi.  We make plays, usually experimental in nature, and we are inviting you to JOIN THE WALK!

. . . by shelling out One Single Dollar.  (yes, you read that right.)

Our CANpaign will help us raise funds to produce Taylor Mac's The Walk Across America for Mother Earth as part of Steppenwolf Theatre Company's 6th Annual Garage Rep.  Our set forThe Walk Across America for Mother Earth will feature 3,000 Coca-Cola cans . . . um.  Did you catch that?  3,000 cans.  On stage.  YOU GUYS THREE THOUSAND IS A HECK OF A LOT OF CANS.  And why Coca-Cola, you ask?  Because, duh: Nothing says America like "The Great National Temperance Beverage."  Obviously.

Our goal: To raise $1 for every coke can that appears on our stage.

That translates into:  You turning over your couch cushions, checking the dryer after doing laundry, or digging through the gum wrappers strewn under the passenger seat for some spare change.  Cause we are only asking you to give us a buck. ONE! One crisp, crumpled, or creased George Washington. No more, no less.

In return for your ONE dollar donation, you will get ONE dollar off your ticket when you come to see The Walk Across America for Mother Earth.  (Just go ahead and work out the math on that one, kids.)  

Once you donate, let all of us at Red Tape Theatre and all your friends know how magnanimous you are by sharing our CANpaign on social media and tagging #JOINTHEWALK & #CANpaign. 

Together we can get to $3,000.  Yes we CAN-CAN!!

P.S. If you have any empty coke cans lying around, let us know.  We'll gladly take them off your hands.

For more info on the show and what the $3,000 will be used for, keep on reading.  For those of you who don't care, STOP HERE, grab the change out of your pockets, and buy the world a coke!

So where CAN I get my tickets?

Here.  Easy as pie:  Steppenwolf Garage Rep

Or here.  Easy as cookies:  Red Tape Theatre

So what's this walk about?

Political activism meets bedazzled drag show in this story about two young friends who flee their suburban upbringing in “Real America” to join a ragtag group of activists on a protest march from D.C. to Nevada. On the road, the group attempts to establish a nomadic utopia, but the marchers continually find themselves divided by unrequited affections, indecision, and a secret hunger for power. Whimsically blending commedia dell’arte influences with song and dance, The Walk Across America for Mother Earth explores how the idea of community sometimes fails to unite us, and sometimes brings us together in the most unexpected ways.

So who's walking the walk?

The cast and crew for The Walk Across America for Mother Earth include:

Cast list

Breon Arzell (Ensemble)
Nikos Brisco (Beeka)
Nick Combs (Nick)*
Sean Ewert (Marsha) 
Alex Grelle (Kelly)
Luke Michael Grimes (Ensemble)
WITCH HAZEL (Jimica/Key-Key/Ensemble)
Ruth Margraff (Flower)
Morgan McNaught (Angie)
Sadie Rogers (King Arthur)
Angelica Roque (Rainbow Carl)
Johnard Washington (Greeter)* 

Artistic Staff

Director: Bonnie Metzgar
Artistic Consultant: Eric Hoff
Musical Director: Jon Schneidman
Producing Director: JD Cannady*
Scenic Design: Yu Shibagaki
Costume/Make-Up Design: Izumi Inaba *
Sound Design: Aaron Stephenson
Lighting Design: Rebecca Barrett
Music Director: Jon Schneidman
Properties Design: Scott Dickens                                                                                         Casting Director:  Laura Durham*
Production Manager: Julian Gonzalez
Stage Manager: Janette Bauer
Assistant Director: Katrina Dion
Assistant Costume Designer: Liesl Krieger

*Denotes Red Tape Theatre Company Member

story:
Valleto’s Artistic Director, Valeria Gonzalez, found herself while discovering her inner passion of establishing VALLETO. Many of her own dramatic, raw and inspiring cultural encounters in the artistic world led her to create what VALLETO truly consist of: a platform which inspires and unifies the art and dance community. VALLETO is a group of unique and culturally diverse dancers that create space for vulnerability, imagination and through movement a new impassioned form of art is uncovered. 

VALLETO is a New York-based emerging dance theater company led by Valeria Gonzalez.  VALLETO's performances explore and convey deep feelings of the conscious and unconscious being through intense and continuous physical movement. The work collaborates along visual arts such as film, live electronic music and photography. It's mission is to inspire equality and create a platform for audiences to relate, experience and connect in a deeper way. VALLETO creates and uncovers significant meaning in each production.

On May 9th, our second production #VOIDS will premiere. It explores the root of a humans constant desire to fill an empty space within themselves. It revolves around the natural feeling of emptiness. Depicted in the theatrical and abstract performance, #VOIDS are the encounters that arise when attempting to fill an inner-soul void.  The show reflects abstract and sarcastic representation of behaviors that develop in different surroundings that involve money, fashion and unattainable relationships. The performance identifies the direct correlation between the unique language of ones soul and society's cultural confines.

If VALLETO receives support we will work towards making art available to a broader audience. VALLETO believes in diversity and aims to find new possibilities for dance theater. In order to develop the work, the company needs financial contribution, but with a sincere promise to generate a positive difference not only in the artistic world but the whole world. VALLETO will arise new and positive ways of thinking around art that will create opportunities all around the world.

As a company, we kindly ask for your contributions and love. Please support VALLETO on our IndieGgogo campaign. 

FROM THE BOTTOM OF OUR HEARTS THANK YOU SO MUCH!

VALLETO is fiscally sponsored by Unique Projects, Inc., a New York State not-for-profit 501(c)(3) organization administrated by Pentacle/DanceWorks, Inc.
story_txt: Valleto’s Artistic Director, Valeria Gonzalez, found herself while discovering her inner passion of establishing VALLETO. Many of her own dramatic, raw and inspiring cultural encounters in the artistic world led her to create what VALLETO truly consist of: a platform which inspires and unifies the art and dance community. VALLETO is a group of unique and culturally diverse dancers that create space for vulnerability, imagination and through movement a new impassioned form of art is uncovered. VALLETO is a New York-based emerging dance theater company led by Valeria Gonzalez.  VALLETO's performances explore and convey deep feelings of the conscious and unconscious being through intense and continuous physical movement. The work collaborates along visual arts such as film, live electronic music and photography. It's mission is to inspire equality and create a platform for audiences to relate, experience and connect in a deeper way. VALLETO creates and uncovers significant meaning in each production.On May 9th, our second production #VOIDS will premiere. It explores the root of a humans constant desire to fill an empty space within themselves. It revolves around the natural feeling of emptiness. Depicted in the theatrical and abstract performance, #VOIDS are the encounters that arise when attempting to fill an inner-soul void.  The show reflects abstract and sarcastic representation of behaviors that develop in different surroundings that involve money, fashion and unattainable relationships. The performance identifies the direct correlation between the unique language of ones soul and society's cultural confines.If VALLETO receives support we will work towards making art available to a broader audience. VALLETO believes in diversity and aims to find new possibilities for dance theater. In order to develop the work, the company needs financial contribution, but with a sincere promise to generate a positive difference not only in the artistic world but the whole world. VALLETO will arise new and positive ways of thinking around art that will create opportunities all around the world.As a company, we kindly ask for your contributions and love. Please support VALLETO on our IndieGgogo campaign. FROM THE BOTTOM OF OUR HEARTS THANK YOU SO MUCH!VALLETO is fiscally sponsored by Unique Projects, Inc., a New York State not-for-profit 501(c)(3) organization administrated by Pentacle/DanceWorks, Inc.

story:
Who we are

Paperwork was founded by Hayley Greggs, Nicole Morris and Briony Anderson in 2014; we’re a team of theatre-makers. United by our love for collecting interesting stories, we experiment with different performance styles and collaborate with local artists to discover the best way to tell them. We’re passionate about working with local, emerging talent to feed the fringe theatre scene in Liverpool, enabling it to thrive and grow. 

Above all, we want everyone to have a good night out. For anyone who thinks theatre is quite stuffy, worthy, or just not for them, we don’t see it that way. Through creating bold and playful theatre, we want everyone who attends our shows to experience a delightful and moving evening!

So how are we doing this? 

'How May I Direct Your Call…'  is a one night event which is formed of five site-specific street performances and a team of roaming performers, focusing on the great British icon that is the red telephone box. 

This event is free to the public, family friendly and accessible, meaning that as wide an audience as possible can enjoy it! However this does mean that we are unable to earn revenue to pay artists. And this is why we need you. 

As winners of the Awesome Fund March draw we have been able to pretty much cover our production costs already so our need is simply to enable us to pay our artists fairly for their time. 


What We Need & What You Get

The following budget of £780 will pay all the team for the 1 day event:

Actors fee £70 x 7 (the life and soul of the party, a brilliant bunch of men and women who bring our characters to life): £490

Roaming performers/ushers £30 x 3 (this small team will ensure people have our maps, know where to find us and are entertained between performance sites) = £90

Paperwork Team- 2 x Writers and 1 x Director fee (from page to stage, these ladies have been working tirelessly to get our show in the road!) : £200

We believe it is important to value the work of emerging artists and enable them to practice their craft whilst still being able to pay the rent! As such, if we do not meet our target, any funds we do raise will be shared between our performers as a thank you for all of their hard work.

As a thank you to you, we've come up with a selection of rather lovely rewards as a token of our appreciation (see perks).

The Impact is City Wide

Chit chat, Clark Kent, and calling your mum for a lift home: what springs to mind when we think of the telephone box?

How May I Direct Your Call? is formed of five site-specific street performances and a team of roaming performers. Focusing on the great British icon that is the red telephone box, 90 years after they were installed and 30 years since BT abandoned the design, this performance celebrates the city’s connection with the famous boxes and their designer Sir Giles Gilbert Scott.

The audience can pick up a map of our performance sites on the evening or can download a copy in advance, and will follow the map to discover our actors - the mini-plays can be seen in any order, and the audience can move between them at their own pace.

In addition to the live performance, we will collate recordings by asking the Liverpool community (and beyond!) to call us up and leave us a voice mail telling us about their most important telephone conversations throughout the ages; these stories will form the basis of an audio installation which we hope to house at the Liverpool’s Anglican Cathedral, along with Sir Giles Gilbert Scott (well, a very convincing actor!). This will run in conjunction with the street performances, and be shared on-line after the event to create a digital legacy.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't be involved!

We'd love it if you can come and see our production, tell all your friends about it too to make it a fantastic night!

You can find us 5-8pm on Friday 15th May in Liverpool City Centre, in a red telephone box. 

We'll also soon be posting on our website how to get involved in our audio installation where we are asking members of the public to leave us a voicemail telling us 'what was your most important call?'

Please share our campaign with your friends and followers to help us reach our goal! Thank you, Nicole, Hayley and Briony - Paperwork Theatre

story:
Short Summary

The Penguinz are a University Level team from Colorado competing in a program known as Destination Imagination (DI). 

DI involves young kids and adults from Kindergarten to University level, and has teams of students create a solution to one of 7 given challenges. Each challenge has a specific focus, such as theater arts or engineering, and teams present their solution to a panel of judges, competing against other teams in their area for a chance to advance to the State and Global Level.

We are competing in the Structural Challenge this year, Lose to Win, and are the first University Level Team from or Region. We have been working for weeks on our solution, and will continue to do so until Global Finals in Knoxville, Tennessee, on May 20th.

By funding us, you are encouraging our creative new take on the standard play format teams have been using for years, and instead using a combination of music and engineering to create an intense sound and sight display utilizing our custom song score and microprocessor controlled LED lights to make a story unlike anything DI has ever seen before.

But we need YOUR HELP to get there.

What We Need To Compete

There are many expenses to funding a Global Finals Trip. Currently, all of this money will have to come out of our own pocket, and with all of us being full-time students and having part-time jobs, this expense can be very difficult to finance. Listed below are all of the expenses we will need to pay for our trip, in order of priority:

Room and Board: $750 per person = $3000

Plane Ticket from Denver to Nashville: 

$300 per person = $1200

Prop Shipment: $300

Bus from Nashville to Knoxville: $85 per person = $340

Pins: $250 per person = $1000

Opening and Closing Colorado T-shirts:

 $40 per person = $160


Total= $6000


The Impact

Our goal as a University Level Team has always been to promote DI and show children and young adults in the program how far their knowledge and creativity can take them.  We do this first hand by showing them what we have done personally through competing, and encouraging them that eventually they will be able to create the same incredible things as we do, if not better. 

By supporting our campaign, you're allowing us to reach out to more people in the program, as well as giving us the chance to relive memories we made competing at Global Finals during our Elementary, Middle and High school years.

Perks: 


$5 - Warm Fuzzy Feeling 

Donate $5 and you'll instantly obtain a warm, fuzzy feeling inside!

$20 - Personalized Thank You Letter

We will send you a personalized letter in the mail telling you how awesome and amazing you are!

In addition, you will receive these previous perks:

+ Warm Fuzzy Feeling


$50 - Adélie Bundle

Named after one of the smallest Penguins, the Adélie (Add-uh-lee) Bundle is the small but important first step in sponsorship, and is perfect for helping out while not straining the wallet.

For this perk, we will create a personalized video thanking you for your contribution and telling you what your money was spent on. We will send it to you on a CD and post it on our Facebook page!

In addition, you will receive these previous Perks:

+ Warm Fuzzy Feeling

+ Personalized Thank You Letter


$75 - Magellanic Bundle

Named after the Magellanic (ma-jə-ˈla-nik) Penguin, which was in turn named after the explorer Ferdinand Magellan, this Perk is for the thinker in the group, always interested in gaining more knowledge.

For this Perk, we will send you paper copies of all of our prop designs, created using Autocad!

In addition, you will receive these previous Perks:

+ Warm Fuzzy Feeling

+ Adélie Bundle


$90 - Humboldt Bundle

Named after the Humboldt Penguin, this Perk is for the music or art lover  and anyone who wants to see exactly what all the hype is about.

For this Perk, you will receive an audio copy of our original song score used in the play as well as a recording of our performance at Global Finals! (on a CD)

In addition, you will receive these previous Perks:

+ Warm Fuzzy Feeling

+ Adélie Bundle


$130 - Chinstrap Bundle


Named after the Chinstrap Penguin of the South Sandwich Isles, this Perk is for the adventurous and creative one's, living for those unexpected results or outcomes.

For this Perk, we will run a song of your choice through the LED strips on our set, which take an audio input and flash to the beat, and send you the video of what it looks like! 

Note: Please keep songs choices below 10 minutes in length.

In addition, you will receive these previous Perks:

+ Warm Fuzzy Feeling

+ Adélie Bundle


$150 - Rockhopper Bundle


Bearing the name of the most  flamboyant of the Penguins, the Rockhopper Penguin, this Perk is for those who like a little bling and pazazz in their lives.

For this Perk, we will send you a set of our Global Finals trading Pins! Show them off to your friends and family and make them jealous of your philanthropy.

In addition, you will receive these previous Perks:

+ Warm Fuzzy Feeling

+ Adélie Bundle


$200 - Emperor Bundle

Just like the Emperor Penguin it is named after, this Perk is the largest of them all! You will receive all the previous bundles and perks, which means you get:

+ Adélie Bundle

+ Magellanic Bundle

+ Humboldt Bundle

+ Chinstrap Bundle

+ Rockhopper Bundle


Other Ways You Can Help 

Even if you are unable to donate to the trip, there are many other ways you can help the Penguinz! We can always use more support on our Facebook page, but what we're really looking for is support for DI everywhere. 

Support local teams in your area, volunteer at a competition or manage a team. DI is a program that every child deserves a chance to participate in. 

To further this goal, if you are in the Colorado area and would like the Penguinz to present to your team our affiliate competition, contact us! We are always looking for opportunities to talk to people involved in DI.

story:
Rise of the Scorpion Seductress

By: Cristina McLaughlin

A woman bereft of power or influence dares to use her feminine wiles to seduce the most powerful men in Ancient Egypt transforming her from a slave into the queen she knew in her heart she was always meant to be.  Her new position swaths her in comfort and luxury but her resolve is shaken witnessing the brutal practice of female sacrifice.  Ultimately, she will risk all she has gained to stand in solidarity with her fellow women ...even if the cost could be her life.


How did it all begin?

In July of 2014 I met Betty (my producer); she was a self-made entrepreneur experienced in producing small scale events in her Manhattan loft with a vision of breaking into the theatre world.  I was a high school English/Drama teacher with a passion for writing ...and no money.  After discovering our mutual love for the arts, we decided to meet and discuss the possibility of starting a project together.  A few days later, armed with my trusty padfolio, I presented my ideas.  Impressed, Betty offered her venue if I was able to provide the script. 

Over the next few weeks when I wasn’t furiously writing, Betty and I were constructing our plan.  By summer’s end, we had a team of people who could make the play a reality and a finished script.  Together with Irmingard, our artistic director, we began casting and preparing for a “teaser” production of Act One. 

After weeks of rehearsal we successfully performed to our first audience of 60 people.  The show was a resounding success, but our progress was halted when we realized that the venue was not sufficient to provide the capacity needed for a full production show.



What is the inspiration?

Primarily, this is a story about female sexual exploration.  In spite of reading a prolific amount of noteworthy feminist literature, I never read about a sexually liberated woman that was a champion of other women.  In literature (and life) women are punished or isolated when they are too “free” with their bodies.  I wanted to challenge that notion in a profound and believable way.  Achieving that paved the way for the acrobatic element of the show which makes this visually tantalizing. The experience of a voyeur is created as spectators are immersed in a sexually charged environment.  Our cast has elevated the production to a theatrical masterpiece expressing the story through extraordinary feats of lyra, pole dancing and ariel net.

However, in many ways the story is inspired by my own personal  journey.  I was a victim of child abuse, and although everyone in my family, school and community knew about it, nothing was done.  My protagonist is the woman I use to dream would come, see the injustice of my suffering and rescue me.  Her character has been developed and refined since her original conception, but the vividness of her spirit remains.  She encapsulates how the best parts of our character are drawn into the light when we stand together to fight injustice. 


Why is this project important?

To sum it up in 2 words: female empowerment.  Although women have made extraordinary strides in the pursuit of equality and liberation, socially we are still very much repressed.  Women are still shamed and judged if we use our sexuality with the same brazen attitude as men.  Worse, women are sometimes our own worst enemies; we will callously label women as “whores,” and use that condemnation as a means to mock other women when they are victimized, or to remain resolute in our apathy.  This show challenges women to raise one another up, see how we’re alike in our struggles, and how powerful we can become when unified. 

A testament to that possibility is the project itself.  Since all of the creators of this project are women from very different walks of life who came together to create this unique show.  Proving the adage, that life imitates art.


Who is also involved in creating this project?

Betty Tricoche is a spectacular woman who generously invested her space for our performers, created an original score to accompany the script, purchased originally designed costumes, rented all the equipment for our performances, and hired photographers and videographers to create our promotional video, and the audio visual crew who worked our initial event.  This play is my brain child, but Betty is the heart and soul of this project.  She has an unrelenting passion for its success and is uncompromising about her high standards.  She willingly invested her own personal money to get the show off the ground, but being only one person could only take it so far.  While I personally feel uncomfortable asking for money, it is for Betty most of all that I am fundraising.

Irmingard Mayer - Betty introduced me to this incredibly talented woman who has electrified the stage with her brilliant insight on performance.  Although already a successful competitive pole dance and teacher at Body & Pole and Crunch Gym, she invested her time for free to give us entrance into the elite world of performance.  Irmingard is a professional pole dancer and aerialist with six years experience, and the 2014 Northeast Aerial Art Champion. In addition to her impressive resume, Irmingard is highly efficient, productive, organized and reliable at guiding us through the professional world of theatre.  Her invaluable leadership gives us the confidence that this venture will be a success.


What will we use the money for?

Although so many have donated their talents, skills and time to help get the production off the ground, they are reluctant to work for free indefinitely (surprise!). 

We need money to:

·  Pay the performers and our Artistic Director

·  Insurance

·  Materials for set design

·  Renting the A/V equipment needed for the nights of the performances

·  Production costs for printing programs and posters

·  Paying the makeup artists, body painter, and costume designer

· Rental costs necessary for the performances and rehearsal

· Development of Scorpion Theater Project's logo, merchandise, and website for purposes of branding



Scorpion Theater Project is the production company that emerged specifically to get this show off the ground. However, we anticipate funding more plays and performances in the future.

stage with her brilliant insight on performance.  Although already a successful competitive
pole dance and teacher at Body & Pole and Crunch Gym, she invested her time for free to give us entrance into
the elite world of performance.  Irmingard is a professional pole dancer and aerialist with six years experience, and the 2014 Northeast Aerial Art Champion. In addition to her impressive resume, Irmingard is highly efficient, productive, organized and reliable at guiding us through the professional world of theatre.  Her invaluable leadership gives us the confidence that this venture will be a success.
What will we use the
money for?
Although so many have donated their talents, skills and time
to help get the production off the ground, they are reluctant to work for free
indefinitely (surprise!).  
We need money to: 
·  Pay the performers and our Artistic Director
· 
Insurance 
· 
Materials for set design
· 
Renting the A/V equipment needed for the nights
of the performances
· 
Production costs for printing programs and
posters
· 
Paying the makeup artists, body painter, and costume designer
· Rental costs necessary for the performances and rehearsal· Development of Scorpion Theater Project's logo, merchandise, and website for purposes of brandingScorpion Theater Project is the production company that emerged specifically to get this show off the ground. However, we anticipate funding more plays and performances in the future.

story:
• What's the what with RipCity Dance
  • Getting from there to here
  • 2015
  • 2016 and beyond
  • The bottom line
  • Sharing is caring
  • Shout outs
  • Perks

What's the what with RipCity Dance

RipCity Dance is a new dance and movement company in Seattle.  We offer classes for families and intergenerations of every size, color, gender and variety to take together.

We believe families who dance together have fun together, and build stronger communities.  The best experiences in life happen as we share between generations, in families, and with friends.  Dance and movement offer a unique opportunity for people to have fun, become more fit, learn new skills, communicate in new ways, and enjoy the experience of a shared community experience.

Getting from there to here

RipCity Dance is owned and operated by me, Steven Ripley.  Encouraged by my mom, Bobbie Stewart, since I was a child, I have worked in the arts as a playwright, author, stage manager, performer, and for the past four years, as a dancer.  My teachers have included Elia Mrak, Victoria Jacobs, David Zambrano, Elizabeth Davis-Thomas, Brian Bucsit, Irene Lyon and Nancy Lopez Luna, practicing qigong and yoga, Flying Low and Passing Through techniques, hip hop and breakdance, and the beauty and whimsicality of going slow to explore and engage somatic awareness.

I also worked for 18 years for the City of Seattle as a web designer and developer, and an emergency first responder during citywide emergencies.  I retired from the City in April 2015 to reboot and follow my dreams, dance, learn Spanish, and start RipCity Dance.

(RipCity is the nickname my coaches Elia and Brian gave me a few years back.  It stuck.)

As I integrated into the local dance community these past four years, I noted that while families definitely engage and grow together in many ways -- through sports, festivities, day-to-day, food, travel -- there are not a lot of opportunities for families to dance and move together, as families.  This is exciting new territory.

2015

RipCity Dance incorporated in June 2015.  This past summer we developed our business plan and start-up structure, and begun engaging teachers, families and communities.  In September, we offered our first two classes:

Family Funk, an intro to breakdance and hip-hop for everyone six years old and up, taught by Elia Mrak at the Martin Luther King Jr. F.A.M.E. Community Center in Madison Park, and co-produced by dance coach Chris Daigre.

Floor Families, a groovy modern dance and flow class geared for toddlers and kids in the 4-9 age range and their families.  Taught by Matt Drews, the class was offered at a Seattle dance hub, Velocity Dance Center, in Capitol Hill.

2016 and beyond

Our plans this fall and winter, and into 2016, are to continue engaging new teachers and producing new and continuing classes all around town.  Ultimately we'd like to open our own studio in a year or two.  Dream spots in Seattle for a studio include West Seattle and Georgetown.

Until then, to make the company strong and self-sufficient, we need to produce as many classes and workshops as we can.  Your donations will help us to engage teachers, find venues, and develop relationships and opportunities for classes and workshops with local schools and community centers.

Funds raised from this campaign will keep us moving on all these fronts in 2016.

The bottom line

Our campaign goal is $10,000.

Right now we pay our teachers a class rate of $100/hour, which is about 25% above the general market rate.  I don't believe in artists being broke all the time -- they should be paid fairly for their skills.

Venue rents vary.  Promotions and marketing are costly and necessary.  The company has several ongoing base rates to pay -- for merchant services, web site hosting, accounting and banking.

Donations for this campaign will give us a strong operating budget for 2016, and produce more classes.  The more we do, the closer we will focus onto our business plan of ongoing classes and financial self-sufficiency in a home space in town.

What are the risks?  Like all young companies, the big risk is running out of funds before we become self-sufficient.  If you can help now, you are helping us to grow and thrive.

Costs will no doubt multiply once we have a home base.  That comes later, I imagine in the fall of 2016 or in 2017.  For those costs, we will likely be back with a directed campaign for venue start-up support.  The reality is we will start making money after we are established and in a studio.

Until then, building a teacher roster and a community of participating families and friends is where your donation dollars will be spent, helping us go where we need to go.

Sharing is caring

We understand if you cannot contribute funds.  The other big way to help is to share our campaign, with your social media networks on Facebook and Twitter, with your email networks of friends and colleagues, or good old fashioned face to face in coffee shops, gyms, bus stops, book stores, dance classes, community centers, schools, work, and home.

Shout outs

Lots of folk have helped me along the way.  I thank you all.

  • Marissa and Erik Ciccarelli, for their amazing photography and videography.  Find out more about their work at Ciccarelli Photography.
  • Rebekah Jaramillo, for her creativity and vision, and our company and class logos.  See more of her work at Rebekah J Designs.
  • My beautiful mama, Bobbie Stewart.
  • My sisters, Debbie, Cathy and Cristina, and our family.
  • Elizabeth Davis-Thomas and Michael Thomas, their awesome daughters, and the whole West Seattle yoga gang.
  • Colleagues Victoria Jacobs, Chris Daigre and Matt Drews.
  • My accountant, Nina Israel.
  • My supportive buddies at Wells Fargo bank, Antonio, Brandon and Jordan.
  • The Seattle branch of the U.S. Small Business Association.
  • Steady amigos Ben and Blaine.
  • Tim, Danny, Sarah, Hannah, Andrew, Joe and Aidan at Analog Coffee.
  • The man, Brian Bucsit.
  • Elia Mrak and Nanzy Lopez Luna.  Abrazos.

Perks

My super-artistic family is going to get together to make thank you cards and bookmarks.  They are going to be unique and beautiful, our way of saying thanks for helping us out.

Through Zazzle, we will create and offer quality beverage mugs, tote bags, t-shirts and kid hoodies using our awesome company and class logos created by the super-talented Rebekah J. Designs.

Class perks will give you and your family a chance to participate in our Seattle classes in 2016.

Finally, my amazing sister Debbie McKesson is creating a custom decorative quilt based on photos from our classes -- unique and one of a kind.

And of course, web site and social media shout outs to everyone who can help.

Sample photos of perks:

story:
We're going back to Ireland (with your help)!

TOSOS, New York City's oldest professional LGBT theater company, in association with En Avant Playwrights, has been invited to go to the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival for the fourth time!

The company has been developing two new plays: Kathleen Warnock's "Julie Andrews is the Devil..." and Ed Valentine’s “Each to Each,” both of which will join a wonderful evening of short plays at the Cobalt Café in Dublin, opening May 9, 2016!

"Julie Andrews is the Devil"

Now there’s a provocative title! What can it possibly mean? You’ll find out when lesbian dycon folksinger Marissa crosses paths with Tabitha (formerly Sister Ruth) on Commercial Street in Provincetown during Women’s Week.

·  Directed by Ed Valentine

·  Starring Andrea Alton & Virginia Baeta

"Each to Each"

Who hasn’t heard the mermaids singing? Well Sister Ann, for one. The good sister, an older Irish nun, has been assigned to be the keeper of the newly-captured mermaid Cyrene. Sister Ann wants to hear the mermaid sing…Cyrene wants to return to the sea. Who will get her way?

·  Written & Directed by Ed Valentine

·  Starring Virginia Baeta & Elizabeth A. Bell

How you can help!

Your contribution of any amount will help fund the following:

·  Roundtrip airfare from NYC to Dublin for the company (the prices are great this year!)

·  The rental of a furnished flat (with kitchen and laundry!) in Dublin for us to rest our weary heads. And presumably cook and do laundry.

·  Postcards, posters and other PR/marketing essentials.

·  Transit passes for the company so we can get around the city.

·  A per diem for the hardest working team in NYC indie theater!

Other Ways You Can Help

Many of the people reading this are artists trying to get their own work on... sometimes you're just not able to contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

·  Share, post, tweet and otherwise spread the word about our campaign.

·  Send your Irish friends to the show!

·  Send us a kind word, and come to our invited dress rehearsal TBA…late April/early May!

story:
We need to see 'Rabbit' in Somerville, MA!

In this sensitive and controversial day in age, women are being challenged by the patriarchy every single day. Male bosses patronize female employees, cat calling is part of the female daily experience, and Republicans wish to deny women right to their own bodies- just to name a few. 'Rabbit' brings up the feminine lifestyle and challenges the patriarchy by showing them that women are just as smart, hard, and intelligent as men. With love, sensitivity, and wit, we can show a casual audience in a bar, that important issues can be part of casual conversation. Let's be forward thinking. Let's be progressive. Let's do a production of 'Rabbit' in Somerville, MA.

We need more immersive theater in this world, let's start with Somerville. Somerville has a large artistic population who would benefit to see the story told in 'Rabbit'. 

My name is Dani Berkowitz. I am a recent graduate of Emerson College (2015) and an Actor/Director in Boston. My directing credits include Through the Years (NJ), All Men Are Dogs (Emerson College), and Two Hot Summers (Brookline, MA). My recent acting credits include Six Degrees of Separation, True to Life Training, The Wakeville Stories, The Learned Ladies, and Anything to Declare?
Help me help society by supporting this important project!!

Why is this production of 'Rabbit' interesting?

Immersive theater is the best way to see a play. We are going to set 'Rabbit' in an actual bar, so patrons can enjoy the show with a cocktail in hand.  The juxtaposition of this feminist play taking place in a casual environment will help with our goal: To make these important issues part of everyday conversation.

What we need:

Rights to 'Rabbit': $450
Paying the Artists: $350
Costumes & Props: $200
Marketing: $150
Total Cost: $1,150

What is 'Rabbit' about?

"It's Bella's twenty-ninth birthday. Friends and former lovers meet for a drink to celebrate. But as the Bloody Marys flow, the bar becomes a battlefield. In the uncivil war between the sexes, what happens when the females have a real fire-power - stockpiles of testosterone, lethal wit and explosive attitude? And what happens when patriarchy gets personal, when it's your own father who is tragic and terminal? When the only man you really love is dying?"

Please help us bring this awesome story to life!!

story:
The Show

1969 New Orleans: it’s standing room only. The band starts the opening number for Miss Blanche, the hottest act in the Quarter -- but Miss Blanche is missing in action. Instead, a fiery young man takes the stage. Relaying tales from his brutal childhood, he reveals a mysterious trunk, filled with clues about his past and the key to his future. Inspired by the imagination of Tennessee Williams, this intimate and seductive show takes us on one man’s journey of desire, self-expression and liberation.

The Journey

Our team began developing Miss Blanche Tells It All in late 2015. What started as a creative game of “what If…” deepened into a daring piece of musical theatre that has a profound impact on audiences.  

We first developed the idea in a collaboration lab for alumni of Columbia’s MFA theatre program (CoCo Lab). From there, we committed to develop a full length musical.  After performing a section of the show last summer at Dixon Place’s HOT! Festival, we’ve been invited for a full production at the 2017 New York Musical Festival (NYMF).  We’re thrilled about NYMF’s excitement in the show, and we see this as a fantastic opportunity to attract producers who can help the show find its future professional production.   

Along the ride, we’ve picked up some amazing talent:  Brian Charles Rooney takes center stage as LEE and BLANCHE; Robert Frost leads the band.  Designers Philip Heckman (costumes) and Christopher Weston (lighting) are going to make this show look fabulous.

For now,  we are a small team of independent artists producing the show on our own.  Together, we have years of experience, ample talent, and endless passion for putting on one helluva show.  We’ve pledged to raise the $34,000 it will take to get Blanche to NYMF.  But we are relying on the kindness of strangers… not to mention friends and family … to help Blanche on her journey.

What It Takes

By producing a NYMF show, we’ve committed to a professional production. This means working with unions like Actors Equity and Musician’s Local, and hiring a staff of professional designers and managers to make Blanche look like a million bucks. Your support will help us pay a portion of our total budget, such as:

  • $6614 for Artistic Staff (lead performer, musicians, designers)  
  • $2100 Physical Production (costumes, props, set, etc.)
  • $3050 Publicity and Marketing
  • $4415 Management Team (General Manager, stage managers)
  • $1400 Rehearsal Studios and Music Copying  
  • $16,150  Administrative Costs (insurance, payroll taxes, fees)

Why Now, Blanche?

We believe Miss Blanche Tells It All has the potential to touch a wide audience, both in New York and beyond.

For most gay, lesbian, or transgender adults who came of age in America before the 1990s, growing up was a difficult, if not painful experience.  We grew up the world of “the closet”: in homes where we were unseen, misunderstood, or despised, in schools where we were teased and bullied, and in communities where we felt isolated and ostracized. Fortunately, it does get better for many of us.  Through great efforts we’ve won rights and respect. The incredible progress of the last 30 years allows most of us have to live out and proud today.

Still, millions of young LGBTQ people still face rejection from parents, bullying in schools, and scorn from their religious institutions.  And with Trump, Pence, and DeVos holding the reigns, there’s every reason to fear for the safety and rights of LGBTQ youth and adults. It’s never been more important to remember what gay life was like in the past, to honor the progress that we’ve made.


Miss Blanche... offers a historical look at gay life in the South in the mid-20th century and celebrates how queer people have used their imaginations to face oppression, create safe spaces, and build communities. The moving score draws on popular American music styles like jazz, country, blues, and rock, to explore how gender roles have been forced upon men and women alike.  Like Hedwig and the Angry Inch, the show immerses the audience in an exotic setting--a gay cabaret in New Orleans circa late 1960s-- and follows a central character through a transformative journey of healing and finding wholeness.  By looking at gay life in the past, the show challenges us to think about the world we want in the future.  

Why NYMF?

The New York Musical Festival nurtures the creation, production, and public presentation of stylistically, thematically, and culturally diverse new musicals to ensure the future vitality of musical theater.  In 13 years, NYMF has presented over 420 new musicals. Over 97 of them have gone on to further productions following NYMF. Beyond New York, NYMF shows have delighted theatergoers in all 50 states and 24 countries around the world!  4 NYMF shows have opened on Broadway: Chaplin, Next to Normal; [title of show]; and In Transit.  17 NYMF shows have had commercial Off-Broadway productions, and 14 shows have had not-for-profit Off Broadway productions.

Producing at NYMF will offer an opportunity for us to develop and showcase this powerful new American musical to professionals in the theatre industry who could help take the show all the way!

Other Ways You Can Help

Miss Blanche relies on the kindness of strangers, and there are lots of ways you can help: 

  • Share this IndieGogo campaign with others and encouraging them to support the project.
  • Join us on Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/MissBlancheTellsItAll/
  • Contact us if you’re interested in making a larger tax-deductible donation through NYMF.  All donations earmarked to Miss Blanche Tells It All will go to our show.
  • We also are offering special perks and programs for Business Sponsors.  Contact us to learn more.

About Us  

Jason Jacobs (Book and Lyrics)  has been named as a NYTheatre.com ‘‘Person of the Year.’’ He was formerly the co-artistic director of Theatre Askew, where he co-created and directed Bald Diva! and devised numerous projects with LGBTQA youth. He directed Lavender Songs (TOSOS II, Bistro Award), After the Chairs (2014 Fresh Fruit Festival, Best Direction Award) and Richard Sheinmel and Clay Zambo’s Modern Living series (LaMama Club). His play Another Horatio Alger Story was recently seen at Chicago’s Pride Film and Players Gay Play Fest. Regional productions at Vermont Stage Company and Kitchen Theatre. Member of Lincoln Center Theatre Directors Lab. www.Jason-Jacobs.com

Matthew C. Pritchard (Music and Lyrics) began his career as a boy soprano, studying at the Peabody Preparatory of Music and the Baltimore School for the Arts, followed by stints at Manhattan School of Music and New York University.  He's performed with the Baltimore Opera Company, the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and, for the Metropolitan Opera Guild/Kennedy Center he originated the title role in the workshop of Carly Simon's opera, Romulus Hunt.  He was lyricist/singer for Dutch rock outfit The Saturnine on their album The Winter Years. With songwriting partner Isam Rum he has provided original music and/or sound design for Bianca Leigh’s BUSTED: The Musical, I, Claudius Live and the GLAAD Award nominated productions of Bald Diva! & i google myself (all for Theatre Askew), The Abduction of Becky Morris & Coyote Katie (NY Fringe Festival), Home/Away & The F On My Chest (Theatre Askew Youth Performance Experience), Tim Cusack’s WHAT DID HE SEE? (ForemanFest) and Jason Jacobs’ Another Horatio Alger Story (The Cell).

Gisela Cardenas (Director and Developer) has directed in England, Germany, Peru, Romania, The Netherlands, Norway and USA. Awards: Princes Grace Fellowship, Phil Killian Directing Fellow (Oregon Shakespeare Festival), Women's Project Director’s Lab, TCG/ NEA Career Development Program, and member of SDC. She has an M.A in Performance Studies (NYU) and an M.F.A in Directing (Columbia University). Past credits: Shakespeare’s Macbeth, Aeschylus Agamemnon (Drama Desk Nomination); Antigone (Romania), Kander & Ebb's Kiss of The Spider Woman (Vortex Theater Company); Part 1 of An Oresteia (Classic Stage Company), Euripides' Medea, Brecht's Jungle of Cities, Richard III (Norway), Weskler's The Kitchen, and Fassbinder’s Katzelmaher. With InTandem Lab: Instructions To Decode A(n In)human Transformation, adapted from Kafka's Metamorphosis; Hybrid Suite No.2: The Carmen Variations a devised electronic Opera (HARP Program HERE Arts Center). Upcoming: An Isle Full of Noises, a sonic performance of The Tempest, and Sonata for a Heart, a devised play about organ transplantation.
story_txt:
The Show1969 New Orleans: it’s standing room only. The band starts the opening number for Miss Blanche, the hottest act in the Quarter -- but Miss Blanche is missing in action. Instead, a fiery young man takes the stage. Relaying tales from his brutal childhood, he reveals a mysterious trunk, filled with clues about his past and the key to his future. Inspired by the imagination of Tennessee Williams, this intimate and seductive show takes us on one man’s journey of desire, self-expression and liberation.The JourneyOur team began developing Miss Blanche Tells It All in late 2015. What started as a creative game of “what If…” deepened into a daring piece of musical theatre that has a profound impact on audiences.  We first developed the idea in a collaboration lab for alumni of Columbia’s MFA theatre program (CoCo Lab). From there, we committed to develop a full length musical.  After performing a section of the show last summer at Dixon Place’s HOT! Festival, we’ve been invited for a full production at the 2017 New York Musical Festival (NYMF).  We’re thrilled about NYMF’s excitement in the show, and we see this as a fantastic opportunity to attract producers who can help the show find its future professional production.   Along the ride, we’ve picked up some amazing talent:  Brian Charles Rooney takes center stage as LEE and BLANCHE; Robert Frost leads the band.  Designers Philip Heckman (costumes) and Christopher Weston (lighting) are going to make this show look fabulous.For now,  we are a small team of independent artists producing the show on our own.  Together, we have years of experience, ample talent, and endless passion for putting on one helluva show.  We’ve pledged to raise the $34,000 it will take to get Blanche to NYMF.  But we are relying on the kindness of strangers… not to mention friends and family … to help Blanche on her journey.What It TakesBy producing a NYMF show, we’ve committed to a professional production. This means working with unions like Actors Equity and Musician’s Local, and hiring a staff of professional designers and managers to make Blanche look like a million bucks. Your support will help us pay a portion of our total budget, such as:
$6614 for Artistic Staff (lead performer, musicians, designers)  
$2100 Physical Production (costumes, props, set, etc.)
$3050 Publicity and Marketing
$4415 Management Team (General Manager, stage managers)
$1400 Rehearsal Studios and Music Copying  
$16,150  Administrative Costs (insurance, payroll taxes, fees)
Why Now, Blanche?We believe Miss Blanche Tells It All has the potential to touch a wide audience, both in New York and beyond.For most gay, lesbian, or transgender adults who came of age in America before the 1990s, growing up was a difficult, if not painful experience.  We grew up the world of “the closet”: in homes where we were unseen, misunderstood, or despised, in schools where we were teased and bullied, and in communities where we felt isolated and ostracized. Fortunately, it does get better for many of us.  Through great efforts we’ve won rights and respect. The incredible progress of the last 30 years allows most of us have to live out and proud today.Still, millions of young LGBTQ people still face rejection from parents, bullying in schools, and scorn from their religious institutions.  And with Trump, Pence, and DeVos holding the reigns, there’s every reason to fear for the safety and rights of LGBTQ youth and adults. It’s never been more important to remember what gay life was like in the past, to honor the progress that we’ve made.Miss Blanche... offers a historical look at gay life in the South in the mid-20th century and celebrates how queer people have used their imaginations to face oppression, create safe spaces, and build communities. The moving score draws on popular American music styles like jazz, country, blues, and rock, to explore how gender roles have been forced upon men and women alike.  Like Hedwig and the Angry Inch, the show immerses the audience in an exotic setting--a gay cabaret in New Orleans circa late 1960s-- and follows a central character through a transformative journey of healing and finding wholeness.  By looking at gay life in the past, the show challenges us to think about the world we want in the future.  Why NYMF?The New York Musical Festival nurtures the creation, production, and public presentation of stylistically, thematically, and culturally diverse new musicals to ensure the future vitality of musical theater.  In 13 years, NYMF has presented over 420 new musicals. Over 97 of them have gone on to further productions following NYMF. Beyond New York, NYMF shows have delighted theatergoers in all 50 states and 24 countries around the world!  4 NYMF shows have opened on Broadway: Chaplin, Next to Normal; [title of show]; and In Transit.  17 NYMF shows have had commercial Off-Broadway productions, and 14 shows have had not-for-profit Off Broadway productions.Producing at NYMF will offer an opportunity for us to develop and showcase this powerful new American musical to professionals in the theatre industry who could help take the show all the way!Other Ways You Can HelpMiss Blanche relies on the kindness of strangers, and there are lots of ways you can help: 
Share this IndieGogo campaign with others and encouraging them to support the project.
Join us on Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/MissBlancheTellsItAll/

Contact us if you’re interested in making a larger tax-deductible donation through NYMF.  All donations earmarked to Miss Blanche Tells It All will go to our show.
We also are offering special perks and programs for Business Sponsors.  Contact us to learn more.
About Us  Jason Jacobs (Book and Lyrics)  has been named as a NYTheatre.com ‘‘Person of the Year.’’ He was formerly the co-artistic director of Theatre Askew, where he co-created and directed Bald Diva! and devised numerous projects with LGBTQA youth. He directed Lavender Songs (TOSOS II, Bistro Award), After the Chairs (2014 Fresh Fruit Festival, Best Direction Award) and Richard Sheinmel and Clay Zambo’s Modern Living series (LaMama Club). His play Another Horatio Alger Story was recently seen at Chicago’s Pride Film and Players Gay Play Fest. Regional productions at Vermont Stage Company and Kitchen Theatre. Member of Lincoln Center Theatre Directors Lab. www.Jason-Jacobs.comMatthew C. Pritchard (Music and Lyrics) began his career as a boy soprano, studying at the Peabody Preparatory of Music and the Baltimore School for the Arts, followed by stints at Manhattan School of Music and New York University.  He's performed with the Baltimore Opera Company, the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and, for the Metropolitan Opera Guild/Kennedy Center he originated the title role in the workshop of Carly Simon's opera, Romulus Hunt.  He was lyricist/singer for Dutch rock outfit The Saturnine on their album The Winter Years. With songwriting partner Isam Rum he has provided original music and/or sound design for Bianca Leigh’s BUSTED: The Musical, I, Claudius Live and the GLAAD Award nominated productions of Bald Diva! & i google myself (all for Theatre Askew), The Abduction of Becky Morris & Coyote Katie (NY Fringe Festival), Home/Away & The F On My Chest (Theatre Askew Youth Performance Experience), Tim Cusack’s WHAT DID HE SEE? (ForemanFest) and Jason Jacobs’ Another Horatio Alger Story (The Cell).Gisela Cardenas (Director and Developer) has directed in England, Germany, Peru, Romania, The Netherlands, Norway and USA. Awards: Princes Grace Fellowship, Phil Killian Directing Fellow (Oregon Shakespeare Festival), Women's Project Director’s Lab, TCG/ NEA Career Development Program, and member of SDC. She has an M.A in Performance Studies (NYU) and an M.F.A in Directing (Columbia University). Past credits: Shakespeare’s Macbeth, Aeschylus Agamemnon (Drama Desk Nomination); Antigone (Romania), Kander & Ebb's Kiss of The Spider Woman (Vortex Theater Company); Part 1 of An Oresteia (Classic Stage Company), Euripides' Medea, Brecht's Jungle of Cities, Richard III (Norway), Weskler's The Kitchen, and Fassbinder’s Katzelmaher. With InTandem Lab: Instructions To Decode A(n In)human Transformation, adapted from Kafka's Metamorphosis; Hybrid Suite No.2: The Carmen Variations a devised electronic Opera (HARP Program HERE Arts Center). Upcoming: An Isle Full of Noises, a sonic performance of The Tempest, and Sonata for a Heart, a devised play about organ transplantation.

story:
WHY WE NEED YOU

(We promise we haven’t spent all the money on hiring male escorts...)

We have been given a four-night run of FIVE CARD STUD at the Lantern Theatre as part of the Brighton Fringe Festival and have raised a significant amount of funding needed through investment and generous donations.

However, we do not have the facilities to hire out our team as one might ‘company’, so we still have a little more to raise! We want to ensure the production is the highest quality and reaches our identified audiences; to raise the profile of our talented artists and raise awareness of the three core themes in FIVE CARD STUD – preconceptions on gender and the LGBTQ community, stigma against sex workers, and the unspoken often crippling loneliness in the middle-aged.

The £1,600 we are asking you for will be paid towards the travel and accommodation of the team to and from Brighton, some design elements of the show and increasing our marketing materials to get press coverage and ensure reviewers attend the show, reach our target audiences and help with our long-term goal of an extended production.

 

THE IMPACT

This play has been developed over a long period of time with a wealth of wonderful people and organisations, and it would mean the world to have your support in helping us finally present this play in the professional, full-length run it deserves.

In a time when sex is literally at our fingertips with modern social/dating/hook up apps, it seems to be becoming harder to find meaning when meeting someone. What is even more astounding though is the fact that sex can be had at the push of a button, yet there is still such a varied opinion on the issues we are addressing. Our research indicates that both older gay men and straight women alike find it difficult to embrace their sexuality in such a hands-on era, but even worse, they are judged for their actions when they do.

Furthermore, the stigma toward sex workers of both genders is palpable. To quote the play’s feature escort Ace, “It’s something everyone has an opinion yet doesn’t really know much about”. Charity National Ugly Mugs are fighting stigma and saving lives, providing greater access to justice and protection for sex workers who are often targeted by dangerous individuals, working to advocate the human rights of this discriminated group and keep them safe. We as a team fully support the work of this organisation and are honoured to be helping spread the word and raising awareness on their behalf.
 

ABOUT THE PLAY

For a male escort, if the clients are play nice, it  can be a pretty sweet deal. Problem is, Elliot doesn't always play nice…

Elliot was once the employer of marketing intern Alex. Alex has since gone on to become Ace, a male escort in high demand.  High above the city in a swanky flat, what service will the Five Card Stud be expected to perform when confronted by his past?

Join Ace and Elliot’s evening as it unfolds in two different ways; one where Elliot is an older male client, one where she is female. As the audience become silent voyeurs in the room at close quarters with the two couples, they are asked to consider what difference gender makes to the transaction; what can and cannot be said between the sexes when sex is on the table.

 

OUR SEXY TEAM

RWF Howard - Author

Geoffrey Williams - Director

Emma O’Mara - Producer

 

Cast soon to be announced.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you can’t give financially but still want to support us, or if you would like to do both, please spread the word of our #FiveCardCampaign on social media, email, or good old fashioned word of mouth. And maybe most importantly, come down to Brighton to see the show and support us in person!

 

For more information please go to:

Twitter: @FiveCardStud1
