story:
The Show

Tartuffe, a wily con man who passes himself off as a pious puritan, has insinuated himself  into the household  of Orgon, a wealthy Parisian. The impostor has designs on his benefactor's fortune, and his attractive wife. Members of the family are exasperated, then outraged, by Tartuffe's malign influence, as he plots to gain control of Orgon's assets, disinherit his son, marry his daughter and take over his house – as well as his mind.

The script updates Moliere's language without losing his incisive wit. In this farcical face-off between love and greed, credulity and cynicism, we've added a framing device that parallels the crisis within the play, leading to a surprise climax.

The tuneful score, as you can hear in our two-minute video preview, likewise reflects both the play's period and our own. Listeners have likened it to A Little Night Music and Candide.

The Production

Tar2f! will premiere in April 2018 on Silverthorne Theater Company’s home stage in the Hawks & Reed Performing Arts Center, Greenfield, Mass. The fully professional production (which means: everyone gets paid) will employ ten actor/singers, three or four musicians, an experienced creative team, and a skilled technical crew. We will draw from the deep pool of Valley-based pros, including members of Actors Equity.

The production won’t be lavish – we’re making economies wherever possible – but it won’t be cheap. Silverthorne’s usual production budget will cover less than half of this show’s costs. That’s where you come in. Your contribution, in whatever amount, will help us not only get Tar2f! on the boards, but mount it to the standard it deserves.

Exactly what will we do with your tax-deductible donation? We'll  pay our actors ($7,400) and musicians ($2,000). We'll hire a director, arranger, musical director, choreographer, technical director and stage manager ($5,300). We'll pay for rehearsal and performance space ($5,500). We'll build a set and create costumes ($1,260). We'll advertise ($1,000). We'll sell tickets and solicit sponsorships, but we need an additional $10,000 to bring Tar2f! to life.  

The Cast

We haven’t quite finished casting, but here’s a sneak peek at the company so far. We're excited to be working with these talented artists:

Peter Ludwig* as Tartuffe
Myka Plunkett as Elmire
Sam Samuels* as Orgon
Linda Tardif as Dorine
Rich Vaden as Damis
Grace Olmsted as Mariane
Louise Krieger as Mme Pernelle
Steven Williams as Valère

* Member of Actors Equity

Who We Are

Jeff Olmsted (Composer/lyricist) has been imagining Tartuffe as a musical for a long time. He was for many years musical director of the award-winning Shadowbox Theatre in New York City, where he was also founder and director of the Interfaith Fellowship Choir. His Songs of Rumi, for chamber orchestra and chorus, was premiered by the Dayton Philharmonic Orchestra. He recently moved back to his hometown of Northampton, Mass., where he directs the Valley Jazz Voices, the Haydenville Congregational Church Choir and two a cappella groups, the Wise Guys and On That Note. The first reading of Tar2f! was sponsored by the Cincinnati Playwrights Initiative.

Silverthorne Theater Company is an independent nonprofit professional theater organization, founded in 2014 and named by one critic as the area’s “newest and most adventurous” theater. We are committed to providing opportunities for meaningful paid work to local and regional theater artists; producing new and established works that focus on the human condition and bring unheard voices to the stage; and making meaningful contributions to the cultural life and economic vitality of the Pioneer Valley region of Western Massachusetts. Silverthorne is the resident company at the Hawks & Reed Performing Arts Center in Greenfield, Mass.

Lucinda Kidder (Producer) is Silverthorne’s Managing Director. She holds an MFA in Theater from UMass Amherst and an MA from Emerson College. High points of her 40-year career include directing over 150 productions, producing a festival of plays by women from Islamic cultures in New York City, founding five different theater companies in various cities, and creating a Shakespeare-based theater-intensive program for English language learner middle-school students.

Chris Rohmann (Director) has staged over 40 plays and musicals with numerous area theaters, including the Majestic Theater, New Century Theatre, Old Deerfield Productions, Hampshire Shakespeare Company, Valley Light Opera, and Silverthorne Theater Company, where he directed Jacques Brel is Alive and Well and Living in Paris last season, as well as 12 innovative productions at the Pioneer Valley Performing Arts Charter School. Chris is the theater critic for the Valley Advocate, where his Stagestruck column was named one of the paper’s most popular features in a readers’ poll. He’s also a book author, freelance editor, grant writer and voice-over artist, and has produced several albums of original songs.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not you’re able to contribute toward our dollar goal, you can help. Here are some ways: Get the word out to your email lists and social networks, and make some noise about the show and our campaign, use the Indiegogo share tools or volunteer at the show.

Thank you!

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you!

story:
Who We Are

Route 66 Theatre Company is a storefront theatre that brings together high-quality production values and top Equity talent to perform World and Chicago premieres in intimate theatre setting. Route 66 is also the only theatre company in town that involves its patrons in their season selection process with its Driver’s Seat Monthly Reading Series. Founded in 2008, Route 66’s mission is to produce plays, concerts and musicals for the stage that embrace the American spirit of risk, exploration, and fearlessness.

What We're Doing

Since our inception, Route 66 has operated with the philosophy that producing shows of quality, with compelling stories and artists that can connect with audiences, is the most important thing. This means that sometimes, work we believe in and work that resonates with patrons doesn’t always make the front page, and we try our hardest to make up the difference in ticket sales with other fundraising efforts.

We are at a place where our fall show, A FUNNY THING HAPPENED ON THE WAY TO THE GYNECOLOGIC ONCOLOGY UNIT AT MEMORIAL SLOAN-KETTERING CANCER CENTER OF NEW YORK CITY, needs an extra push to be produced. This dark comedy is poignant, engaging, and a story that we’re excited to tell, but it will be a taller mountain to climb without the help of our backers.

Why your Help Matters:

  • Productions are expensive. In order to adequately pay our talented actors and production staff, we are looking to raise $5,000 for FUNNY THING. Why this show and why now?

    • Tickets sales only cover a third of our costs - that's a lot of corners to cut!

    • Illinois budget cuts for the arts and arts funding means that projected funds for this show are not what we planned for - donations are imperative to make up this deficit.

    • We want to realize our commitments to our partners and this show, such as paying people on time, making good on other financial commitments. Your contribution ensures we can do that without making late payments. 

      We need your money to make sure that happens.  Our show is opening soon and we want to secure a successful run.

  • Supporters will receive special notes from the cast and crew, signed scripts, tickets to shows, and the opportunity to connect with our cast and director one on one. We want to produce this show because we are drawn to the story, to its raw exploration of human emotion and the way we connect with one another. As such, we will offer our supporters multiple opportunities to interact with us in real life!

Risks & Challenges

  • We believe in this show and its power, and are confident that ticket sales will reflect that. But to get to the point where we’re packing the house and sharing this story with more people than we could have hoped for, donor support is paramount to our success. Without this funding, we risk delayed payments to our artists, to our venue, and fewer shows - which means fewer chances to show this story to our city.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know money can be tight for some. If so, you can still help us out!

  • Tell your friends! Encourage them to check us out and see if they can donate. We would be your friends forever.
  • Share with Indiegogo share tools! Not only will it increase awareness among our friends and supporters, but will help us reach other supporters who may not know about Route 66 and what we do

Thank you for your assistance in bringing this great show to Chicago! Route 66 Theatre Company is a registered 501(c)(3) organization. Any donations are tax deductible minus the cost of material goods (ie show tickets). All donations will be acknowledged by tax receipt from Route 66.

story:
WHO WE ARE

Under the leadership of Artistic Director Nick Zappetti one19 Productions is a new theatre company with the motivation to champion the tradition of daring independent theater for the City of New York. In a creative and professional environment One19 Productions provides an artistically fulfilling outlet for actors, directors and all respective fields of theatre art. Our goal is to produce one act plays, staged readings, full length plays--including contemporary, classical, Shakespearean and experimental; cabarets, musicals reviews, concert version and full musical productions. 

 

 

WHY HOROVITZ?

Our first production will be a combination of two Israel Horovitz one-acts: 'The Indian Wants The Bronx' and 'Beirut Rocks' performed  in one program titled 'A Night Of Horovitz'. 

As a company, we feel that it is important to reflect modern day society through theatre. These pieces explore how fear and rage poison the human experience through cultural ignorance and narcissism. 

 

THE INDIAN WANTS THE BRONX

An East Indian gets lost on his first day in New York as two teenage punks find him waiting at a lonely bus stop. He cannot understand English, and the boys have some fun with him – at least it starts out as fun. But little by little, they get bored; then annoyed; then vicious. It is the very pointlessness of their brutality that makes this play so disturbing.

 

BEIRUT ROCKS

Four American college students; Benjy, a Jewish boy from the Bronx studying at Middlebury College, Jake, a Harvard student, Sandy, studying at Stanford and Nasa, a Palestinian girl studying English at Cambridge, seek refuge from the 2006 July War in a hotel acting as a safe house. It doesn't take long for the students to realize the hatred that fuels the conflict outside exist within themselves and tensions reach a fevered pitched. 

 

 

 

 

 

WHAT DO WE NEED?

Our goal is to raise $5000. We are well on our way to producing an incredible show. The venue has been secured at The Secret Theatre. Performance dates will be October 19th-22nd. The shows have been cast with some amazing talent including Gregory Kowlessar, please check out his youtube channel https://www.youtube.com/GregoryKowlessar
Rehearsal spaces are booked. But we still need some help. You’re generous donation, no matter how big or small will be put solely towards the following:

  • Promotional material
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Venue Space
  • Costume/Props/Set
  • Lighting/Sound
  • Continuing to produce further show

 

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you can’t support us financially at this time we completely understand. As artists, we are all too familiar with the struggle but there are other ways you can help.

We are always looking for people to volunteer their time during production week. We’re in need of ushers at each performance and others to help at our concessions area. Please email 119productionsny@gmail.com if you’d like to join us!


If you are on social media, please share this page and check out our Facebook and Instagram @one19productions. Soon we will be launching our own website. Not only do we say thank you but also take strength from you support.

 

A very big  

THANK YOU

from Nick and everyone at one19 Productions

story:
Who are we?

BUMP&GRIND are a recently established, Dublin-based theatre company who devise, produce and perform invigorating and provocative theatre. We met in UCD in the wonderful UCD Dramsoc where we first started working together. We are comprised of performers, makers, directors, producers and designers and Bump will be our first venture with a performance overseas. The crew behind Bump is made up of Rosa Bowden, Cathal Sheerin, Rosa Torr, Ailish Toal, Shane Gill and Kelley Gissane.

About Bump

Lily is 23, young, free and single and waiting for her life to start, but she's hit a bump. Bump is a tale of some of the awkward encounters and nauseating moments that make up a girl’s life. Meet Lily and hear her story as she confronts her choices in the waiting room of an abortion clinic. Bump is a visceral and fast paced one-woman show exploring the journey of childhood to womanhood.

Why Is It Important?

Abortion in Ireland is illegal unless it occurs as the result of a medical intervention performed to save the life of the mother. It is prohibited by both the constitutional protection of the right to life of the unborn and by legislation. Twelve women a day travel from Ireland to the UK to have an abortion. Bump presents the audience with the opportunity to hear the story of a woman who has decided to have an abortion. A woman who is from the UK. A woman who will not face any legal consequences for her decision. A woman who does not take this decision lightly. Bump introduces us to Lily as she openly relives with us all the awkward encounters that go along with growing up as a young girl, a teenager and a young adult. It is important to us to present Lily's story without the politics of an Irish setting and to give the audience this chance to get to know Lily and empathise with her position. Personal accounts are of vital importance within this debate. The reason so many Irish people are campaigning to repeal the eighth amendment is because they believe they deserve a choice. Bump presents us with an unflinching personal account so that we, the audience, can see a detailed account of a person in this situation rather than a statistic.

The Impact

Taking a show to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival is a big financial risk. There are over 3000 performances staged at the festival annually and we will be up against big competition to have our show seen and ensure Lily's story reaches as many people as possible. So why Edinburgh? We want to take Bump to an international stage to further highlight the debate that is currently happening in Ireland. We want to have this discussion, which is not a uniquely Irish one, but a global one, with a global audience. As well as attracting a huge number of shows, Edinburgh attracts the largest and most diverse audience of any Fringe Festival in the world, and that is where Lily's story belongs. Performing at the festival can also open up opportunities to tour our show internationally, earn some development funding for the future, and of course, win awards! None of this is possible without every generous donation, however big or small.

What We Need & What You Get

We need €8,000 to contribute towards a variety of costs that come along with our wonderful slot in the Assembly Festival. To date, we have fundraised to contribute to costs we have incurred at this stage in the production process and will continue to fundraise after this campaign too. The physical production values of the show are minimal as Bump is all about Lily, not about spectacle, and the show needs to travel easily and cost-effectively. An extra poster can equate to an extra ten lovely people (or ten nasty people, we'll take either) coming to enjoy our hard work and labour of love. The costs are broken down as follows..

  1. Venue Costs: We have been programmed by the Assembly Festival, one of the big four venues at the Edinburgh Fringe, and we couldn't be happier! The Assembly Festival is famous for presenting the work of young emerging international artists every year. That must be us?! But of course the venue require a guarantee, insurance and some more stuff we won't bore you with in order to be able to programme such a fantastic festival.
  2. Accommodation: We (the cast and crew) will be residing in Edinburgh for the entire month of August and that costs a pretty Great British Pound plus all the pennies down the side of your couch.
  3. Travel: We gotta get there to put on the show! Boarding passes and bus tickets will be required to get us from Ireland to Edinburgh and on to conquering the world.
  4. Promotional & Marketing Material: So, we've done steps 1, 2 and 3. We've made it to Edinburgh, dropped the stuff of at our flat, arrived at the venue and no-one's there to see the show. Nope. That simply won't do. If a tree falls in the wood and nobody hears it, did it really fall? Many smart academic-type people ask the same of theatre. If there is no audience, can you even call it theatre? We don't want to be on the other end of that question. Press assistance, flyers, posters, advertising and more are essential to make sure Bump is a hit.

Perks

We recognise that your donation is a charitable one but it is with insurmountable faith in our project that we have undertaken this journey and that is why we are asking you to join us, your support means so very much to the success of this production! Therefore, although we can't offer you millions if the show is a big hit (if it is, we will hopefully all arrive home in only a small amount of debt each), we can offer you some lovely perks to show you how much we care.

These include (but are not limited to):

  • A friendship like no other (check it out below).
  • Tickets to our upcoming super-secret fundraising party.
  • Tickets to our previews in London and Dublin.
  • Home-made Pom Pom accessories by our very own performers (earrings, keyrings).
  • Lots of incredibly grateful mentions on our social media and any other opportunity we get to thank you.
  • Regular updates on Bump as it develops and during production.
  • You could be Beyoncé. *

*only as true as your imagination makes it.

If we don't reach our entire goal, that would be unfortunate. However, Bump is currently being sold online at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival website so there is no turning back! The funds we gratefully accept from this campaign, if we are not successful in reaching our goal, will go mostly towards venue rental and accommodation as the most expensive elements of this travelling production. We will continue to fundraise and seek financial support elsewhere right up until when we land in Edinburgh to help contribute towards our other costs, and we will of course be saving and contributing our own money towards the production.

Risks & Challenges

Performing a show at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival is notoriously risky and comes rife with challenge after challenge. We've decided to do it as we believe we are prepared for this level of risk so let us make it clear.

We are at risk of running up personal debts while in Edinburgh, even if we make our campaign target and our other fundraising targets. If you google "Putting On A Show at the Edinburgh Fringe", we can guarantee that within three clicks, you'll have read at least three instances of people expressing, "Even if your show sells out you could make a loss." In fact, check out the Fringe budgeting and finance guide here and you should find that information very quickly. So one can imagine how awry things might go if we arrive having not met this target!

The biggest challenges of the Fringe are getting people to come and see your show. "Of course! There's loads of shows on! How will Bump stand out amongst thousands?", you’re thinking and, "Why? There are thousands of people there to see theatre and comedy? Surely they will want to see Bump?". The thousands of artists there fight every day for peoples' attention on the Royal Mile and near to their venues to encourage someone to take a flyer and go buy a ticket for their show. For several hours each day, we will promote the show come Scottish rain, rain or rain (let's be honest, it'll mostly be rain) on the street. In between then, the show will be performed. After that, we'll mingle with other artists, attend their shows and do our best to convince them to come to ours. It never stops! Much like the rain. And despite that, we have no guarantee of a minimum amount of tickets we might sell, though we have a fairly good idea which brings us to..

 

How are we going to surmount these risks and challenges? Meticulous budgeting and surviving solely on the consumption of bananas are our plans for overcoming these challenges. With a detailed and regularly updated budget, we can begin to quickly forecast ticket sales, identify immediately where we can cut costs, and all things going well, identify where our spending is most valuable. The bananas were a joke; staying healthy in body and in mind in Edinburgh is vital to our success. We'll need buckets of positive energy each day to get our show up onto the stage and to successfully promote it to anyone lucky enough to lock eyes with us on the street. Promotion and sales experience amongst the cast and crew are a big advantage to us.

Cumulatively, we have an extensive amount of experience in professional international festivals, performances, fundraising, budgeting, development, touring, theatre of all types and we have done as much research as we possibly can about what it takes to make Bump the hit we know it can be. We are well qualified to deal with anything that comes in our direction and we are, more importantly, ready for it.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are coming to the end of this campaign description, having been so moved by our passion, our intelligence and the sheer gall of this project we are undertaking, with a single tear rolling down your cheek because you simply cannot donate, never fear! Often times, those with the least money have the most friends! Just because you can't contribute, doesn't mean you can't help;

  1. Share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, MySpace, Google+, Bebo, everywhere. Encourage your friends to contribute! Make some noise!
  2. Email this campaign to your friends and colleagues (this is the best way to help, according to science).
  3. Get us in touch with anyone you know who is looking to support a project like this. We want to meet them!
  4. Attend our next fundraiser (keep an eye out on Facebook).
  5. Come see our preview shows! (TBA). We want your feedback to help make Bump the best show it can be.
  6. Join our mailing list for updates. Email "Hello" to bumpandgrindtheatre@gmail.com

story:
Listen, New York City has hundreds of one act festivals that deal with almost everything from short plays focused on social change or short plays designed for solo performances. But there is not one, NOT ONE festival where the focus is on the art of humor.  That is why Adam Chisnall and Yue Liu bring to you The One Act Comedy Fest  at The PIT Loft. A festival where every work deals with comedy, the most glorious word in the English language (yeah, I kinda stole this saying from 42nd Street). This festival gives a chance for new writers to showcase their humorous works to see just how many laughs a play may get!

 

The brains behind this fest is Adam Chisnall, a comedian and emcee residing in NYC. Adam has a BA in Musical Theatre from Point Park University and has studied with The Second City Chicago. Adam has been a part of the "Hoboken Comedy Festival" and has toured with "Comedy's Best Kept Secret". He has emcee'd at Caroline's, StandUp NY, New York Comedy Club, Broadway Comedy Club, Dark Horse Comedy Club, and Gotham. Adam has combined his love for comedy with his love of theatre therefore creating The One Act Comedy Fest. He has joined forces with producer Yue Liu, who is receiving her MFA in Theatre Management and Producing from Columbia University. 

 

We are looking to raise funds that will go to help paying our artists, rehearsal spaces, costumes, props... you understand why we need these generous donations. The idea for The One Act Comedy Fest is to have a stepping stone to eventually create, The Comedy Repertory Theatre of New York; a theatre company focused on, you guessed it, comedy! Please join us October 29 at The PIT Loft 2 & 9pm for The One Act Comedy Fest. Tickets are $5 for matinee and $10 for evening. The evening will include these works from upcoming playwrights and composers:

 

Permanent Stain Tattoo

by Eric Dietz

 

The Basics of Conning

by Sam Strum

 

The Charm

Book and Lyrics by Christiana Cole Little

Music by David Shenton

 

Writer's Blocked

Book and Lyrics: Josh Shapiro

Music: TJ Rubin

 

Your kind support and donations are greatly appreciated. See you October 29th!

story:
Who is Arcadian Broad?

Hello everyone! I'm Arcadian Broad. I'm 21 years old and reside in Orlando FL. I'm a Dancer, Choreographer, Actor, Musician and Composer. I'm currently a Leading Dancer and Artist in Residence with the Orlando Ballet. 

A little about myself so you're not talking to a complete stranger ;)

I started my ballet training at 15, which is rather late in the game. But I was always linked into the arts way before that. I started playing the piano at 2 years old, which i continue to play to this day. Music is where my artistic roots are which has allowed me to branch out into all the different facets that I'm involved in today. So it was quite appropriate that the first style of dance I  gravitated to was tap! I later started hip-hop as well. Did that for a couple years, eventually adding jazz to my list. At 12, I was a understudy for the role of Billy in the original broadway show of Billy Elliot. Then at 13 I auditioned for Season 4 of America's Got Talent. I danced my way to the Top 10!  After that, Ellen Degeneres invited me to perform on her show, which was pretty awesome! At 15 I attended the Juilliard School in NYC. That is where I started focusing on ballet, contemporary and choreography. A year later, Orlando Ballet's Artistic director Robert Hill hired me for the professional company. I'm the youngest dancer to be hired under him. During the past 5 seasons with company Ive had the opportunity to grow into Principal roles and choreographing for the company. I produced my first work at 16 and haven't stopped since! With an ever growing repertoire including successful pieces such as:

"Time"

"Pshycological Recovery"

 "White Noise"

 "MW2"

 "Seasons"

and "An American in Paris Suite". 

 I've also branched out into composition now. Most recently I choreographed and composed an original score for my first full length production "Beauty & the Beast". 

This campaign is to launch my project "From A to B". Which is a group where we'll perform my choreography. This will allow me to have the space to produce more work in both dance and music more efficiently. To experiment and grow to get one step closer to perfecting my craft. 

I've always loved the idea of community. The "It takes a village" concept. Which it does! As much as this project is about me, it is also about the community! Cause without the audience coming to support my ideas and shows,,,there would be no growth of community. It is my great hope and intention that not only I will benefit by "From A to B"s success but the community benefits as well! 

The Breakdown

So I'm going to level with you guys...

If we don't reach our goal of $15,000..then this won't happen. 

Let me break down the expenses for you:

Venue Rental) 

I'm shooting for the 300 seat venue Alexis and Jim Pugh Theater in Orlando, FL to kick off my project. That rental will range from 3k-5k.

Production Elements)

I've decided for the sake of budget, to stick with very minimalistic production elements in terms of drops and props. This will range from 2-4k.

Lighting)

It is essential to me to have a variety of options for lighting. It really elevates the scale of the production. This will range from 5-7k.

Paying the dancers)

The remaining budget would be for paying the dancers. Remember, these are professional dancers we're talking about here. You wouldn't ask a NFL player to join your team for free right?! Same thing here. Paying the artists is very important.

 

If we don't reach our goal... the funds that were raised will be set aside for the next campaign.  

Although, I am very confident that we will reach our goal! I know I can trust you guys!

Risks, Challenges & Rewards

Just like with anything in life there will be risks and challenges. I am starting this project from the ground up. Right now, it's just ideas and hard work behind this dream. With your contribution, you will help make this a reality! 

But with challenges...can come rewards... 

I have a few people who have watched my career throughout the years and really support me, offer to MATCH the funds we raise but only if we reach or surpass the $15,000 goal! 

Could you imagine... 15 turning into 30...

Then 30 to 45..

and 45 to 60! 

It all very exciting!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially...you can still help!

By spreading the word amongst your circle of people and so on and so on to where it catches like wildfire! Sharing will help a lot! Share this on all your social media, email to friends and family etc. Remember, sharing is caring! ;) 

Thank you so much for sticking around and reading all about "From A to B"! 

I hope that you decide to stand with me in making this dream a reality! 

Until next time folks!

Love, Arcadian Broad
story_txt:
Who is Arcadian Broad?
Hello everyone! I'm Arcadian Broad. I'm 21 years old and reside in Orlando FL. I'm a Dancer, Choreographer, Actor, Musician and Composer. I'm currently a Leading Dancer and Artist in Residence with the Orlando Ballet. 
A little about myself so you're not talking to a complete stranger ;)
I started my ballet training at 15, which is rather late in the game. But I was always linked into the arts way before that. I started playing the piano at 2 years old, which i continue to play to this day. Music is where my artistic roots are which has allowed me to branch out into all the different facets that I'm involved in today. So it was quite appropriate that the first style of dance I  gravitated to was tap! I later started hip-hop as well. Did that for a couple years, eventually adding jazz to my list. At 12, I was a understudy for the role of Billy in the original broadway show of Billy Elliot. Then at 13 I auditioned for Season 4 of America's Got Talent. I danced my way to the Top 10!  After that, Ellen Degeneres invited me to perform on her show, which was pretty awesome! At 15 I attended the Juilliard School in NYC. That is where I started focusing on ballet, contemporary and choreography. A year later, Orlando Ballet's Artistic director Robert Hill hired me for the professional company. I'm the youngest dancer to be hired under him. During the past 5 seasons with company Ive had the opportunity to grow into Principal roles and choreographing for the company. I produced my first work at 16 and haven't stopped since! With an ever growing repertoire including successful pieces such as:
"Time"
"Pshycological Recovery"
 "White Noise"
 "MW2"
 "Seasons"
and "An American in Paris Suite". 
 I've also branched out into composition now. Most recently I choreographed and composed an original score for my first full length production "Beauty & the Beast". 
This campaign is to launch my project "From A to B". Which is a group where we'll perform my choreography. This will allow me to have the space to produce more work in both dance and music more efficiently. To experiment and grow to get one step closer to perfecting my craft. 
I've always loved the idea of community. The "It takes a village" concept. Which it does! As much as this project is about me, it is also about the community! If we don't reach our goal... the funds that were raised will be set aside for the next campaign.

Just like with anything in life there will be risks and challenges. I am starting this project from the ground up. Right now, it's just ideas and hard work behind this dream. With your contribution, you will help make this a reality! 
But with challenges...can come rewards...

story:
What is ONE Movement Project?  

Alex Abarca, Myra Bazell, Emily Christianson, and Bella Dorado (all Atlanta-based), Alicia Baskel (San Diego-based) and Lillian Ransijn (Philadelphia-based) are the brains, heart, and backbone of ONE movement project that started up in September 2016. 

Together, we make up a collective of movement and theater artists, each with a unique background, perspective, and set of life experiences.  

Individually, we are each creating movement pieces based on our interpretation(s) of the word "one" through the lens of our personal stories, culture and pop culture, society, history, and politics. Once a month, we gather to share our work and give one another feedback in a supportive laboratory format.

Our year-long choreographic exchange will culminate in a series of live public performances, community movement workshops geared towards people with little to no formal dance training, and open discussion sessions in Atlanta, San Diego, and Philadelphia in Fall 2017 and Winter 2018. 

 

Our Goals: 

We aim to:

- Examine our personal relationships with the multiple facets of "one," in particular: feelings of isolation, singularity, unity, solitude, and inclusion using contemporary dance and theater as the vehicles;

- Unearth through movement and text the various ways that humans are interconnected in spite of their apparent external differences;

- Foster meaningful discussions about the significance of “one” and how dance as an art form can communicate this concept; 

- Create and sustain an open, dynamic dialogue with the public

- Provide greater accessibility to contemporary dance to people who might not otherwise have the opportunity to be a part of it

 

... we value artmaking that is meaningful, provocative and accessible and want to invite you to be a part of our journey! 

 

How you can help:

We need to raise $20,000 to cover the costs of producing our premiere performance in Atlanta and touring our show to San Diego and Philadelphia. Theaters cost money to rent, flights cost money to book, and we need to pay the creative and production teams for their hard work and commitment! 

By contributing towards ONE movement project, you will help pay for:

  • Artist fees for all six participating choreographers
  • Stipends for cast of 30-40 additional movers
  • Theater rental for performances in Atlanta, San Diego, and Philadelphia
  • Airfare and other travel-related expenses to and between Atlanta, San Diego, and Philadelphia
  • Production costs 
  • Fees for essential woman/ manpower: 
    • Technical Director, Production Manager, Lighting Designer, Stage Manager, and Sound Engineer
  • Marketing materials
  • Costumes

 

Our way of saying Thank You: 

We have some really "ONE-derful" perks to offer you as a thank you for contributing to our campaign!

$5:  Shout out on social media

$25:  Shout out on social media + name listed on website and in printed program

$50:  (all the above) plus ONE movement project refrigerator magnet

$100:  (all the above) plus photograph of the ONE movement project participating artists

$200:  (all the above) plus 2 complimentary tickets to the final performance in Atlanta, Philadelphia, or San Diego

$500:  (all the above) plus ONE movement project T-shirt

$750:  (all the above) plus ONE movement project tote bag

$1,000:  (all the above) plus exclusive invitation to one of our intimate monthly feedback sessions in Atlanta, San Diego, or Philadelphia

$2,500:  (all the above) plus enjoy a toast with the artists of ONE Movement Project following one of our performances

$5,000:  (all the above) plus we will create and perform an original happy dance for you AND sign your T shirt and tote bag!

 

Why we need your help:

Since we are a collective group of artists and not a nonprofit arts organization, we are limited with how we can raise money. We are not eligible to apply for most government and foundation grants, so our funding sources are limited. That's why we need your help! 

Without making our fundraising goal, we will be extremely limited with where we can present our final performances in Atlanta. Also, touring the show to San Diego and Philadelphia will be financially difficult. We will have to operate on a shoestring budget that will not allow for the artists or production team to be paid their full stipends. We may not be able to compensate our cast of 30-40 additional performers for the final production. Finally, we are committed to offering one pay-what-you-can-performance to encourage audience participation across all economic levels. If we do not raise the necessary funds, we will not be able to offer reduced-price tickets to our final performance.

Please help us reach our goal by contributing to our campaign, spreading the word to your friends and family, keeping up with us on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/OneDancing/), and using the Indiegogo icon to share our campaign. 

If you're not able to contribute financially, you can always share our campaign with your friends and family. We gratefully and humbly appreciate all types of support! 

 

From the bottom of our hearts, we thank you!

story:
Whalebone

Whalebone has been in development since we came back from Edinburgh last year. The initial seed was Nabokov’s unfinished novel, Laura, in which the protagonist deletes their body, imagining it invisible, simply because they can.

We found in this the potential to create a thought-provoking, complex, witty response to the issue of the objectification of women.

    Our Laura, faced with the same external pressures experienced by the majority of women, decides to take back control by deleting her body altogether.  We are extremely excited to present the story of Laura, in an attempt to respond to a problem that plagues so many of the women we know. It’s irreverent, feminist theatre. It’s also narrated by a talking vagina, if that helps.

    We are lucky enough to have secured a preview at Bunker Theatre in July, a slot at the Pleasance Courtyard in Edinburgh, and a one-off show at Pleasance Islington in October.

     

    However, as funding for small theatre companies becomes increasingly scarce, we are reliant on your support.

      We need to raise £2,000 to take Whalebone to Edinburgh. The money you donate will be spent on marketing, transport, and design elements of the show, as well as allowing us to pay for rehearsal space in the immediate run-up to the festival. If we achieve even more than our target, we will put money towards wages for everyone involved, as we really believe that in an idea world, everyone should get paid for what they produce.

      We will be performing at the Bunker on the 17th July at 7pm, and in the Pleasance Courtyard from 2nd-27th August at 1pm

      We are hugely excited to bring this show to the biggest arts festival in the world, and to one of its most prestigious venues. Edinburgh is this show’s best chance of being seen by as wide and audience as possible, and enjoying a future life after the festival.

      But more than that, Edinburgh is a platform for us as a new company, and we are so grateful for the spotlight that Pleasance is offering to us at the start of our career. We want to make more theatre like this – formally experimental, socially conscious – and a successful Edinburgh run will help us on our way.

        Risks & Challenges

        For any Edinburgh show, selling is a tough business. This is made even harder if there are fewer of you to harass people into attending your show. However, we are confident that we will be able to engage people in the subject matter of our play, and really want to connect with as many people as possible about the issue of gender body politics, and introduce them to our puppet-led storytelling. As a small team, each of us is committing a huge amount of time, energy and (inevitably) personal funds, in order to give this show what it deserves. Any help you can give, however small, would make a difference!

          If you can’t afford to donate, WE UNDERSTAND, but please support us in whatever way you can

          - Like us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram (@hatchittheatre)

          - Tell all your friends and family and even people you don't know or don't like about us

          - COME AND SEE THE SHOW

           

          ***EXCITING UPDATE***

          For donations of £20 and up, you can claim a one-hour pass at our Body Cool day on Sunday 2nd July. What's Body Cool, you ask?

          Body Cool is a day-festival celebrating all things cool about your body, hosted by the Arcola Theatre! 

          This workshop invites people of all ages to come and explore their bodies, discover their capabilities and, in the process, uncover a new found love and understanding for themselves.

          Here's the lineup, all led by incredibly exciting up and coming practitioners:

          Five Element Dance  13:00-14:00
          Body Play 14:00-15:00
          Life Drawing  15:00-16:00
          Luna Yoga 16:00-17:00
          Moving Touch 17:00-18:00
          Burlesque 18:00-19:00

          Here are Loussin-Torah and Alex Luttley doing their thing. You can catch Loussin in yoga at 4, while Alex is taking burlesque at 6!


           

          To find out more about Body Cool, check out the event via facebook.com/hatchittheatre

story:
The White Bear

From fresh new writing to unearthing lost classics, The White Bear Theatre is "South London's new writing powerhouse" - The Stage. 

It exists to nurture talent, extend possibilities and offer a space where risks can be taken. The theatre has helped launch some of the country's most exiting theatre makers including Vicky Featherstone, Blanche McIntyre and Joe Penhall. Against a background of economic insecurity and Arts Council cuts, it supports emerging practitioners who want to develop their work and take their careers to the next stage, and for experienced artists to re-invent themselves. 

Following extensive refurbishment of the entire White Bear building as well as a complete re-imagining of the theatre space, The White Bear is back with an exciting new programme of work that demonstrates its continued commitment to plays, engaging modern society in all its complexity.

We are ready to re-launch with a dynamic opening season bringing vital theatre to as wide an audience as possible. We are close, but need your help to get us over the line.

 

What We Need

We list our needs in order of priority. All funds received will be allocated according to priority.

Let There Be Light!

Donate to our new state of the art LED Lighting system: Zero88 LX Desk; Lights consist of Etc source 4, Fireball LED PAR and Zero88 alphapacks.

 

 £1,500.

Full of Sound (with a side of fury...)

Donate towards our new, state of the art Sound system: Sound desk is Behringer; Amps and speakers are Crown and JBL.

 £1,000.

Are You Sitting Comfortably?

Existing seating will be upholstered and covered with hard-wearing new fabric.

 £500

Stretch Goals

So you like the look of the work the White Bear is doing and want to lend your support (great!). But the initial target has already been met (also great!) but now you feel you missed out (oh dear). Well... never fear! There is still more that we need help with! Any money we raise in excess of our initial target will go towards:

- Writers' Programme: The White Bear is establishing a Writers Programme that seeks to work with emerging playwrights to develop their work. We are committed to seeking out the country's future playwrights and working with them over a sustained period of time to nurture and develop their talents. We also will offer a platform for playwrights to meet and network with leading playwrights and practitioners in the industry.

The Impact

Crowd-funding is an important way of reaching out to you, as a way of inviting you to become an active and supportive member of the White Bear community. In doing so, you will ensure that fundamental technical equipment will be financed, without which we would be unable to reopen. Reaching our target will allow us to concentrate on exceeding the high standards of theatre the White Bear's audience has come to expect.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate, you can help us with our campaign by sharing the links below and spreading the word about our aims. Beyond that, you could come to our shows when we reopen!

Indiegogo - https://igg.me/at/WhiteBearTheatreReopens

Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/White-Bear-Theatre-108...

Twitter - @WhiteBearTheatr #WhiteBearTheatreReopens

Website - www.whitebeartheatre.co.uk

story:
"Browncoats: The Musical": A Firefly fan musical

We were all heartbroken when Firefly was canceled. That day, a truly great piece of Sci-Fi was snuffed out far too soon. But the Firefly fandom has proven itself to be mightier than any network, and we've brought back out favorite smugglers in "Serenity" and in the comics.

We at Tea Time for Mad Girls Productions are avid Firefly fans. One day, as we were mourning the short run, we came upon an interesting thought. What would have happened if Joss Whedon had written a musical episode of Firefly, like Buffy The Vampire Slayer's "Once More with Feeling"? We concluded that it would have been awesome. 

So we took it upon ourselves, as fans, to write the musical episode of Firefly. 

And Browncoats: The Musical was born. 

And now we're bringing it to you for the first time, live onstage, in Brooklyn, NYC on May 6th! The crew you know and love is back, with a new plot, snappy dialogue, and a full score of original songs. 

Come see what happened to the crew of Serenity after the events on Miranda, and enjoy Firefly in a whole new media! Tickets are available now at geminiandscorpio.com! But don't worry, Firefly fans who live far from New York City, there are ways for you to see Browncoats: The Musical too! (Spoiler Alert: we're filming it.)

Now we need your help to get Serenity flying again. With your contributions, we can bring back your favorite Sci-Fi show in a whole new way.

What we need from you, and all the cool stuff we're offering:

To paraphrase Terry Pratchett,  "Theatre doesn't make money. You put money in and Theatre comes out." And that is true of Browncoats: The Musical. And because all the proceeds from ticket sales are gong to be donated to the ACLU, we are relying on you to help us bring Browncoats: The Musical to life.

Below is a simple cost breakdown, giving you an idea of how much it can take to bring a story like Browncoats: The Musical to life.

  • Production Costs

    • Rehearsal Studio Spaces: $600

    • Set and Properties: $250

    • Musicians: $350

    • Costumes: $250

    • Printing (Scrips, Scores, Programs): $150

    • Set and Instrument Transportation: $100

    • Crowd Funding Perks (Printing, packaging, shiping): $100

    • Misc. Costs: $200

  • TOTAL: $2,000

That's where you come in. $2,000 is a lot of money for a small production company, but when you break that up among a thousand Firefly fans....it only costs $2 a fan to see your favorite story come back to life in a whole new media. Of course....you're probably going to want to give us more than $2...because we're not only bringing you an incredible Fan-Musical based on your favorite smugglers, we also have some incredible perks for you!

  • A Browncoats: The Musical DVD: Good new for those of you outside the NYC area, we will be filming the first performance of Browncoats: The Musical so that you can all see it, no matter where you are from. Don't let distance stand in the way of you getting to be at the premiere of the "shiniest" musical ever! Just get the recording as either a physical DVD or a Digital Copy and watch Browncoats: The Musical over and over and over again...just like you watch Firefly and Serenity!
  • We had the fantastic Jennifer Drucker, graphic designer, put together a beautiful show poster and set of 9 character prints, inspired by Browncoats: The Musical to offer as perks for you here. (Check them out in the Photo Gallery) They're a beautiful and unique way to show your support for both Browncoats: The Musical, and the whole Firefly fandom!

The Browncoat Cause: Why we're doing this as a benefit

We're living in an interesting time. The world around us is heaving into turmoil. And as artists, we wanted to do our small part to help. As fans, we couldn't help but see ourselves in the Browncoats, who "Picked the losing side, but still ain't convinced it was the wrong one." So we made a story. A story about resistance. A story about moving forward. A story about learning to live when it seems like the whole world is upside down. 

And we decided to perform that story while raising money for the American Civil Liberties Union, and organization that has promised to protect the rights of ALL Americans. We felt it was the best way for us to give back. 

So help us.

Share the Signal!

We know not every die-hard Browncoat has the spare cash on hand to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't get involved!

  • Share this campaign on all your social media. Facebook. Twitter. A blog. Anything. Help us reach as many of your fellow fans as possible.
  • Use the hashtag #browncoatsthemusical every time you post!
  • Like Tea Time for Mad Girls Productions on Facebook, and follow on YouTube, Twitter, Tumblr, and Instagram to stay in the loop.
  • But most importantly, get out there and tell your fellow fans. Wouldn't YOU be excited to hear about more Firefly?

So now its up to you, Firefly fandom! You got together and proved you were powerful enough to bring back Firefly once, and we all got an incredible movie; "Serenity". Let's do it again for Browncoats: The Musical!

story:
Short Summary

Dylan Guerra and Caitlin Rodstein are both Directors, Writers and Producers who recently graduated with their B.F.A's in Theater. Caitlin received her degree from Boston University, and Dylan received his from Southern Methodist University. The cast varies from all across America, and all have recently moved to NYC in pursuit of a career in the arts. 

Get Hit was developed during Dylan's time at SMU, presented in Miami, and then revamped and work-shopped for this production in NYC. 

 

We Need Your Help

This fully realized production requires more funds than we have in our pockets; and as the launch of a new theater company, we need all the help we can get. 

The money we're raising is going toward Theater Rental, Actors, Set/Props, and Publicity. We have the projected costs laid out below: 

Theater Rental: $3100 
Actors: $2400 
Set/Props: $1000
Publicity: $500

 

The Impact

"Get Hit" is a play for today. It deals with social issues youth are facing today: self discovery, longing to escape, trying to survive, find a job,  and pursuing dreams. It deals with the struggle to continue your education when universities seem to be upping their tuition every year. 

And it's a comedy! It's a fast paced, action packed, comedy!

"Get Hit" is the first full-length play produced by the new and improved "Company Company". A theater company dedicated to producing and developing new works by up and coming playwrights. "The Company Company" works to create innovative, challenging, and accessible theatrical experiences. 

Risks & Challenges

NYC is a gigantic city. It's easy to get lost. In order to get your voice heard, we've learned, you cannot wait for your chance- you have to make it. 
Money is a risk. 
Putting these characters on stage together is a risk. 
Presenting a voice on stage is a risk. 
It's a business filled with risk. 

What we're asking is for your help in creating this opportunity to share a fun and important play with the theater community of NYC. 

Help us make our voices heard. 
Help us launch a theater company whose mission is to get more voices heard. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that's totally okay! 
We would love to see you at "Get Hit". You can purchase tickets here: http://gethitnyc.brownpapertickets.com/

Or feel free to reach out to us at companycompanynyc@gmail.com

Information: 

"Get Hit" runs June 29th- July 8th 
@ The Medicine Show Theater (549 W 52nd St, New York, NY 10019)

Jess lost her scholarship. 
James doesn't have a job. 
Paula needs to get to London. 
Jill's a convict. 
Archie just wants to be an actor. 
Patrick is just doing what's right. 

They get in to car accidents for money. 

This fast paced comedy explores how far desperate college students are willing to go to make some extra cash.

Running Time: 1 hour 45 Minutes (with intermission) 

Produced by: The Company Company 

Any questions? Email us at CompanyCompanyNYC@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary:

My name is David Lind and I am actor, director, playwright and teacher. I am also survivor of childhood sexual abuse.

The merging of my “artist” self and “survivor” self resulted in my creating FAITH – From Anger Into Trust & Hope - a show that explores the healing journey of a survivor of clergy sexual abuse.

By assisting me in producing this show, you will help me to...

...reach out to others who may have been abused and letting them know they are not alone.

...encourage other survivors and victims to pursue healing paths and finding their voice.

...help supporters, family and friends of survivors/victims better understand what the survivor/victim they know are going through.

What We Need & What You Get:

I am currently in the process of finishing the show and preparing to perform it at the 2017 Minnesota Fringe Festival. I have a performing slot at The Jungle Theater and am seeking funds to help pay for costumes, props, and set pieces; marketing and other promotional materials.

There are a variety of perks available to those who contribute ranging from being listed in the show's program and website to tickets to the show and opportunities to meet with me before or after the show to ask questions or discuss the issues of childhood sexual abuse or clergy sexual abuse or even how a show like this is created.

If the fund-raising exceeds the goal, any additional funds will be used to help promote bringing the show to other venues.

The Impact:

This show, while still in the creation stage, has already had an impact. There are survivors/victims who have reached out just from hearing that it is being created and expressed a desire to help out and share their stories, too.

Risks & Challenges:

This is not your typical piece of theatre. The topic, while extremely topical, is a difficult one for many people to discuss. It's also a difficult journey to present to an audience. As Break The Silence's founder Sarah Super wrote:

“There is no easy way to be a survivor. If I only tell you about the pain, I fear I will perpetuate toxic stereotypes of the victim who is broken. But if I share with you only about my healing, I fear you will believe that time heals trauma, that healing is linear, and that I will minimize the damage of sexual assault.”

This show looks at both the initial impact of clergy sexual abuse as well as what it takes to heal.

Any assistance you provide will be greatly appreciated. And if you're not able to help financially, please come see the show and spread the word.

Many thanks.

David Lind
Creator/Performer
FAITH – From Anger Into Trust & Healing

story:
AUDIENCE FEEDBACK FROM THE DECEMBER 2017 OFF-BROADWAY READING

https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=YxVnuxPh93I

"I feel like everybody personalized their characters really well."

"It was amazingly clear. I was moved actually."

"I enjoyed it thoroughly."

SUMMARY
The Court Martial of Almirante Montojo by Dennis Posadas is a Spanish American War historical drama similar to court room dramas like A Few Good Men and The Caine Mutiny. It was inspired by how Admiral George Dewey came to the defense of Spanish Almirante Patricio Montojo in a Madrid trial after the 1898 Battle of Manila Bay, as mentioned in Dewey's 1913 Scribner autobiography.

The play is available on Amazon at https://www.amazon.com/dp/B072MTYRG2

AWARDS
1st Place (Historical), 2017 LA Screenplay Contest http://lascreenplaycontest.com/winners/2017-win...

Special Jury Prize, 2017 Barcelona International Filmfest https://www.barcelonafilmfestival.com/awards-an...
Official Finalist, 2017 Hollywood Screenplay Contest
Official Finalist, 2017 NY Screenplay Contest

ABOUT THE PLAYWRIGHT

Dennis Posadas is the Filipino author of Leap: A Sustainability Fable (Singapore: Pearson, 2015). His previous books include Greenergized (UK: Greenleaf, 2013), Jump Start: A Technopreneurship Fable (Singapore: Pearson Prentice Hall, 2009) and Rice & Chips: Technopreneurship and Innovation in Asia (Singapore: Pearson Prentice Hall, 2007). 

His previous opeds have been published in Bloomberg BusinessWeek, Forbes, The Guardian, San Francisco Chronicle, YaleGlobal, South China Morning, Post, Straits Times, and other publications.

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

  • We will need $20,000 to cover all costs of a 2-3 night off-Broadway full production, with actors in costumes, off-Broadway theatre rent, director, costume rentals, playwright royalty, video etc. No expensive sets will be used.
  • Major Donors ($500 and up) will be mentioned as Sponsors in the video.
  • You get to see the full play on Vimeo (or Youtube).
  • NOTE: Indiegogo also charges fees for the use of their service.

THE IMPACT

I hope to bring a forgotten 120 year old historical event, The Battle of Manila Bay/Batalla de Cavite, on stage and make it interesting even for Marines, Moms, and Millennials.

You might want to read some articles about the play and what it stands for at https://www.broadwayworld.com/off-off-broadway/article/Admiral-George-Dewey-Off-Off-Broadway-Play-Reading-To-Show-His-Compassionate-Side-20171208

https://www.euroweeklynews.com/columnists/14725...

http://www.sfchronicle.com/opinion/openforum/ar...

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

There is always a risk in everything we do. In this case, it would be falling short of the funds required to stage this play. 

If that will not materialize, we can do a scaled down play. Or a reading of actors in costumes. That would be our last resort option.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

IF you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help. Kindly share and ask your friends and family to consider supporting this off-Broadway play project!

story:
What We Need

We need to raise $15,000 by July 10th in order to launch this year's FURY Factory.  We need your help to do that! Any little bit can help.  We are committed to supporting the artists who participating in the festival in every way we can.  Thus, the money raised here will go to fund one of the following:

  1. Artist Fees of the participating theater companies
  2. Day-to-Day Operation of the Festival
  3. Location Fees for our many stages across the city
  4. Material Fees for the ground-breaking, new pieces of theater being produced at the Festival

What You Get

  • $35 USD  -  PROVOCATION: Personalized Social Media shoutouts + a Festival water bottle

  • $50 USD - FASCINATION: water bottle OR festival tshirt OR festival tote bag + an official invite to our exclusive Donor Appreciation Party

  • $55 USD  -  ACTION: 2 Tickets to any Shotgun Players Show! OR 2 tickets to a Z Space Show*! + An invite to our exclusive Donor Appreciation Party! *Availability of tickets on any given performance is subject to availability. Some shows where a third party has rented Z Space may not be available.

  • $65 USD  -  ADMIRATION: 2 Tickets to Cutting Ball's production of UNCLE VANYA! OR 2 Tickets to a Thursday or Friday performance of We Players CAESAR'S MAXIMUS + An invite to our exclusive Donor Appreciation Party!

  • $125 USD - COLLABORATION: Festival Swag, a 3-Show pass to the festival, and an exclusive invitation to our Donor Appreciation Party.

  • $150 USD  -  INNOVATION: Happy Moose Juice for a week (7 X 9 oz. bottles), local & organic cold-pressed juice + A 3-Show Pass + An Invite to our Donor Appreciation Party

  • $500 USD - JUBILATION: INNOVATION (minus the juice)+ registration in our UMO Workshop July 7/8

  • $1000 USD  -  CELEBRATION: 5 Show Pass + Invite to Donor Appreciation Party + A two-night getaway at Venado Retreat (up to 8 people), with a special dinner provided, to be used with in two years. venadoretreat.com

The Line Up

The FURY Factory showcases unique and diverse voices through an amazing array theater experiences. It features: “Mainstage” productions of fully crafted works by some of the country’s most innovative, exciting theater makers, “Raw Materials” – Selections of new works being created, Workshops in creation techniques led by participating artists and other master teachers, as well as panel discussions and more.

Click HERE for more information on tickets!

Mainstage Performances

  • 13th Floor (San Francisco, CA) – Space Pilots in Spaaaace!/A Live Action Sci-Fi Radio Play
  •  Deborah Slater Dance Theater (San Francisco, CA) – In Civility: Part 1, Instability 
  • Pratik Motwani (Blue Lake, CA) – #//EMBEDDED//# 
  • foolsFURY (San Francisco, CA) – (dis)Place[d] 
  • SF Neo-Futurists (San Francisco, CA) – Infinite Resistance: 30 Political Plays in 60 Liberatory Minutes 
  • Swim Club (Vancouver, BC) – Other Inland Empires 
  • marzipanik (San Francisco, CA) – Woodland Creatures Series 
  • Pelú Theater (Charlotte, NC) – Pícaro, bitácora de un migrante 
  • Sandglass Theater (Putnam, VT) – When I Put On Your Glove 
  • UMO (Vashon Island, WA) – Resistance Cabaret 
  • Uplift Physical Theater (San Francisco, CA) – Terra Incognita: Through The Waves 
  • Lee Minora (Philadelphia, PA) – White Feminist

 Raw Materials Series 

  • Naomi Stein (Oakland, CA) – No Man’s Land 
  • Felonious (San Francisco, CA) – Curren$y 
  • Alison De La Cruz (Los Angeles, CA) – Rooster Boi 
  • A Host of People (Detroit, MI) – Cleopatra Boy 
  • Cynthia Ling Lee (Santa Cruz, CA) – Lost Chinatowns 
  • The Stations Ensemble (San Francisco, CA) – Stations 2 (Bearing the Burden) 
  • Square One Collective (New York, NY) – No Place 
  • Hope Mohr Dance (San Francisco, CA) – Leaving the Atocha Station 
  • Re:Act (Richmond, CA) – Dracula 

Workshops 

  • Building Blocks for Devised Work: The UMO Ensemble Method 
  • Ways Not to Drown: a Dance-theater Workshop 

 

 All this and more!

story_txt:
What We Need
We need to raise $15,000 by July 10th in order to launch this year's FURY Factory.  We need your help to do that! Any little bit can help.  We are committed to supporting the artists who participating in the festival in every way we can.  Thus, the money raised here will go to fund one of the following:


Artist Fees of the participating theater companies

Day-to-Day Operation of the Festival

Location Fees for our many stages across the city

Material Fees for the ground-breaking, new pieces of theater being produced at the Festival


What You Get

$35 USD  -  PROVOCATION: Personalized Social Media shoutouts + a Festival water bottle
$50 USD - FASCINATION: water bottle OR festival tshirt OR festival tote bag + an official invite to our exclusive Donor Appreciation Party
$55 USD  -  ACTION: 2 Tickets to any Shotgun Players Show! OR 2 tickets to a Z Space Show*! + An invite to our exclusive Donor Appreciation Party! *Availability of tickets on any given performance is subject to availability. Some shows where a third party has rented Z Space may not be available.
$65 USD  -  ADMIRATION: 2 Tickets to Cutting Ball's production of UNCLE VANYA! OR 2 Tickets to a Thursday or Friday performance of We Players CAESAR'S MAXIMUS + An invite to our exclusive Donor Appreciation Party!
$125 USD - COLLABORATION: Festival Swag, a 3-Show pass to the festival, and an exclusive invitation to our Donor Appreciation Party.
$150 USD  -  INNOVATION: Happy Moose Juice for a week (7 X 9 oz. bottles), local & organic cold-pressed juice + A 3-Show Pass + An Invite to our Donor Appreciation Party
$500 USD - JUBILATION: INNOVATION (minus the juice)+ registration in our UMO Workshop July 7/8
$1000 USD  -  CELEBRATION: 5 Show Pass + Invite to Donor Appreciation Party + A two-night getaway at Venado Retreat (up to 8 people), with a special dinner provided, to be used with in two years. venadoretreat.com


The Line Up
The FURY Factory showcases unique and diverse voices through an amazing array theater experiences. It features: “Mainstage” productions of fully crafted works by some of the country’s most innovative, exciting theater makers, “Raw Materials” – Selections of new works being created, Workshops in creation techniques led by participating artists and other master teachers, as well as panel discussions and more.
Click HERE for more information on tickets!
Mainstage Performances

13th Floor (San Francisco, CA) – Space Pilots in Spaaaace!/A Live Action Sci-Fi Radio Play

 Deborah Slater Dance Theater (San Francisco, CA) – In Civility: Part 1, Instability 

Pratik Motwani (Blue Lake, CA) – #//EMBEDDED//# 

foolsFURY (San Francisco, CA) – (dis)Place[d] 

SF Neo-Futurists (San Francisco, CA) – Infinite Resistance: 30 Political Plays in 60 Liberatory Minutes 

Swim Club (Vancouver, BC) – Other Inland Empires 
marzipanik (San Francisco, CA) – Woodland Creatures Series 

Pelú Theater (Charlotte, NC) – Pícaro, bitácora de un migrante 

Sandglass Theater (Putnam, VT) – When I Put On Your Glove 

UMO (Vashon Island, WA) – Resistance Cabaret 

Uplift Physical Theater (San Francisco, CA) – Terra Incognita: Through The Waves 

Lee Minora (Philadelphia, PA) – White Feminist

 Raw Materials Series 

Naomi Stein (Oakland, CA) – No Man’s Land 

Felonious (San Francisco, CA) – Curren$y 

Alison De La Cruz (Los Angeles, CA) – Rooster Boi 

A Host of People (Detroit, MI) – Cleopatra Boy 

Cynthia Ling Lee (Santa Cruz, CA) – Lost Chinatowns 

The Stations Ensemble (San Francisco, CA) – Stations 2 (Bearing the Burden) 

Square One Collective (New York, NY) – No Place

story:
Echo & Narcissus

 

A Vision

Echo & Narcissus, the new interdisciplinary ballet by Satellite Collective, will debut at Brooklyn Academy of Music on September 14th & 15th. This work is being created and performed by 40 individuals, a massive undertaking for a company as small as Satellite Collective. Echo & Narcissus consists of an original score, original choreography, a live orchestra, some of the best dancers in New York, exceptional visual art, film, lighting design, and stage tech. This will be the seventeenth major interdisciplinary work Satellite has produced since our founding, nine years ago.

As we’ve built this work over the past year, the project has received generous support from the likes of Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, New Music USA and Brooklyn Academy of Music. But to get us to opening night, we’ll need our friends, family, and community to show their enthusiasm for and dedication to this ambitious endeavor.

 

 

The Story

Echo & Narcissus repurproses a 4000-year-old myth for the current turbulence of our own political moment. Grappling with themes of love, madness, selfishness, and transformation, Echo & Narcissus asks if we have the will to wrench ourselves away from the intoxication of our own reflection. With an original score, original choreography, original animation, a live orchestra, some of the best dancers in New York, and a top tier production team; the ambition of this work is matched only by the deftness of our fierce little crew. But we can’t do it without your help.

 

 

Thank You Gifts

Your tax-deductible donation comes with amazing thank-you gifts, including performance tickets, program credits, VIP events, behind-the-scenes opportunities, and more. Here are some of our initial rewards.

$35 – A donation of $35 dollars gets you a ticket to the debut of Narcissus at BAM on September 14th & 15th. These shows will sell out and a ticket at the box office will go for $25. By kicking in an extra $10, you’re helping to support the monumental labor put in by our artists and securing a spot to what will be a sold-out premiere.

$60 – Two tickets. Same reward as above but at a better deal.

$100 – Two tickets and your name credited as a supporter in each evening’s program.

$250 – Two tickets, a program credit, and an invitation to our VIP event. Snack, drink, celebrate, and raise rabble with the glamorous visionaries who have conjured this work.

$1000 – Two tickets, program credit, VIP event, and a backstage experience during our dress rehearsal on Thursday, September 13th. You’ll get a chance to see a work in process in its frenzied final moments prior to its debut. After, we’d like to invite you to dinner with several of our core creative members, artists, and Board for discussion and camaraderie.

 

 

Our Team

The narrative structure of Echo & Narcissus was conceived by Lora Robertson, Satellite Collective’s Executive Director, and Kevin Draper, the company’s Artistic Director. Both were founding members of Satellite nine years ago and both are contributing extensive visual design, as well as Lora’s remarkable stop-motion interstitials. This is their seventeenth major work with the company.

The original score for Echo & Narcissus was composed by Aaron Severini. Following his career as a dancer at New York City Ballet, he was admitted to The Juilliard School, where he earned a Master of Music in composition and won the Juilliard Composers’ Orchestra Competition. Aaron has composed original scores for the New York City Ballet, the Pacific Northwest Ballet School, The Juilliard School, and the New York Choreographic Institute. 

This new ballet was choreographed by Norbert De La Cruz III, a NYC and LA-based contemporary choreographer and educator.  Since receiving his BFA from the Juilliard School in 2010, he has been commissioned by Aspen Santa Fe Ballet, Tulsa Ballet II, Barak Ballet, Hubbard Street II, James Sewell Ballet, Attack Theatre, Ballet X, and Grand Rapids Ballet.  De La Cruz has been awarded fellowships from the Jerome Robbins NEW foundation, the Princess Grace Awards - USA, The Jerome Foundation, The Wolf Trap Foundation, and the Commissioning Choreographers Campaign.  

Lighting for the production has been designed by Satellite Collective Board Member, Brandon Stirling Baker. His lighting can be seen in the repertories of New York City Ballet, San Francisco Ballet, Dutch National Ballet, Berlin Staatsballet, Miami City Ballet, Joffrey Ballet, Pacific Northwest Ballet, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Houston Ballet, Pennsylvania Ballet, Semperoper Dresden, Cincinnati Ballet, Los Angeles Philharmonic, Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance, Los Angeles Dance Project and many others.   Since 2010, Baker has been a frequent collaborator with choreographer Justin Peck of the New York City Ballet. 

Philip Stoddard is a New York-based actor, singer, and director making his debut with Satellite Collective. He is the first graduate of two programs at The Juilliard School (BM in Vocal Arts and MFA in Acting). Credits include: title role in Mozart's Don Giovanni and Tommy Albright in Brigadoon at the Chautauqua Institution, title role in Woyzeck, Colonel in Father Comes Home From the Wars, Dorian Belle in the world premiere of P.Y.G. and Second Place winner in the 2018 Lotte Lenya Vocal Competition. Stoddard has directed artists from the Metropolitan Opera's Lindemann Young Artist Program, assistant directed La Traviata at the Aspen Opera Center, and is co-founder of OperaComp, the first interdivisional opera development laboratory at Juilliard, which culminated in the world premiere of six new operas at National Sawdust in April.

story:
What is BELOW?


BELOW: An Underworld Story is a performance event which brings the audience into the world of an Alzheimer's patient and his caretakers, particularly examining the phenomenon of "Sundowning," where Alzheimer's patients are more active during the nighttime than the day. Using elements of immersive theater, dance, performance art, and installation art, BELOW draws inspiration from memoirs by and interviews from Alzheimer's sufferers and their family members as well as the myth of Orpheus and Eurydice to ask - What is actually there? What is the patient imagining? And what is the difference? 




BELOW is a multi-sensory performance experience drawing on dance, performance art, and theatrical sense in a non-theatrical environment. The architecture of our spaces doesn't just to enhance the performance experience - it IS the performance experience.  Audience members have the option to experience the entire performance event, but are free to enter and leave at any time. 


CHARACTERS:


THE MOLE -  A young man without a name or a past (that he can remember). Sensitive, athletic, but somehow a blank.

THE MOLLUSK - Female. A remnant of the old ocean. Full of loss and confusion. Stunningly beautiful. Blind.

THE CARETAKER - Here to bring his brother, the MOLE, to get help. Slowly losing both his brother and the MOLLUSK to mental decay. Just trying to keep everything together.

SONYA [AN-EX PROSTITUTE] - Has seen some shit and is jaded beyond belief. Is always putting up walls around herself and those she loves. Rough-looking, sturdy, unconventional, sexy. 

JACKIE [SUPERVISOR] - This is her domain, and she runs a tight ship. Surrogate mother to the Mole and the Caretaker. Trying to stay afloat.

THE URCHIN - Haunting the halls, staying out of sight, helping when he can. 


Who are we?


Collaborators on this project are a multi-talented, multi-disciplinary ensemble of Northwestern students and graduates whose fields of study include Dance, Theater, Psychology, Fine Art, and Gender and Sexuality Studies. We are also very lucky to have a brilliant composer and scenic supervisor working with us to develop the piece. Our work on the proposed project began this past fall in Mary Zimmerman's Performance Art class,  and the ensemble committed to an additional six months of research and development.  Many of them are still in school, so we have one small window this summer to make this piece come to life. 


Why we need YOU:


We are currently in the final stages of creating BELOW! We've received a very generous grant from Northwestern University to cover the production costs of this show, but because of university regulations there are two problems:


1. We can only be reimbursed for expenses, but can't have the grant money up front to pay for them. 

This means we have to front all expenses out of our own pockets, then wait for the university to reimburse us. 

2. Again, because of university regulations, we can't use any of the grant money to pay the performers or any other artists involved. 

We'd like to pay our performers. Artists should get paid for their work. 


The money raised in this campaign will  front the money we will eventually get from the university, AND once we've been reimbursed for expenses, the entire $3,000 (or whatever the sum total we raise) will go back to the artists who created the show! Pretty sweet deal, huh? The missing piece of this equation? Its YOU. 

Please donate, or, if you're broke artists like us, please spread the word on Facebook, twitter, instagram (you can use our super cool logo art), or anywhere else you can think of! Shout it from the rooftops!  In return, we'll keep you posted on all the cool happenings during our rehearsal process, including photos, videos, and where and when you can see the finished piece.


TOGETHER WE CAN MAKE IT. 

LOSE YOURSELF. 

JOIN US.
