Beginner courses:  Improv 101s for the total novice - get your feet wet and see what it's all about! Then for the not so novice, but not yet intermediate - getting in more practice with professional coaching!
Intermediate courses in short form improv: polish your improv skills, learn new games, challenge yourself with new concepts and approaches in short and long-form improv options.
Advanced courses:  Go deep and break apart your playing, learn new techniques, recognise bad habits and take your improv even higher!
Musical course:  Learn to improvise with music - create songs and play with your voice and rhythms.  
Teens course: With a focus on building an ensemble, teens develop their teamwork and listening skills in a non-judgemental and respectful environment where they are able to explore and expand their creativity.
 

The MCIF Teachers (Instructors, Profs, Specialists): CHECK www.mamacityimprovfest.com for a workshop lineup!
Alaistair Forbes (Canada)

Alastair is a Second City Mainstage Alumni and a three time nominee for Canada's best male improviser. He's been improvising and teaching professionally for over a decade with the Bad Dog Theatre, Comedy Bar and The Second City. He's attended numerous international improv festivals and was voted the top member of the International Ensemble at the Vancouver Improv Festival. He's improvised and worked numerous greats like Colin Mochrie, Ryan Stiles, Dave Foley. He writes comedy for TV and in his spare time plays far too much disc golf. 
Alastair will perform at MCIF2017 with Lusty Mannequins.
Connor Thompson (Canada)
Connor is an actor, writer, and improvisor from Toronto, Canada. At Second City he wrote and performed in three main-stage reviews, winning a Canadian Comedy award in the process. With his troupe Lusty Mannequins he has taught and performed improv around the world, including in festivals in London, Barcelona, Dublin - and at the inaugural MamaCity Improv Festival in 2016. As a faculty member at the Second City Toronto training centre, he has taught hundreds of students, from beginners to veterans and everyone in between, and he's excited to return to Cape Town to meet the next batch of up-and-coming improvisors from the Mama City!
Connor will be performing with Lusty Mannequins.
Follow him on twitter @cpethompson!
Stefan Pagels Andersen (Denmark)

Stefan is an improviser and actor, and has performed in more than 8 Danish Feature films. He studied at Improv Olympic and has been a professional performing improviser since 2009.  In 2013 he organized the Copenhagen International Improv Festival, that facilitated more than 60 International Improvisers. 
Due to the Festival’s success, he was invited back to the iO to shadow teach some of the worlds best instructors by iO founder Charna Halpern. He has traveled in over 35 cities in the world studying, teaching and performing, some with the worlds best improv performers TJ and Dave www.tjanddave.com – on a tour shadowing their classes and doing shows.
In early 2016, he opened the 1st ever professional improv theatre in Denmark, The ICC Theatre - which was just awarded BEST STAGE IN COPENHAGEN, after only 10 months open.
Stefan will be performing with the Mixed Team and other configurations.
Bill Binder (USA)

Bill began performing in 1994 in Michigan and has been performing in Phoenix, Arizona since 2000. Bill has been producing the Phoenix Improv Festival since 2002 and is a teacher and performer at The Torch Theatre. Bill has enjoyed traveling across North America and Europe learning new styles of play and is very excited to perform for the first time in South Africa.
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=1000079...
Twitter: http://twitter.com/whbinder
Improv Network: http://www.theimprovnetwork.org/members/whbinder
Misch Whitaker (USA)

Misch Whitaker, the resident director at Catalyst Comedy, has been performing and teaching improv for over ten years. Past credits include TheaterSports/FaceOff at ImprovBoston (2007-2008); NXT at Improv Asylum (2007-2008); Improv Asylum Mainstage (2008-2012) and ImprovBoston Mainstage (2013-2014). She's the smaller half of the two person musical improv show Pat and Misch Break Up, and is a member of the international touring company Big Bang.  Misch coaches and teaches improv for kids of all ages at various schools and community organizations, and is an adult improv instructor at ImprovBoston's Comedy School. Back at Catalyst Comedy, she co-created a children's show called KERPLUNK!  and directs and performs with Boston's Unscripted Musical Project (B.U.M.P.), and Dirty Disney.
Misch will be performing with B.U.M.P!
Kevin Miller (USA)

Kevin Miller has performed, coached, and taught improv in Austin, Texas for over 15 years. He is the dean of the Merlin Works Institute of Improvisation at the ZACH Theatre in downtown Austin. He has teaching experience around the US, and as far afield as Finland and Estonia. Kevin owns one dog, two cats, and 12 chickens.
http://i.imgur.com/yWO9q89
https://www.facebook.com/happywaffle
https://www.twitter.com/happywaffle
  
Other ways you can support MCIF...
Some people just can't contribute financially, we get that, but that doesn't mean you can't help:
You can help get the word out about MCIF 2017 and make some noise about our Indiegogo Campaign! Tell your friends and family, follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram @mamacityif . Join our mailing list for updates by visiting our site www.mamacityimprovfest.com
You can also use the Indiegogo share tools to let others know about our campaign!
#MCIF2017 #Improv #Comedy #CapeTown #SouthAfrica
For more info about MCIF 2017 please visit our website or drop us an email with any questions you may have.
Can't wait for you to be part of the MCIF family!
Much Love,
The MCIF team xxx

story:
INSPIRATION

We are interested in exploring the vitality and free creativity that can be generated by a guided collaboration between artists working in a beautiful, and even healing, place. The public performance will be elemental, raw, and connected to the actors’ experience of and with the land. We want to explore how Shakespeare’s language--some of the most beautiful descriptions of the countryside and the relationship between the human and the environment--is illuminated by work in countryside that actually resembles that language. We want to explore how language changes bodies, and how bodies, in turn, change language; how language--poetry--contains hidden dimensions that can only be brought out by engaged meditation on, and practice with, that language. As Peter Brook writes, “[Theater] can never really change so long as culture or any art is simply an appendage on living, separable from it and, once separated, obviously unnecessary. Such art then is only fought for by the artist to whom, temperamentally, it is necessary, for it is his life. In the theatre we always return to the same point: it is not enough for writers and actors to experience this compulsive necessity, audiences must share it, too. So in this sense it is not just a question of wooing an audience. It is an even harder matter of creating works that evoke in audiences an undeniable hunger and thirst.”

THE DIRECTOR

As a writer-director, Matthew Gasda's productions are known for their creative uses of light and unusual stagings; a sense of immediacy and intimacy; rhetorical and emotional explosion. In addition to staging his own original dramas, Matthew directed a production of Howard Brenton’s 1983 play, “Bloody Poetry” first at the Brooklyn Art Library in New York, and this past April, in a greenhouse at The Sekrit Theater in Austin, TX. In 2015, he authored an award-winning adaptation of Euripides “The Bacchae” on commission from SUNY Oswego. Altogether, he has been involved in over 7 successful professional productions in the past 18 months.

THE ENSEMBLE

The biographies of the many actors involved in this workshop are too extensive to list here. Needless to say, even a quick inquiry into the backgrounds of the cast members will reveal a remarkably talented and worthy group of performing artists: Melissa Nelson; Jonathan Wilde; Veronika Dash; Kim Paris; Di Di Chan; Kossivi Alokpovi; Kayla Miller; Theresa Zeitz-Lindamood, Eliza Vann, and more TBA.

THE PRODUCER

Our producer, Mike DeCrosta, is local to the Lehigh Valley, and will be the liaison between the farm and local community and the workshop.  Michael has worked in the fields of urban planning and community development and is interested in the relationship between people and spaces that surround them. He received his Master's of Sociology from Lehigh University in 2015.

PRACTICAL DETAILS

What we are asking for here is enough money to cover transportation, food, and a small contribution to the Seed Farm (which is a non-profit organization). 

We will show up, bring our own food, house ourselves, work independently during the
day. The goal is to minimize troublesome or expensive elements. We will not be building a stage, using stage lights, speakers etc. As a rule we will not use anything that is not at our fingertips: voices, body, grass, trees, sunlight, moonlight. We are literally going to attempt to create a richly immersive version of Shakespeare's luminous play with as few resources as possible. A few resources, however, are not no resources.  

THE IMPACT

If this workshop is successful then the following happens:

- We build a troupe capable of bringing Midsummer back to New York City and beyond.

- We lay the groundwork for a future theater festival in Pennsylvania.

- Art is done for arts sake: for the sake of expanding the expressive and imaginative range of a worthy group of creative artists.

RISKS & CHALLENGES

Theater is always difficult. Shakespeare is always difficult. On short notice, with limited resources, it is even harder. We intend to give a public after only 3 days of all-day work. The margin for error will be small. Memories will be tested, bodies will be tired. This however, is nothing that an experienced, supportive, passionate group of performing artists cannot overcome. Part of the power of the performance will come from the energy generated by the overcoming of practical obstacles.

story:
Gardiner Comfort and Kel Haney will have a run of their hit show, THE ELEPHANT IN EVERY ROOM I ENTER this November at a soon-to-be-announced New York City Theater, where they will present the show for three weeks.  While this is a major step up for Comfort and Haney, they are still tasked with paying for everything themselves!  You can see the outline of those costs below.  The goal is a commercial Off-Broadway run of the show and Comfort and Haney believe they can achieve that goal if the right producers and press are there in November.  But we need to get this production on its feet to do so.

Here's what you're supporting:

Incredibly Top-Notch Theatre

All contributions will support the creation and promotion of our show :

Compensation for everyone involved in the production: designers, choreographer, stage manager, associate director, press rep, technicians, videographers and more

Rental of projection equipment 

Set, costume, and lighting design, building upon our workshop production, to further heighten the performances visual aspects

Additional marketing and advertising costs--to get as many people as possible being aware of and seeing the show

A Disability Uncovered

Tourette's is much maligned in the public eye today, often relegated to a base joke in a comedy showing someone unable to stop swearing. Our play looks to blow that stereotype wide open: an honest examination of the complex and varied difficulties involved with the disability. The awareness that this piece will bring can play a serious part in completely changing the world's view of this syndrome.

A Total Joy to Watch

Alongside the education and awareness ELEPHANT brings, the play is an absolute thrill to experience. A show of comedic portrayals (wild dancing, and a touching memoir all performed by one man) will leave you ecstatic as well as informed. You haven't seen a piece like this before, and it can only happen with your contributions!

story:
Who We Are 

Unhitched is a romantic comedy by Morgan English adapted from her screenplay of the same name. It follows three couples,  who are navigating the ups and downs of love lost and love found. A love letter to love. 

 This show is being co-produced by Jenny Skiffington and Giselle Fischman as the first production of their new production  company Palm Tree & Pine.We are a small independent theatre company, passionate about storytelling, with a group of talented young women at the helm.   

Unhitched will be going up in Hollywood, CA this April 6th & 7th. 

Thank you so much for your interest and support of live theatre! 

Your Contribution 

Our Budget Includes: 

  • Theatre Rental  in Hollywood for our performance weekend: $1150
  • Marketing and Advertising : $150
  • 6 Actors at $100 per actor : $600
  • Set Pieces, Props and Wardrobe : $250 

Total Budget: $2150 

Our first priority is our theatre space and set pieces. Anything over will go to provide pay for our ensemble of actors, and marketing. 

Risks & Challenges

There are many risks with any original project. Ours is financial. Rent on theatre's in Hollywood can be steep, as well as set pieces and props to bring the story to life. We love live theatre and we would love any help and support you can give, to bring  this play to life. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see the show, and spread the word!

story:
OUR IMPACT

Derek* is a 3rd grade student at Logan Elementary School. He took CHI Dance throughout the school year and had the highest attendance among his peers. Derek communicated that he had “anger issues,” so his CHI Dance instructor focused heavily on teaching him breathing exercises to calm the body and mind, and connected themes of anger management to creative movement and mindfulness activities. At the end of the school year, Derek checked yes on his evaluation stating “After taking this course I have more skills to cope with stress” and wrote the word “Breathing” underneath this question. Unprompted by the instructor, Derek demonstrated he had learned that he can use breathing as a technique to deal with stress inside and outside of the classroom. Derek will move onto 4th grade this upcoming school year and he will be a “CHI Dance leader” in his class. Giving Derek a chance to be a “leader” was a decision made among KYL/D’s Youth Education Coordinator and the Logan School Principal to help build Derek's confidence and enforce his mindfulness skills. Great work Derek!

*The name of this student is changed for confidentiality purposes


ABOUT CHI DANCE: kyld.org/community-outreach/

Kun-Yang Lin/Dancers (KYL/D) is a non-profit contemporary dance company based in Philadelphia. KYL/D offers FREE mindfulness-movement classes for students, like Derek, in schools throughout Philadelphia, known as CHI Dance. During CHI Dance, students learn dance through the lens of mindfulness, a practice of maintaining a nonjudgmental state of awareness of one’s thoughts, emotions or experiences. Students are provided a safe space to move, while also developing skills in mindfulness, anger management, self-discipline, teamwork, as well as spatial and inner awareness.CHI Dance is modeled after Artistic Director, Kun-Yang Lin’s CHI Awareness Practice, which focuses on the relationship of the moving body to breath.

We reached over 750+ students this past school year and we are looking forward to being in the following schools: Southwark School (South Philly), Francis Scott Key School (South Philly), Alexander Adaire School (Northeast Philly), Charter High School for Architecture and Design (Center City) and James Logan Elementary (North/Northwest Philly). But, we need YOUR help to support expansion of this important program! We have a waitlist of 37 schools, help us reach just ONE MORE!


WHY ITS IMPORTANT

Dance is a valuable art form that is absent in our schools and communities

  • There are only 23 dance teachers in the Philadelphia Public School system compared to the 611 total music teachers and 321 total visual and media art teachers.
  • 55% of students surveyed have told us they can not take dance class due to lack of finances and transportation.

Through CHI Dance, KYL/D fills the gap of dance instruction and mindfulness-based movement opportunities to underserved students throughout the public school system in Philadelphia by providing programs on site via in-school, after-school and summer programs.


OUR GOAL!

KYL/D hopes to raise at least $1,450 to support one fall session worth of programming at our new school, Francis Scott Key in South Philadelphia. This amount covers compensation for our lead and assistant CHI Dance instructors as well as supplies and administration. We set a very modest goal, and we have a waitlist of 37 schools that want our program, which means no gift is too small and surpassing our goal means we can reach even more children!

HOW YOU CAN HELP:

  • Make a quick and easy gift online that is meaningful to you. Any gift is meaningful to us!
  • Help us spread the word by sharing the link to our Indiegogo page to your friends and family online (FB, Twitter, Instagram, Email, etc.)

Note: We will also be grateful for mailed donations, if you prefer. Please make checks payable to KYL Dancers Inc., and mail it to:

Kun-Yang Lin/Dancers
1316 S. 9th St.
Philadelphia, PA 19147                                                                                                        

From all of us at KYL/D, We THANK YOU for your support!

 

ABOUT KYL/D

Kun-Yang Lin/Dancers (KYL/D) is a professional contemporary dance company located in South Philadelphia. Hailed for its superbly trained dancers and inventive choreography, the internationally-active KYL/D probes at the limits of national identity. Drawing upon Eastern philosophies while expanding the perimeter of contemporary dance, Artistic Director Lin's zen-inspired practice of dance manifests in lush works of poetic sensibility that The New York Times says "create and inhabit worlds of their own." Lin draws upon multicultural insights from his ongoing research throughout Asia, creating a personal movement language that is an unexpected hybrid between Western and Eastern cultures, suffused with strong spiritual underpinnings.

story:
The Dance Legacy Project

In Collaboration with the University of Michigan Organ Conference and The Baroque Chamber Orchestra

The Dance Legacy Project’s inaugural season marks the first time that Doris Humphrey's Air (1928), Passacaglia and Fugue in C Minor (1938), and Brandenburg Concerto No. 4 (1958/59) will be presented in a single concert with live music, reflecting the theme of the Conference: Trailblazers: Women's Impact on Organ, Carillon, Harpsichord, and Sacred Music.

The Challenge

The University of Michigan has generously supported this performance through three specific grants and rehearsal/performance space in kind.

Only an additional $6,000 is needed.

Funds are needed for guest artists to stage the works, to costume thirty-two dancers, to hire a stage manager and crew, to build and transport staging materials, to livestream the concert, and to provide modest promotional and administrative support.

$500 pays for half of the event’s stage manager

$1000 will cover half of the staging of the works by Trustees of the Doris Humphrey Foundation

$2000 will pay for half of the unique and integral Humphrey costumes

$2500 will pay for the archival recording and broadcasting of the concert

Click on the BACK IT button at the top of the page, next to the video to DONATE any amount of your choosing.

The Project

Humphrey is one of North America’s preeminent pioneers in twentieth-century modern dance and one of the first women to lead her own company of professional dancers. Her love for the music of J.S. Bach is woven through her work. Talented dance students and faculty from the University of Michigan and Eastern Michigan University will perform three seminal dances spanning four decades of Humphrey’s influential career. 

These works are filled with hope, joy, and the harmony of dancing together. Presenting the legacy of Humphrey’s work will provide an historical connection to many of today's master works. In addition, the creative process of staging these works together will provide an impactful and unique creative experience for students, faculty, performers, and audience. The beauty and power of Humphrey’s work will transport, connect, and inspire this community, while sustaining an important dimension of our shared dance heritage.

The dancers have trained in the Humphrey Technique through an experiential learning process. This intensive process will deepen the performers’ understanding and execution of Humphrey’s choreography, bringing her work into direct relation to present-day lives. Setting these works to live music performed on the organ by James Kibbe, Professor of Music and by the University of Michigan’s Baroque Chamber Orchestra will honor the full creative force of Humphrey’s vision.

University of Michigan Dance faculty Jillian Hopper and Christian Matijas-Mecca are producing the works. Staging will be by Gail Corbin and Jillian Hopper.  Rehearsals are underway and preview performances have galvanized audiences.
story_txt: The Dance Legacy ProjectIn Collaboration with the University of Michigan Organ Conference and The Baroque Chamber OrchestraThe Dance Legacy Project’s inaugural season marks the first time that Doris Humphrey's Air (1928), Passacaglia and Fugue in C Minor (1938), and Brandenburg Concerto No. 4 (1958/59) will be presented in a single concert with live music, reflecting the theme of the Conference: Trailblazers: Women's Impact on Organ, Carillon, Harpsichord, and Sacred Music.The ChallengeThe University of Michigan has generously supported this performance through three specific grants and rehearsal/performance space in kind.Only an additional $6,000 is needed.Funds are needed for guest artists to stage the works, to costume thirty-two dancers, to hire a stage manager and crew, to build and transport staging materials, to livestream the concert, and to provide modest promotional and administrative support.$500 pays for half of the event’s stage manager$1000 will cover half of the staging of the works by Trustees of the Doris Humphrey Foundation$2000 will pay for half of the unique and integral Humphrey costumes$2500 will pay for the archival recording and broadcasting of the concertClick on the BACK IT button at the top of the page, next to the video to DONATE any amount of your choosing. The ProjectHumphrey is one of North America’s preeminent pioneers in twentieth-century modern dance and one of the first women to lead her own company of professional dancers. Her love for the music of J.S. Bach is woven through her work. Talented dance students and faculty from the University of Michigan and Eastern Michigan University will perform three seminal dances spanning four decades of Humphrey’s influential career. These works are filled with hope, joy, and the harmony of dancing together. Presenting the legacy of Humphrey’s work will provide an historical connection to many of today's master works. In addition, the creative process of staging these works together will provide an impactful and unique creative experience for students, faculty, performers, and audience. The beauty and power of Humphrey’s work will transport, connect, and inspire this community, while sustaining an important dimension of our shared dance heritage.The dancers have trained in the Humphrey Technique through an experiential learning process. This intensive process will deepen the performers’ understanding and execution of Humphrey’s choreography, bringing her work into direct relation to present-day lives. Setting these works to live music performed on the organ by James Kibbe, Professor of Music and by the University of Michigan’s Baroque Chamber Orchestra will honor the full creative force of Humphrey’s vision.University of Michigan Dance faculty Jillian Hopper and Christian Matijas-Mecca are producing the works. Staging will be by Gail Corbin and Jillian Hopper.  Rehearsals are underway and preview performances have galvanized audiences.

story:
Our Show, In Between Dreaming and Sleep, ventures into the subconscious that can only be accessed in ones dreams. Why do we dream? And what do dreams mean anyways? Do they have a purpose, a deeper meaning, or are they just nonsensical activities of the sleeping brain? Is it in these moments of lucid exploration that a person's deepest desires and fears can be experienced? This show physically explores these questions in the search for what truly lies in between dreams and sleep.

 

Fundraising Goals 

We need your help to cover the costs of: 

  • Rehearsal Space and Performance Venue Rental 
  • Costumes/Props
  • Print Material/Marketing
  • Artists'/Choreographers/Stage Crew Fees

 

About the Team

To The Pointe Dance Project is a Hamilton based Dance Collective. Working to promote dance within the community, To The Pointe Dance Project strives to utilize dancers with connections to Hamilton and surrounding Arts Communities. What started out as a small workshop based collective has grown into a successful and accessible performing company. To The Pointe Dance Project’s work has been described as “a lyrical feast for the eyes that melts one’s soul”. 

Our contemporary dance production In Between Dreams and Sleep is being presented on Saturday December 1st, 2018 at The Staircase Theatre in Hamilton . Choreographed by Cassandra Bowerman, Alexandria DiFazio, Sarah Dowhun-Tompa and Alyssa Nedich, In Between Dreams and Sleep is a mixed program of both remounted and premiere performances danced by Elizabeth Alexander, Jenna Begon, Cassandra Bowerman, Alexandria DiFazio, Sarah Dowhun-Tompa, Samantha Etzel, Kelsey O’Callaghan, Alyssa Nedich, Josh Taylor, and Sharon Denise van Es.

 

If you can't contribute... 

Don't worry! Keep your eyes and ears peeled for more information regarding our show! Try to come out to a show or share one of our event and fundraiser with some friends. Any social media love that we can get will go a long way!

 

With Love,

To The Pointe Dance Project

story:
Who We Are

Maya Burton and Lexi Chipman originally created Raisins in a Glass of Milk as a one act play based on interviews with Theatre Makers of Color. Since their original script premiered in 2016 it has been shared in venues across the country.

Lexi Chipman is a Southern California native, who graduated from Cornish College of the Arts’ Theater Department in 2016. Since graduating she has performed with Seattle Shakespeare Company, Island Shakespeare Company, Copious Love Productions, Theater22, Radial Theater Company, The Williams Project, and more. She loves working with Live Girls!, you may have seen her performing in their Sleepover Fundraiser for Planned Parenthood (2016), 70’s Cabaret Fundraiser (2017), or Cabaret That Stole Christmas (2018).

Maya Burton, a Cornish College alum (2016), is beyond stoked to bring her and Lexi Chipman’s original play to a tenacious company like Live Girls! Since graduating she has performed with Seattle Shakespeare, Seattle Children’s Theatre, Taproot Theatre Company and more.

Live Girls! is now partnering with us to bring Raisins 2019 to the stage this February. Live Girls! is one of the longest running fringe theater companies in Seattle and has been dedicated to producing and developing new plays by womxn since 1999. They have fostered the creation of more than 300 theatrical works by womxn in their 19-year history and have also supported hundreds of female performers in multiple disciplines, including music, dance, comedy and improv, through their cabaret and performance series. www.lgtheater.org

 Live Girls! is powered by Shunpike.

Shunpike is the 501(c)(3) non-profit agency that provides independent arts groups in Washington State with the services, resources, and opportunities they need to forge their own paths to sustainable success.

 

What We Are Making

After producing the original script numerous times, we realized that there were still stories waiting to be told. That is when we decided to create an annual series simply known as Raisins. This production will be the first of many where we conduct new interviews and weave them into an original play to be produced every February. For Raisins 2019 we took 250 pages of candid responses and and crafted them into six multidimensional women with six different backgrounds and six distinct points of view. These women of color will be confronted with the question: “How can we dismantle white supremacy in the American theater?” In trying to find the answer they will walk to the edge of what is civil to find what is right.

 

How Important is It?

America is currently experiencing a cultural shift. We are seeing more representation on stage and in film. We are standing for black lives. We are marching for immigrant families. We are in the process of claiming seats in the house and Senate. The American tradition of institutionalized racism is beginning to crack. By directly telling more and more stories of People of Color, loudly, proudly, and without shame, we can make sure that this movement is not temporary, but creates permanent change. Raisins ignites the conversation that proves that People of Color should finally be seen as a standard, essential part of storytelling, as opposed to stereotypes, controversies, and out of date statements.

 

What we have in place now?

A provocative and truthful script, incredible actors, funds secured for space, rehearsal basics, and a portion of production expenses, and a secured performance venue at The Issac Studio at Taproot Theater Company! We are close, but we still have a little ways to go.

story:
$10,000 FOR OUR CAST!

Actors love their craft, but they like to eat, too! Often an amazing theater project suffers when a not-so-amazing film has more budget, for the actors. Actors prefer working on quality material, but far too often choose lesser quality to pay the bills.

We want our actors to be paid their worth, and be able to commit to this project.  

The Impact

You are supporting the return of quality theater entertainment

  • Hashtag Chris Missed is a new adult Holiday entertainment tradition. 
  • Be an active part of the evolution of live acting. 
  • A quality production can create ongoing, annual work, in Georgia and beyond.

Risks & Challenges

Although, your support will allow us to do so much more creatively, we are committed to providing for our ACTORS FIRST. 

  • Reaching this goal by September 23rd, will allow us to budget sponsorship donations wiser.
  • Your gift is guaranteed to be honored.

SHARE OUR CAMPAIGN

DO WHAT YOU CAN. SHARE, TAG, POST! Sharing this campaign on your social media or with your email contacts can help us reach out goal.

  • Indiegogo has great sharing tools! Try it now!

The actors of "Hashtag Chris Missed" thank you, right now!

story:
About Us

Our house is one built on a solid foundation of faith and excellence. We are an award-winning, multifaceted production company, with talent in theatre, film, and TV. A house where the lights are always on and where creatives are watered daily.

Our mission is to Share Our Stories With The World.

Hey, Troy here.....

Out of hundreds of entries, A Little Black Lie got selected to perform at the prestigious DC Black Theatre and Arts Festival in Washington, DC and we couldn't be more excited.  One of our goals for 2019 was to take ALBL on tour to the States in the Fall but clearly the Universe had other plans! At Crossfield House Productions, we believe in seizing opportunities when they come and performing our play twice on an international stage is one that we do not want to miss.  Since our beginning, CHP has been an independent, completely self funded company. As we get closer to Washington, we have realized that we need some help financially. We have a large team travelling (each person is needed, we cut where we could without sacrificing the integrity of the show) and the cost are higher than we anticipated (Thanks exchange rate!) and we also have the cost associated with producing our upcoming encore performance in Toronto in July.

Our community is rooted in everything that we do at CHP, you provide our stories, you are our biggest supporters and you are our biggest WHY...and we need your help to get us to DC.

 

What We Need & What You Get

So what do we need exactly? Our goal is to raise $3000.00.  This money will go towards the accommodations and transportation for our team. We will be renting cars to drive down and will be staying in Washington, DC from June 21st-June23rd.  

And guess what...your contribution could get you a part in our play! Or lunch with Troy! As a thank you we have some really cool perks available because we want to make sure that your support is acknowledged and that you know you are appreciated.

 

The Impact

"When I started Crossfield House Productions, initially I wanted a space where I could be creatively free. A place where you could pitch an idea or a dream and instead of being told ‘no’, you heard ‘let’s figure out how to get this done’. With that mindset and determination, and the support of my team, I’ve been able to turn my ideas into successful, sold out plays: A Little White Lie and A Little Black Lie. This year, 2019, we will be producing films which will give us a wider reach and more opportunities for our people."

The opportunities that will come out of performing ALBL in Washington will be huge for CHP and our community. Having an international platform where our voices will be heard and our talent seen, will give us more leverage & social capitol which will allow us to scale CHP to a global company where we will develop and grow other entrepreneurs and shine a bigger spotlight on our community.

Risks & Challenges

So what happens if we don't meet the goal? That's a great question, and while we are very optimistic that we will meet our goal, that is a reality that we are aware may happen. And the answer to that is....we will find the money somewhere, somehow.

Other Ways You Can Help

Currency comes in many forms and we appreciate any way that you can help. We ask that you please share this campaign with your network so that we can get the word out to as many people as possible.

story:
In spring of 2017, we debuted as a company with our very successful adaptation of Alice in Wonderland. And now we are following up with a new adaptation of Peter Pan, opening this January at the Lesher Center for the Arts in Walnut Creek.

For Peter Pan, we created this crowd funding campaign to secure the remaining funds we need for the budget. Your contributions will not only fund the show for it’s local debut, but thanks to our booking management company we are signed with, will allow the production to tour nationally and internationally for years to come!

For Alice in Wonderland, we used actors, high quality life sized puppetry, and a digitally projected Live Virtual Set to perform the stage show. You can click below to see the show onstage and see what we mean.

Alice in Wonderland Trailer

 

With Peter Pan we are going to perform the same way, but it will be a much bigger show!

  • Bigger digital display
  • Bigger puppets (crocodile anyone?)
  • Special effects
  • A bigger creative team
  • A longer story with an intermission, and…
  • We are moving into a larger, 800 seat theater!

 

What makes this show different?

While we’re keeping the story line and the characters that everyone loves, we’re putting our own fun twist on the show in our adaptation! We have 9 original puppets onstage and 11 well-known songs performed live with rewritten lyrics. And of course, flying! With the use of our Live Virtual Set, we can make Peter and Wendy fly through the air and into Never Land!

Our shows are highly entertaining, not only for children, but especially for parents as well. Everyone loves our offbeat humor, adults love waiting to hear what song comes next that they will recognize with cleverly written lyrics. Not to mention who doesn’t love the nostalgia of seeing larger than life puppets onstage!?

 

The Impact

As a nationally recognized company, we travel to different performing arts centers for both public performances and school matinee performances. 

Our adaptation of Peter Pan will teach children the power of their choices, and to place attention on what they want to create in their life. As Wendy learns from the Lost Boys, "A brain full of fear has no room left for dreams!" Curriculum connections include literature, writing, critical thinking, STEAM, and social-emotional learning.

 

What We Need

Our productions are completely created from scratch with attention to detail. Each individual puppet is designed, engineered and built by hand, which can take up to 200 hours to create. All costuming is original and built by hand. The software for the Live Virtual Set takes hundreds of hours to create by Steve Axtell and his staff at Axtell Expressions.

Campaign contributions will fund-

  • PUPPETS Material costs for building the 9 characters from foam, fleece, metal, hardware,  wood, plastic, fur, paint, adhesives and much more!
  • DIGITAL SCENERY The Live Virtual Set artwork and software takes hundreds of hours to create by Steve Axtell and his team at Axtell Expressions in Southern California.
  • EQUIPMENT For Peter Pan we are purchasing a much larger digital display screen, as well as fog/smoke machines, show running software
  • COSTUMES We are bringing back Jayne Serba,(costume designer of Beach Blanket Babylon for over 20 years) who costumed Alice in Wonderland!
  • WIGS Custom created wigs made by artisans from San Francisco Opera!
  • ADDITIONAL SCENERY & PROPS Risers, cubes/boxes and even a large rowboat!
  • MARKETING Professional Promotional photos and videos, Digital Advertising, Posters, postcards, sponsored social media posts.
  • LEGAL Copyrights, Trademarks, Licenses, Insurance.

 

What you get, The Perks!!

We are excited to be giving back to those who contribute! Take a look at the rights side of this page to see all of the Perks we are offering with your contribution! Perks include exclusive free merchandise, behind-the-scenes pictures and videos of rehearsals, free tickets, invite only post-show-discussions, and staged photos on set with our characters!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Contribute without a perk. If none of these perks call out to you, but you would still like to contribute, simply click the BACK IT button at the very top of the page. You will be prompted to enter a dollar amount for your contribution. You can do so anonymously or by letting us know who to thank!

Become an Executive Producer! If you would like to contribute beyond the perk levels we have listed, please email us at dluxpuppets@gmail.com to discuss how you can become an executive producer!

Please share and invite friends on Facebook and other social media to join us in our campaign. We hope to share this show and this message with as many people as possible!

 

THANK YOU for your support!

We are so incredibly grateful for our supporters and fans.

Thank you for being a part of our journey to Never Land! See you at the show!

 

With Gratitude,

Derek and Lauren Lux

Founders of DLUX Puppets

 

SHOW DETAILS

DLUX Puppets' Peter Pan 

January 27 & February 2, 2019 at 2pm

Lesher Center for the Arts

1601 Civic Drive Walnut Creek, CA 94598

 

Tickets on sale now!

http://lesherartscenter.showare.com/DLUXPuppetsPeterPan

or by calling (925) 943-SHOW

story:
Be Part of our (Re)Evolution!

Dear Community,

Thank you for reading/watching,

I am really excited about this new project: a dance theatre piece called Foreign Bodies: An Underwater Love Story which is a multi-sensory experience that crosses borders and oceans to challenge the human collision of difference.

With Ella Mesma Company we have enjoyed some incredible opportunities across the globe and are so grateful for every part of it: every success, every failure has brought us here... it is all absolutely a gift and a shaping of the art we make and how we communicate our story.

We are so happy with what we have raised so far and still have a way to go! We would love your help to spread the word about what we do, or your donation to the creation of our set for this amazing show which Elsabet Yonas described recently as "A powerful show about the complexity and simplicity of the human experience. the interconnectedness of love, the illusion of fear and how it manifests in to separation, racism, otherness. Connected by a game show host and danced by a cast of Jellyfish - I don't think you've seen anything quite like it"

Below you can find out more about the project and our work, or you can just go straight to the donate button!

Thanks for all your love and connection! xxx

About Ella Mesma and our company

My name is Ella, and I am an artist. As well as having had an amazing career as a performer (read all about that here), I own and direct Ella Mesma Company: with whom I have enjoyed some incredible opportunities across the globe (See more about our work here), and I am so grateful for every part of it: every success, every failure has brought me here... it is all absolutely a gift and a shaping of the art I make and how I communicate my story.

We can all use art for positive change... in this daily struggle to be human, it is easy to feel disheartened, not to go for what we would love, or to settle... there have been many moments in my life when I have made choices which were not true to what I would love to create... but  the further I step on my own Path and find out more about who I am... I realise... first and foremost... I am an Artist! And the Earth without Art is just EH!

I recently re-read this quote by James Baldwin, and I have found myself returning to it every day this week... because it reminds me how powerful art is! How art can be a part of our own evolution... and of revolution... Art touches our hearts so deeply... just as these words do mine!

"It seems to me that the artist’s struggle for his integrity must be considered as a kind of metaphor for the struggle, which is universal and daily, of all human beings on the face of this globe to get to become human beings… The poets (by which I mean all artists) are finally the only people who know the truth about us. Soldiers don’t. Statesmen don’t. Priests don’t. Union leaders don’t. Only the poets".

Why are we here? 

We are here on Indiegogo because Ella Mesma Company are currently creating an amazing multi-sensory dance and theatre experience, a quiz show and a re-evolution for our beautiful audience: you!

And we would LOVE your help!

We are super excited about the piece... you have probably seen lots of social media posts about our latest project: Foreign Bodies: An Underwater Love Story, because it is... well.... awesome! Danced by four beautiful, heartfelt, fun, genius dance artists: Isaac Ouro Gnao, David Evans, Elsabet Yonas, Franck Arnaud- Lusbec, Lucia Afonso, and one super talented and very funny actor: Milton Lopes (plus my voice makes a few appearances from back stage!), the piece is a powerful look at our world, the complexity and simplicity of the human experience. the interconnectedness of love, the illusion of fear and how it manifests in to separation, racism, otherness.

You will be hearing us talking about jellyfish ALOT in the next few months! 

In Foreign Bodies: An Underwater Love Story, we look to nature and the way of the Jellyfish, and how the earth works together as one cooperation (We think we humans can learn a lot from nature!). The piece was inspired by a metaphor I came across for healing from trauma: there is one type of jellyfish that takes little bits of nutrients from the sea bed and on the way up to the surface deposits little bits: providing nutrients for the whole ecosystem. 

I recently read a book called: "The vanishing face of Gaia"... and was inspired by this concept, as well as my studies of the age of Aquarius, and my hope for our spiritual evolution... of the evolving of the human psyche, of the evolution through healing from our traumas, of how we evolve and grow together when we connect, collaborate, and move up to the vibration of love and out of the low vibration of fear...

When I refer to LOVE overcoming fear, I refer to the innate fear for survival in every human, and I also refer to the current political climate: to the fear we hear repeatedly in the news: the xenophobic fear of 'other', to that time when Teresa May said that we humans are not allowed to be "Citizens of the World", to the votes that mean that we are now leaving Europe, to the 70 countries which now have built fences and walls as borders, and the 65 million people displaced since 2018 (the highest since World War 2!) 

This story was also inspired by the love story (and the fight for their love) of my parents of different ethnicities/heritages in the 70s and 80s, and by the fear-mongering and xenophobic hate we seem to be bombarded with when we pick up the newspapers, or look on twitter, or switch on the tv this year. This piece of work is super important to all of us in the company: all having had direct personal experiences related to this topic which have fed in to the work.

I originally dreamed up this interactive quiz show that crosses borders and oceans to challenge the human collision of difference: because I believe Art... the artists (and I believe we are ALL artists!) have a real power to understand, to tell real stories and to shout: in some ways more effectively than politicians (but perhaps not including my heroine Alexandria Ocasio Cortes!), and to give people a voice... but also to question our vote... our voice... to imagine a world where we were not about to Brexit, and to allow us to think about that: does our vote count?

In the wake of the doom and gloom of Brexit, we hope that this underwater world presents a utopian alternative reality: a world where there is no racism, no colourism, no inequality, no passports, no borders...and where the audience can reflect on what is gained and what is lost through cultural exchange and connection. 

So now! Now we are awaiting an Arts Council Grant, and raising £2000 alongside that here, to create our set! 

You will see sneak preview pictures of our set if you donate, made by the amazing Chris Durant in Newcastle! Our final R&D will happen in November, with the full cast, the amazing Shelley Maxwell as Rehearsal Director and finally working with the set design, technology and lighting design to realise the piece.

We will be sharing the work at three Northern Venues, and everyone who donates will also be invited to watch on live stream. After this... the piece will be ready! We will be taking bookings (plus setting up our own UK tour!) You will be contributing to our company: Ella Mesma Company having a piece ready before going out on the road, and actually doing it properly! (Wahooooo!)

What We Need?

 

  • This crowd funder is to go towards realising the set design, created by Chris Durant from Northern Stage, the full set comes to £2069.88 (we have added on the 5% that Indiegogo take on top so in total, we need to raise £2173.37) We know we will raise that with your help and because we are 100% focused on that End Result: so we hugely appreciate your being a part of that journey with us... and for that reason... there is no need to imagine any other scenario! (But no matter what, we do get to keep the money: and it goes towards our set).
  • These costs cover: Sheet Ply, Timber, Consummables, The paint finish, Festoon, Cables, Lamp holders, Lamps,Joining connectors, Staff costs (electrician, scenic art, a builder), The workshop hire and the VAT to realise this work... all things which I know not much about, but I do know exactly what I want to create and I love the design! 
  • We need the set as part of the audience part in our Love Story: you guys will be voting in the show, and your votes will show up in real time on the set! (How exciting!) This is something I have been dreaming about since I first had the idea 3 years ago!

What You Get

We have loads of prizes for donators to the campaign!

  1. First of all, everybody will invited to watch the full sharing: we will hold three in the North of England... and for all our friends in the rest of the world, we will invite you via live stream. (Everyone welcome: we will send you your invitation upon donation)
  2. We have 5 guest tickets to watch the show during our tour at the city of your choice (again make sure you leave your email to be contacted and for us to choose which city you will watch the show in. (This is for donations of £200 and above)
  3. We have 3 invitations to watch a private rehearsal either during this phase or during our tour at the city of your choice (again make sure you leave your email to be contacted: for you to choose which city you will watch in!) (This can be selected upon donation)
  4. We have 2 personal videos which we will make for your enjoyment during our rehearsals,,, (This one can be selected upon donation!)
  5. We have one dinner invitation (In Newcastle!) We will cook you a feast! Come round and hang out with the whole company for one evening (This one can be selected upon donation: you just need to come to our rehearsals in Newcastle!)
  6. We will also do one VIP giveaway: for one lucky donator (selected with your name in the hat)... We will write to each donator personally (please make sure you leave us your email address to be contacted!) to take part in a draw for our Maya Gandaia trip to Thailand with all of the teaching fees discounted (so you will pay only for your stay at the gorgeous 5* resort and your flights but get all your classes and workshops completely free!)
  7. A sneak preview of the set you have paid towards.
  8. A review courtesy of Isaac Ouro Gnao for your piece of art

Why Us?

  1. We are a beautiful family: and we consider you a part of it too!
  2. We are so grateful for every single part of this journey: and we honour and love you for your support in every way!
  3. This show is set to be the best Ella Mesma Company show yet... maybe the best show ever! And you will be part of making that happen!
  4. The company members are really good! You should see this dream team they are flipping awesome... Show them you believe in them!
  5. We never give up... We have made loads of stuff before, we make shit happen... no matter what... 
  6. With each opportunity to practise, we just keep honing our skills bigger and better, and finding our unique voice.
  7. Our work is different, underground, sometimes a bit alternative, sometimes a bit political, sometimes a bit revolutionary (We love it that way: because we believe that what art should be all about: and if you are here you probably do too!)
  8. Artists deserve pay... artists have mad dope skills... exposure and experience don't pay our rent, (unfortunately, as a female choreographer, we are expected to just pull things out the bag on little money a lot more often than our male peers)... so sometimes we need to be creative about ways to make things happen... such as asking our audiences to  invest in us...
  9. Some of the shows we have made in the past were made on little or no budget.... But look what can we do with money! With this money to make the set, with this funding... we will make an amazing show!
  10. Sadly, if we don't have this money... there is no set, there is no audience participation, there is no quiz show... Yes we really cannot have a set without this money! The show... whilst awesome... will be flipping amazing (and hilarious: Milton is brilliant!) with this set and this quiz show as a part of it!

Thank you!

Thank you everyone for reading, for supporting, to all who have funded and supported us, to all who have encouraged us, to everyone who has supported our crowdfunders in the past, for everyone supporting us by liking what we do, for coming to our shows, for the shares of things we might like, for offering us ideas, opinions... we love and value you! 

Other Ways You Can Help

  1. Some people just can't contribute, we totally understand (we have been there too!) But that doesn't mean you can't be a part of the revolution! Help us by shouting about our dream team! Help us to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! (Just click Share!)
  2. Stay in touch: share your thoughts, talk to us, talk to each other, make art, be part of the (re)volution!

THANK YOU WE LOVE YOU!

story:
THE OPEN BOOK THEATRE COMPANY

New York City’s Oldest Established Reader’s Theatre Company

A Not-for-Profit Organization

The Open Book is New York City's first and longest lived Readers Theatre Company, established in 1975. 

Readers Theatre can be as basic as stools on a stage, or elaborate with costumes, sets, props and the like—but always with at least one actor, often all, with script in hand. This is our link to theater and the printed word.

For over 40 years The Open Book has presented the best of all worlds of literature — drama, comedy, prose, poetry, even nonfiction — to our culturally diverse audiences, including literature of excellence likely to be bypassed by more traditional theatre companies. The astounding creative talents behind TOB are teaming up with celebrated artists to create new, innovative, and most importantly, entertaining productions that can take an audience out of itself, and into our reality—with shows for kids, families and adults.

Your dollars will help us to continue our tradition of presenting fine theatre, and to preserve and perpetuate the Art of Readers Theatre.

 

BE AN ANGEL!

Funding for the Next Generation of TOB

-----------

Did you know that people who invest in or donate to theatre are called angels?

-----------

Your generous contributions will first and foremost help us to meet our goals for the new millennium.

The Open Book has got some big plans. Among them are:

•Put on more productions for longer runs

•Present better known authors and works to gain recognition 

• Perform in established, well situated theatrical venues 

•Resume our free educational and entertainment programs for schools, veterans, service personnel and seniors

•Reestablish our International Playwriting Competition

• and a whole bunch more.

Resources made available through sponsorships, memberships, ticket sales and fundraising, will allow TOB to perform in more notable venues and market more effectively, as well as to expand it’s use of theatrical trappings such as sets and lighting.

ALL contributors will become members of The Open Book, and receive our (infrequent) newsletters, offers for discounted or free tickets, invitations to special events, discounts on merchandise and a bunch of other great perks. Plus, there will be additional benefit for people donating big bundles of money!

Our stated goal will help us put on our two upcoming productions, A CONFUSED HANUKKAH and THE LAST CHRISTMAS OF EBENEZER SCROOGE, which will run simultaneously during Christmas/Hanukkah week, 2019.

Truly Original

The Open Book is the first and oldest Readers Theatre company in NYC, and remains the premiere presenter of original works by new authors and playwrights. By doing what we do, we are not only creating great theatre, but helping to discover undiscovered talent, and set them on their way into a career in the arts. A worthy goal, which your contribution will be vital in continuing.

It ain't all Bows.

Any endeavor in the arts is a risky business, and theatre probably tops the list. A show may be wildly successful, or close with a whimper. Our limited run performances are generally well attended, but covering the costs of promotion and theater rental has become more difficult over the decades as costs go up and up. Venue space, advertising, printing and the like just keep going up. Your donation will help us overcome that obstacle. 

Got no cash but a love of the arts?

We understand if you'd like to help but just don't have the money. (Hey, we are actors and authors and all, so having no money is certainly not unknown to us. On a regular basis.)

If you'd like to be involved in creating wondrous theater, we are always in need of help: stage managers, tech crew, hospitality folk, and most especially promotion and advertising. Who knows where you might fit in? Let us know, and we'll let you know!

story:
Over the past 25 years, our company has been of service, playing back community stories of resistance, immigration, love, home, and activism. We’ve performed hundreds of times across the United States in an effort to create healing, connection and community. If you’ve seen Playback Theatre, you know how vital this work can be to combat hate and suffering with empathy and understanding. As a diverse collective of 14 artists, we feel called to this work.

At the International Playback Theatre Conference in India, the Living Arts Playback Theatre Ensemble will assist in a workshop facilitated by our director, psychotherapist and drama therapist, Armand Volkas. He will guide conference attendees in a process that focuses on  intercultural conflict transformation and healing historical trauma. Armand will use his approach with the goal of building empathy between historical enemies through Playback Theatre. Through Armand’s facilitation, Playback Theatre practitioners from many countries and cultures will be exposed to his innovative Peacebuilding work.

If you are able to donate a gift of any amount, you’ll be investing in peace during a time of deep division in our country and beyond. You’ll be sending us to India to learn from other artists and healers. For you, community, we are deeply grateful.

 

THE ENSEMBLE 

The Living Arts Playback Theatre Ensemble is a diverse collective of artists, drama therapists, special needs parents, organizational leaders, professional actors, classically trained musicians, chi-gung masters, improvisors, immigrants, jazz musicians, and educators. We have founding members that have been with us since the beginning.

The chance to take center stage in front of an international audience is the opportunity of a lifetime for us. We’ll be there to listen and learn from other changemakers. Funding this trip is funding our evolution as humans.

We can’t wait to bring this experience right back to you.

 

OUR DIRECTOR 

Armand Volkas  is the Director of the Living Arts Playback Theatre Ensemble. He is a psychotherapist and Registered Drama Therapist in private practice and Clinical Director of the Living Arts Counseling Center in Oakland, California, where he directs a training program for students, interns and therapists who want to integrate drama therapy into their practice. Drama Therapy uses acting improvisation and Psychodrama as therapeutic tools. He is a Board Certified Trainer in this discipline with The National Association for Drama Therapy. In addition, Armand is Associate Professor in the Counseling Psychology Program at California Institute of Integral Studies and Adjunct Professor at John F. Kennedy University. He has developed innovative programs using drama therapy and expressive arts therapies for social change, intercultural conflict resolution, reconciliation and intercultural communication. Volkas directs Healing the Wounds of History, a therapeutic approach in which theatre techniques are used to work with groups of participants from two cultures with a common legacy of violent conflict and historical trauma. At the heart of Armand’s work is a profound respect for the power of personal story to build bridges between people and cultures.
story_txt:
Over the past 25 years, our company has been of service, playing back community stories of resistance, immigration, love, home, and activism. We’ve performed hundreds of times across the United States in an effort to create healing, connection and community. If you’ve seen Playback Theatre, you know how vital this work can be to combat hate and suffering with empathy and understanding. As a diverse collective of 14 artists, we feel called to this work.
At the International Playback Theatre Conference in India, the Living Arts Playback Theatre Ensemble will assist in a workshop facilitated by our director, psychotherapist and drama therapist, Armand Volkas. He will guide conference attendees in a process that focuses on  intercultural conflict transformation and healing historical trauma. Armand will use his approach with the goal of building empathy between historical enemies through Playback Theatre. Through Armand’s facilitation, Playback Theatre practitioners from many countries and cultures will be exposed to his innovative Peacebuilding work.
If you are able to donate a gift of any amount, you’ll be investing in peace during a time of deep division in our country and beyond. You’ll be sending us to India to learn from other artists and healers. For you, community, we are deeply grateful.
